PROCTEXT.PARA: Mr SPEAKER (Hon. Harry Jenkins) took the chair at 10 a.m., and read prayers.

PETITION.TITLE: Chiropractic Services
PETITION.PARA: The Clerk-Petitions have been lodged for presentation as follows and copies will be referred to the appropriate Ministers:
Chiropractic Services
To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled: The humble petition of certain citizens of Australia shows :
That, with the exception of the Australian Capital Territory and the Northern Territory, all State Parliaments have enacted chiropractic legislation.
That chiropractors provide a safe, effective and economical health care service that is complementary to medicine.

That the introduction of a Federally funded health care system restricted to the services provided almost exclusively by the medical profession restricts the freedom to select the health care practitioner of one's choice and does nothing to reduce the high cost of health care in Australia.
That a financial disadvantage will be incurred by those citizens utilising chiropractic care, many of whom find that their health complaints do not respond satisfactorily to traditional approaches.
Your petitioners therefore pray that the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled ensures that chiropractic services are included in Medicare when it is introduced.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mr Cadman,Mr Gorman,Mr Hawker and Mr Porter.

PETITION.TITLE: Kangaroos
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The petition of concerned people respectfully showeth their desire to stop the commercial exploitation of the kangaroo.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that your honourable House re-apply the ban on the export of kangaroo products.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mr Coleman,Mrs Darling and Mr Gorman.

PETITION.TITLE: National Life and Democratic Institutions
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled: The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:

That we, the loyal citizens of Australia firmly express our strong opposition to any proposals to remove or undermine the importance of the place of God and/ or the Queen in our national life, and democratic institutions.

Your petitioners therefore humbly pray: That the Parliament assembled reaffirm our nation's total dependence on God the Creator in accordance with our Australian Constitution, which commences with the words ''Humbly relying on the blessing of Almighty God'', and the Standing Orders of both the Senate and the House of Representatives which prescribe that Parliament each day shall open with a special prayer to Almighty God and the Lord's Prayer.
We also call on the Parliament assembled to re-affirm our genuine loyalty to our Head of State, the Queen of Australia, Elizabeth II-'God save the Queen'.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mr Carlton and Mr Simmons.

PETITION.TITLE: Sex Discrimination Legislation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. That the Sex Discrimination Bill 1983 contains provisions inconsistent with principles of justice and equality which could be used to:
Undermine civil liberties and religious freedom;
Entrench abortion funding and render liable to action hospitals, doctors and nurses, who conscientiously refuse to become involved in morally objectionable operations;
Deny to parents their rights to insist that the school ''community'' provide an environment conducive to the development, including moral development of their children.
Deny to parents their rights to have their children enjoy single-sex sporting activities, e.g., boys' cricket team, boys' football team, etc.

Your petitioners humbly pray that the Parliament assembled: should amend the Bill so as to prevent the possibility of its use in the manner stated above and urge, because of the importance to society of all principles involved, that a conscience vote on the Bill be permitted to all members of Parliament.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mr Cohen and Mr Simmons.

PETITION.TITLE: Proposed Airport at Scheyville, New South Wales
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
1. That an airport in the north-west region (commonly called Scheyville) imposes disastrous economic, environmental and social costs on our community.

2. Note that such a proposal will result in the destruction of the historic village of Pitttown, Longneck Wildlife Reserve, significant Aboriginal relics and the historic Scheyville Camp and will irreversibly alter the character of the five Macquarie towns.
3. Consider the resulting intolerable pollution of the Hawkesbury River.
4. Note that approximately 2,000 properties will be resumed, displacing over 5, 000 residents.

5. Consider the detrimental effects of noise, air and vehicular pollution on many thousands of residents in the surrounding districts of Hawkesbury, Baulkham Hills and Hornsby Shires and Blacktown and Penrith cities.
6. Give immediate consideration to finding a more suitable alternative site.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Brisbane Airport: Curfew
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully show:

That the potential noise hazard to residents of Sandgate, Shorncliffe, Brighton and Nudgee Beach (including 4,000 aged people), will become intolerable when the new Brisbane Airport is operative in 1987, if protective action is not taken.
Your petitioners therefore pray that the Federal Government will, when the redevelopment of the Brisbane Airport becomes operative, ensure that
i no jet aircraft use the 32'14' crosswind runway;
ii the Department maintain the curfew on the runway from 10 p.m. to 6 a.m.

PETITION.TITLE: Medicare: Queensland
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned respectfully showeth:
We have become the innocent victims of your Government's Medicare scheme.
We are forced to pay 1% of our wages only to receive less per capita benefits than the people of other states.

Without canvassing the rights or wrongs of the dispute between the Federal Government and the State of Queensland the fact is that because of it over one million Queenslanders, who contribute to health funds, are being blatantly discriminated against compared with people in the rest of Australia.
Because of the dispute over the introduction of Medicare, Queensland public hospital bed charges are $120 per day compared with $80 per day in the other states. This is grossly unfair.
As it was the Federal Government which decided to introduce Medicare, we believe it is their responsibility to take action allowing health funds' rates in Queensland to be kept at reasonable levels.

Your petitioners most humbly pray that the House of Representatives assembled, should, use its influence with Government so as to avoid the discrimination (of $40 per day) against insured Queenslanders.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Education Funding
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled, the petition of the undersigned citizens, teachers and parents working in and for the interests of the pupils in government schools and colleges throughout Australia, respectfully showeth that:

1. We deplore the unprincipled and self-interested attacks being orchestrated by minority sects and groups against the policies and person of the Commonwealth Minister for Education and Youth Affairs, the Hon. Senator Susan Ryan.
2. We fully support the Federal Government's actions in reducing funds for the wealthiest private schools, and in breaking the nexus between government and non -government school costs.

3. We endorse the Federal Government's principled opposition to the provision of 'base grants' to all non-government schools, as a positive step towards fulfilling their commitment of primary obligation to Australia's government schools.

4. We call upon the Federal Government however to recognise that its failure to create an adequate general recurrent source base for government schools through providing increased recurrent grants, will undermine its own Special Programs and thus frustrate its own stated educational objectives of greater equity and participation.

5. We support the Federal Government's stated policy of entering into direct negotiations for joint agreement on these grants with State/Territory Governments, to ensure a planned programme of improvements in government schools throughout the coming decade.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Education Funding
PETITION.PARA: The Honourable, the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives of the Commonwealth of Australia in Parliament assembled. The petition from parents representing the government schools in New South Wales respectfully showeth that :
1. They call on the Federal Government to re-affirm publicly that its primary obligation is to government schools.
2. They support the Federal Government's policy decisions which have reduced funding to wealthy private schools and which have broken the nexus between government and non-government school costs.
3. They endorse the Federal Government's opposition to the provision of a 'base grant' to all non-government schools.
4. They ask that the Federal Government create a general recurrent resource base which is adequate for government schools through the provision of increased recurrent funding.

5. They call upon the Federal Government to negotiate agreements with State/ Territory governments which will ensure a planned program of improvements in government schools throughout the coming decade.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Paterson's Curse
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives of Australia. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully requests that legislation be enacted to permit the biological control of the weed known as 'Paterson's curse'.
The petitioners wish to express their most serious concern regarding the recent spread of this weed and the resultant loss in primary production.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Australian Capital Territory Road Works
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in the Parliament assembled. The humble petition of certain citizens of Australia shows :

That Bozlin Pty. Ltd. trading as John Bozic Automotive Services, have provided for many years good and reliable service to customers near Parliament House, and represent the only Automotive Service Station available in the Parliamentary triangle, convenient to visitors and persons working at, or near, Parliament House.
That the National Capital Development Commission has indicated its intention to close the access road between Coronation Drive and Kaye Place.

That access has existed in one form or another between Kaye Place and Coronation Drive for most of the last fifty years, and in the judgment of petitioners that access road is convenient, and represents no traffic hazard.
Your petitioners therefore pray that the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled will ensure that the traffic link between Coronation Drive and Kaye Place is not closed.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Ministry of Peace and Nuclear Disarmament
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
1. The concerns which people around the World have for the increasing stockpiles of weapons of mass destruction;
2. The global concern that any nuclear exchange will inflict on humanity unimaginable death and suffering;
3. The vulnerability that Australians will face in any nuclear conflict between the major powers;
4. The public concern that Government should explore all avenues to ensure that the nuclear threat is eliminated

Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the Australian Parliament establish a Select Committee on Nuclear Disarmament and Peace to investigate the creation of a Ministry of Peace and Nuclear Disarmament.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Bank Account Debit Tax
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
We, as members of a school Parent Club object to legislation that calls for the payment of the Bank Debit Tax by a voluntary organisation working for the benefit of children in government schools.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that Exemption from the payment of Bank Debit Tax will be granted to School Parents' Clubs in government schools
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Australian Capital Territory: Self-Government
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth: That in November 1978 more than sixty two per cent of the voters of the Australian Capital Territory in a Referendum rejected the introduction of Territorial Government or Local Government in the Australian Capital Territory.

That until the findings of the Commonwealth Grants Commission inquiry into Australian Capital Territory finances have been made public and there has been a Referendum of the voters of the Australian Capital Territory as to their attitude to Territorial or Local Government. Your petitioners most humbly pray that the Government take no further action nor legislate in respect of Territorial or Local Government in the Australian Capital Territory.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Uranium
PETITION.PARA: To the Speaker, House of Representatives, Parliament House, Canberra. We call on the Australian Government to reverse the decision to proceed with the development of uranium mining at Roxby Downs because of;
the destruction of aboriginal sites
the irreparable damage to the environment
the threat to the health and safety of Australian citizens especially aboriginals and mining workers and the
undeniable link between uranium mining and nuclear weapons production and proliferation.
We ask that all uranium mining and export cease.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Advertising of Alcohol
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the citizens of Queensland respectfully shows:
last year, over 3,300 people died on Australian roads;
alcohol is a factor in 50% of road deaths;
alcohol advertisements do not show the perils of driving after drinking alcohol ;
alcohol advertisements are glamorous and increase their effect on teenagers, indicating drinking alcohol as the social pastime;
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the Parliament will legislate to ban the advertising of alcohol from commercial television and radio.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Bank Account Debit Tax
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in the Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of the State of Victoria showeth our concern over the continuing taxation of Parents' Club bank accounts by way of the Bank Account Debit Tax.
Your petitioners therefore pray that-

Parent clubs being set up by Government Regulation in the State of Victoria ( Regulation XLII) be recognised by the Australian Government as education auxiliaries, in the same way as are School Councils.
The Treasurer move immediately to exempt Parent Clubs from the tax in the same way as are School Councils.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Proposed Assyrian Ethnic Health Worker Position, Fairfield area, New South Wales
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives of Australia in Parliament assembled. This petition of the Assyrian community respectfully showeth that the position of the Assyrian Health worker be created on a permanent basis by the Health Department, to assist all Assyrians in health and social matters.

The position has to date been funded for a period of nine months under the wage pause program. This has shown the very real need of the Assyrian community for a worker who can make Australian services and information accessible to the Assyrian community.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that your honourable House create a permanent position of Assyrian Ethnic health worker based in the Fairfield area to assist Assyrians in need.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PROCTEXT.PARA: The following Bills were returned from the Senate without amendment or requests :
Shipping Registration Amendment Bill 1984
Protection of the Sea (Shipping Levy) Amendment Bill 1984
Assent reported.
Bill received from the Senate, and read a first time.
Ordered that the second reading be made an order of the day for a later hour this day.
Bill presented by Mr Barry Jones, and read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Jones The Hon B.O.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.

The Patents Amendment Bill 1984 does not make any dramatic policy changes. It does, however, reflect dramatic changes in technology which are taking place in the world. Those changes will continue whether or not Australian industry meets the challenge to take part in them. The role of government in meeting the challenge includes assisting industry to identify areas in which Australians can participate effectively and fruitfully. The crisis confronting Australian industry is that we are falling behind the rest of the world. To keep up we must concentrate on areas in which Australia can generate new technologies and take a fair share of tomorrow's prosperity. One such area already identified is biotechnology. The purpose of the Patents Amendment Bill is to encourage commercial realisation of biotechnology research in Australia. The Bill also makes possible Australia's accession to the Budapest Treaty on the International Recognition of the Deposit of Micro-organisms for the purposes of Patent Procedure. These measures complement a program of government support for biotechnology including a Budget allocation for 1983-84 of $12.2m.
Good research, but where is the development?

Australia was once content to ride on the sheep's back, but the time came when the sheep was no longer moving fast enough to keep up with the rest of the world . The wool market was not enough to ensure national prosperity, so we eventually took an interest in manufacturing and mining. Now some of us are clinging to a new sheep's back in the form of out-dated technology. With its 15 million people , Australia has 0.3 per cent of the world's population. We perform 2.0 per cent of the world's scientific research, but originate only 0.7 per cent of patents and undertake only 0.1 per cent of high technology production. Australia is in the middle rank of the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development nations in terms of government expenditure on research and development. But because of the very small contribution by industry we fall near the bottom of the list in terms of gross expenditure on research and development.

Of a total of $1,054m spent on gross expenditure on research and development in Australia during 1978-79, government sources funded four-fifths. Business enterprise sources were responsible for only one-fifth of the funds. The poor performance of the Australian private sector in research and development finds its reflection in Australia's comparative standing as a technologically advanced country. The Australian Bureau of Statistics collects information relating to receipts and payments by business for technical know-how. Figures for 1981-82 show that, uncorrected for inflation, both payments and receipts decreased in the period from 1978-79 to 1981-82, payments by 8 per cent and receipts by 7 per cent. By comparison with other OECD countries, Australia's level of both import and export is very low. It may come as no surprise that the Netherlands had receipts for technical know-how of the order of twenty times as great as ours in 1978; but payments also were much higher-three times our level. On an expenditure basis, Australia performs about 0.9 per cent of the world's applied research and experimental development other than that performed by the United States, and over the period 1963-79 obtained 0.9 per cent of the foreign patents awarded in the United States. Nevertheless, on a per capita basis Australia was strongly outperformed in United States patents by the small developed European nations, specifically Switzerland, Sweden, Netherlands, Belgium, Austria and Denmark.

My science and technology statement for 1982-83 presents the results of a collation of statistics relating to the import and export of goods with a high research component. This collation shows that in 1980 Australia exported $US81 per capita of such goods, which makes for a startling comparison with Switzerland, for which the figure is $2,584, a bare $2,003 ahead of us per capita; Netherlands $1,378; Belgium-Luxemburg $1,352; Sweden $1,087; Denmark $ 882; Austria $720; Ireland $589; Finland $509 and Norway $507.
Patents Amendment Bill

TALK.START.PARA: —What about the United States?

—It is much higher than us. But it is not smaller than we are in population, and all of these other nations are. The figure taken over all OECD nations is $US468 per capita, with Portugal, Greece and Turkey having lower figures than Australia. Even the figure for New Zealand is higher.

SPEECH.PARA: In 1980-81 Australia ran a trade deficit of some $A6 billion in goods with a high research component. The deficit for all manufactures was about $10 billion; overall there was a trade balance, with imports and exports each totalling about $19 billion. A deficit in goods having a significant research component has been a normal part of Australia's trade pattern, but in the last decade it has increased rapidly. Thus we find ourselves in Australia doing a great deal of pure research but not making much commercial or economic gain from it. Government funded pure research largely passes into the public domain and Australian industry clings to the technological sheep's back of the 1950s and 1960s.
Biotechnology

Radical change is needed to correct this imbalance. Australia must make a transition towards newly developing high technology 'sunrise' industries as wealth generators for our future, in addition to restructuring and revitalising our existing industrial base. Of these sunrise industries, biotechnology holds the greatest promise. It is parsimonious and efficient in its use of resources, and has almost unbounded applications in many areas of technology.

There is nothing frightening in basing economic activities on the useful properties of living things. Agriculture has always been so based. Micro- organisms have been used for millennia to make cheese, wine, beer and bread. Industrial fermentations to produce antibiotics, citric acid and ethanol have been used for decades. That is not to mention that amazingly adaptable bacterium , E. coli, now famous in biotechnology, that accompanies all of us, which has been serving the alimentary needs of the human species throughout the entire peristaltic course of history. Modern biotechnology expands and refines the use of living organisms into new and marvellously exciting areas of activity. Human insulin produced by genetically modified micro-organisms is now on the market.

Most important for Australia, we have biotechnology researchers who are world leaders in agriculture, plant and animal genetics, microbiology, biochemistry and medical research. We must take advantage of the leads we have. A symposium and a workshop arranged through my Department have identified the following priority areas: Plant agriculture, including genetic engineering to modify microbes, and tissue culture to improve plant species; veterinary research, particularly on diagnostic probes and vaccines; animal husbandry, including advanced breeding techniques and work on animal hormones; human pharmaceutical and medical research, particularly on hormones, immunoproteins, and diagnostic probes; biotechnology support, including equipment, instrumentation, and resources and processes; food processing, in cheesemaking and other dairy production, and baking and brewing; chemical industry, particularly water treatment.

TALK.START.PARA: —You would think the National Party would be here for this.
—Absolutely, but National Party members have deserted-all but one .
—Hang on!
—All but two. This list is only indicative and there will be worthwhile programs in other areas.

SPEECH.PARA: Government support for biotechnology development

These priority areas have been incorporated into the criteria for the national biotechnology program established by the Government in 1983. We aim in the national interest to broaden and strengthen the slender and rickety bridge between academic researchers and industry. Closer co-operation will help to make our best research findings available to commercially oriented and competitive industry.

Research grants totalling $4.51m which I announced in December last year are the first given under the program. They span the years 1984 to 1986, and include $1.5m in 1983-84. Most of the seven projects involve special collaboration between researchers and industry. Research institutions include the Walter and Eliza Hall Institute, Queensland Institute of Medical Research, Flinders Medical Centre, various University departments and Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation divisions, and the Commonwealth Serum Laboratories. Firms and other organisations include Biotechnology Australia Pty Ltd, Biotechnology Research Enterprises S. A. Pty Ltd, F. H. Faulding and Co Ltd , Gradient Laboratories, Disposable Products Pty Ltd, and the Sydney Blood Bank. The projects relate to veterinary and anti-malarial vaccines, plant virus detection, insecticides, laboratory equipment and diagnostic techniques based on monoclonal antibodies.

Funds allocated under the program in 1983-84 also include $2.5m to extend the Australian Industrial Research and Development Incentives Scheme to encompass biotechnology projects. Apart from the program, $7.8m went to CSIRO for biotechnology research, and $400,000 to the Howard Florey Institute at Melbourne University. Other important Government actions include steps to improve the flow of venture capital to growth industries from the Australian Industrial Development Corporation and taxation incentives to encourage investment in specially established venture capital companies called management investment companies.
Commercial and economic usefulness of patents

Against this background of support, the role which patents might play as a stimulus to development may not be a major one. But the role is essential. Commercial exploitation is not possible without some form of protection in an area where huge amounts of money are needed. Patent protection is particularly important in assisting penetration by Australians into foreign markets. It would be tragic if Australia had to buy back products from overseas which were developed here or if we could only manufacture them here under licence. In 1980 the United States Supreme Court in the Chakrabarty case rules for the first time that living micro-organisms were patentable.

TALK.START.PARA: —What about software? Why do you not do something about that?

—The Attorney-General (Senator Gareth Evans) has that matter well in hand. Chakrabarty was a landmark decision for American industry. In Australia , however, the Patent Office has long regarded biological processes and micro- organisms themselves as patentable, provided they satisfy the usual pre- conditions for obtaining a patent; that is, they must be novel and non-obvious, industrially useful, and fully described in the patent specification. This information has been widely disseminated-see, for example, a paper given in November 1981 by Philip Thomas of the Patent Office at a Sydney symposium on ' Genetic Engineering-Commercial Opportunities in Australia'.

SPEECH.PARA: In October 1983 the Patent Office published a survey entitled 'Genetic Engineering-Patent Trends and Developments'. Based on that survey and later figures provided by the Office, the number of genetic engineering inventions for which patents were sought world-wide increased from 74 in 1981 to 109 in 1982 and 212 in 1983. They are currently running at about seven new inventions per week. Corresponding figures for patent applications lodged in Australia were 44 in 1981, 49 in 1982 and 67 in 1983. In 1979 there were only five. Biotechnology is, of course, broader than genetic engineering. But those figures give an indication of the rate of growth, not of basic research but of potential commercial applications of biotechnology. Yet, of 187 applications lodged in Australia in the years 1979-1983, only one was of Australian origin. Australians do perform research, but what do they do with it?

We used to be satisfied with the high-flown notion that research findings do the greatest public good if they are given to the world. The difficulty is that the rest of the world is more entrepreneurial and less altruistic than that, with the result that Australia is falling behind. The patent system recognises both the desirability of publication and the commercial realities for the innovator. There is a common misconception that patents require secrecy. In fact , provided a patent application is lodged first, a researcher can publish the invention without jeopardising the application-although if it is too early, this may give away some of the lead held over industry competitors. The patent applications will be published in any event usually 18 months after lodgment.

The purpose of patents is to promote economic development. The mechanism is by way of proprietary rights in the form of a limited term monopoly for new inventions. Their economic operation stems first from protection which gives an incentive to invent and innovate, and second from the disclosure of information which is required from the patentee in exchange for patent rights. For an Australian company, proprietary rights protect its local and foreign interests in research and development, and improve its competitive position in other countries. The availability of protection provides incentive for investment. Disclosure enables Australians to have access to information about the leading edge of technology owned by foreign patentees. Over 90 per cent of patents granted in Australia are of foreign origin. I am aware that the patent system has not been without its critics. I hope the current review by the Industrial Property Advisory Committee will yield constructive suggestions on how it can be made to operate more effectively in advancing Australia's technological development.
Patents Amendment Bill

In the area of biotechnology, however, it is already apparent that patent law is failing to meet the needs of patentees, industry and the public. It is not uncommon for the law to lag behind social and technological change, if the two can indeed be separated. It is up to government to make sure it catches up. In the case of biotechnology patents the lag has arisen from the virtual impossibility of carrying out an invention without access to a sample of the micro-organism used. Existing law requires a full written description of the invention. But where the invention involves the use of a micro-organism strain which is not available to researchers, a written description may well be next to useless. An antibiotic producing strain might have been isolated by unrepeatable fluke from the bottom of a lake in Scandinavia or from the soil in someone's backyard. The most thorough characterisation of the strain will not help anyone, apart from the patentee, to test the truthfulness of the patent specification or to make further developments on the basis of the invention. The information is good only if we can obtain the actual materials needed as a starting point for further work. What is needed is a sample of the organism.

Ultimately a micro-organism could be defined genetically in terms of the nucleotide base sequence of its DNA. In standard code the four bases are represented by the letters C, G, A and T. The first chromosome completely mapped out for any organism reads: CCGTCAGGATTGACACCCT and so on for a total of 5,375 bases. That was for a bacteriophage-a type of virus which destroys bacteria- known as *X174. The full sequence may be perused by anyone who is interested but not keen to consult scientific literature in Douglas R. Hofstadter's book, Godel , Escher, Bach: an Eternal Golden Braid, which won the Pulitzer Prize.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is it in the Library?

—It is in the Parliamentary Library. It is a Penguin book, too. Far more fascinating reading could be had for E. coli DNA, which contains 4.5 million bases. The sequence would occupy about 1,000 pages of Hansard, if Madam Deputy Speaker would allow me to incorporate it. Even then the information contained in the base sequence would need to be interpreted into useful form, and the most skilled biochemist would be unable or certainly unwilling to attempt to re-create the organism. For practical commercial purposes all this information would be less useful than a single cell of the bacterium. In a standard culture medium, one cell would divide into two identical offspring in about 30 minutes. Commercial quantities of the organism would take only days to produce.

SPEECH.PARA: The essence of this Bill is to complement the existing requirement of a full description by also requiring deposit, with a prescribed depositary institution, of patent strains of micro-organisms which are not reasonably available. That new principle is to be found in sub-sections 40 (3) and (5) of the Patents Act which are added by the Bill. As a result of the amendments, Australian industry will be guaranteed access to strains of all micro-organisms used in patented processes, just as access to information in written descriptions of inventions is guaranteed under the current law.

In practice, depositary institutions hold a number of samples of each deposited strain. Most bacteria and fungi can be stored in freeze-dried form in small vials or frozen in liquid nitrogen in plastic ampoules or straws. Priceless samples can be readily reconstituted and turned to commercial purposes, provided that no patent is infringed. I dare say that I cannot table the samples. There are some cases where the specification itself describes how to make or obtain the new strain. If a person skilled in the art could reasonably be expected to be able to perform the invention without first having a copy of the micro- organism, then the requirement to make a deposit will not apply.

A corollary to the deposit requirement is that if a deposit is required, then compliance with sub-section 40 (5) will satisfy the requirement of a full description of the micro-organism. That will also apply where the invention is itself a new micro-organism, relieving the applicant of the need to provide an excessively detailed description when a deposit, supplemented by relevant information on the organism's characteristics, is a realistic alternative. Mere deposit without some guarantee of access would not be enough. The applicant must therefore also give authority for the furnishing of samples of the micro- organism in accordance with the regulations and the Budapest Treaty. The terms of the authority to be required by the regulations will be discussed with industry to ensure that a fair balance of interest is struck. It is fundamental to the notion of patents that the patentee should be left with an enforceable monopoly. An unauthorised user of a strain can still be sued for infringement.

The second aspect of the Bill is to implement the Budapest Treaty. That will ensure that the benefits provided by the deposit requirements will be available to Australians who patent abroad and to Australians seeking access to strains deposited by foreign patentees. The main idea of the Treaty is to enable a single deposit in any international depositary authority recognised by the Treaty to suffice for the purposes of the patent law of all member countries. To date 12 countries are members, including the United States of America, the United Kingdom and other major European countries, and Japan. Australia intends to accede to the Treaty when the Bill comes into force. The Bill recognises all international depositary authorities for the purpose of satisfying Australian deposit requirements. There are currently nine authorities. I visited one of them in November last year, the Fermentation Research Institute in Tsukuba, Japan-a very impressive institution offering a range of services to industry and research.

The remainder of the Bill supports these essential features. For example, provisions are made to remedy an inability of a depositary institution to supply samples, and to require a late deposit where a micro-organism ceases to be reasonably available. To gain the full benefits of participation of the new provisions, we intend to establish an Australian international depositary authority which will be recognised under the Budapest Treaty. Australians wishing to patent abroad in order to protect exports will then be able to satisfy the deposit requirements of foreign laws in many instances with a single deposit made locally.
Financial impact

The direct financial implications of the Bill are minimal. This may be an anti- climax, Madam Deputy Speaker. No additional resources would be required by the Patent, Trade Marks and Designs Office in dealing with patent applications where a deposit had been made, and no direct contributions would be involved in acceeding to the Treaty. Establishment of an international depositary authority within an existing Government institution is not expected to exceed $10,000. It is small change.

TALK.START.PARA: —You would still have trouble getting it out of Dawkins.

—That is possible. On- going costs of an authority should be recovered from fees levied on depositors. The user pays principle triumphs again . Fees charged by overseas authorities range from $300 to $1,000 for storage of deposits for the 30-year period required by the Treaty. The indirect implications for industry are very substantial. While the fees charged for lodging deposits are sizable, there will be a reduced need for expensive drafting of patent specifications. But far more important are the advantages from having access to deposited strains. Although the value of access will vary from case to case, it is potentially enormous.

SPEECH.PARA: Conclusion

Development projects based on Australian research are now causing great interest internationally. This was brought home to me in January when I visited two United States companies which are world leaders in biotechnology-Genentech in San Francisco and Agrigenetics in Boulder, Colorado. We must stay in the race and keep ahead in areas where we have the lead. This needs a vigorous approach from industry, research bodies and government, and I hope it will have the support of the Opposition. The Patents Amendment Bill demonstrates the Government's awareness of the need for commercial realisation of Australia's research and development efforts in biotechnology. Industry and researchers must continue to convert opportunities into advantages in this competitive field. The Bill offers improved ways in which that can be achieved. I commend the Bill to the House.

DEBATE.TITLE: WEIGHTS AND MEASURES (NATIONAL STANDARDS) AMENDMENT BILL 1984

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill presented by Mr Barry Jones, and read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Jones The Hon B.O.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.

The purpose of this Bill is to establish the National Measurement Act by amending the Weights and Measures (National Standards) Act 1960, to create a hierarchy of standards consistent with both modern and international practice and to clarify the functions and powers of the National Standards Commission in the light of modern technology. The establishment and use of a common and uniform system of weights and measures has a long history which may be traced back in written records to the earliest civilisations. Today's high technology society requires a far more complex and extensive system and cannot be satisfied by standards for the measurement of length and weight only. A uniformly applied system of measurement is as essential to modern society as a common language or monetary system.

Under Section 51 (xv) of the Constitution, the Commonwealth has power to make laws in respect of weights and measures and as a result it established the National Standards Commission in 1948. The Principal Act under which the Commission operates is the Weights and Measures (National Standards) Act 1960.

In practice, and by mutual agreement, the Commonwealth has limited the application of its power to legislation covering uniform measurement standards whilst the States and Territories have legislated to regulate weighing and measuring practices in the market place. The activities are complementary and combine to give Australia a uniform measuring system applied honestly and consistently everywhere. The principles expressed in the Bill now before honourable members have been discussed with those Ministers of States and Territories who are responsible for weights and measures and have their support.

The National Standards Commission is responsible for establishing and co- ordinating the use in Australia of a uniform system of units and standards of measurement of physical quantities and for approving the pattern of measuring instruments for use in trade to ensure accuracy and reliability in service. The term pattern is of technical significance which honourable members will pick up in the Act. In this era of rapid technological change, the States have looked to the Commission to play an increasing role in matters such as the promotion of uniform principles in State legislation relating to trade measurements and use of units of measurement in the packaging of goods. Trade measuring devices presented for pattern approval have increased in complexity and are often integrated with other devices such as computers. The Bill proposes to give legal effect to the increasingly important role undertaken by the Commission in the new technological age.

This Bill increases the numbers of commissioners on the National Standards Commission from a chairman and four members to a chairman and six members. This is necessary in order to provide adequate representation of consumer and industry groups. Amendments contained in this Bill will permit units which are prescribed as being additional to Australian legal units to be used in specified classes of transactions and so modifies the requirement that contracts be made only in terms of Australian legal units.

TALK.START.PARA: —Hear, hear!

—This will be known as the Cameron clause. The Bill also puts beyond doubt the validity of existing contracts made in terms of Australian legal units which subsequently cease to be Australian legal units. This amendment has been inserted at the request of the States. As the official system of measurement in Australia is now the metric system this Bill proposes the repeal of the Metric Conversion Act 1970. The war is over; it has been won.

SPEECH.PARA: The Metric Conversion Board was established under the Metric Conversion Act 1970 as a transitional body to promote, help and guide conversion from the imperial to the metric system of measurement. Conversion was substantially completed by 1980 and appointments to the Board expired on 30 June 1981. Remaining ongoing conversion activities relate essentially to industries reliant on long life equipment, such as heavy engineering; and those industries influenced by international agreement such as aviation.

TALK.START.PARA: —Do I have to make a speech on this again?
—Why not? The Bill provides for the transfer to the National Standards Commission of responsibility for these residual metric conversion activities. In summary the Bill provides for:

SPEECH.PARA: (a) An updating of the hierarchy of standards of physical measurement in accordance with modern practice;
(b) a clear definition of the functions and powers of the National Standards Commission;
(c) a definition of the objects of the Act including the continuation of the objects of the Metric Conversion Act 1970;

(d) amendments permitting units which are prescribed as being additional to Australian legal units to be used in specified classes of transactions-for example, it does not seem very sensible to apply metric measurements to a dozen eggs-and the validity of existing contracts made in terms of either Australian legal units which subsequently cease to be Australian legal units, or of these specified additional units of measurement; and
(e) an increase in membership of the Commission from Chairman and four members to Chairman and six members.

The financial impact of this Bill relates only to the two additional Commission members and the transfer to the Commonwealth of residual metric conversion activities. The cost of the additional two Commissioners will be approximately $ 6,600 in 1984-85 and metric conversion activities will within a period of three years reduce in cost by an amount of $48,000. I am pleased to announce therefore that the Government anticipates total savings in this area overall of approximately $40,000 by 1985-86. I commend the Bill to the House.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Moore The Hon J.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Opposition welcomes the introduction of the Advance Australia Logo Protection Bill which legalises the Advance Australia logo. Honourable members will recall that the Advance Australia campaign was established in 1979 and came about through discussions between the Australian Manufacturing Council and the then Minister for Industry and Commerce, Senator Cotton. It was brought about in an endeavour to raise the public's perception of locally made goods. In Australia there was a time, and there still is to a degree, when the perception was that Australian made goods were not of the quality required by lots of purchasers, that goods made overseas were always better. I think the Advance Australia campaign has been largely a success.

SPEECH.PARA: Originally the government of the day managed the program through the Department of Industry and Commerce. The Government established the Project Australia Committee with a number of leading alumni on it embracing not only Mr Jim Leslie and the former Secretary to the Department of Industry and Commerce, Neil Currie , but also another guiding light of Australia in the form of the current Prime Minister, Bob Hawke. Its initial efforts were limited to the promotion of shirts , beerholders and the like, of which I am sure the Minister for Sport, Recreation and Tourism (Mr John Brown) will be aware. From there the project has spread widely and is now used in a number of areas including manufacturing and service industries. The regrettable feature of the early days was that no effort was made to register the design. Because of that there was a series of pirating operations on the use of this logo.

On 13 October 1983 the decision to introduce the Advance Australia Protection Bill was announced. It was announced that action would be taken to protect that logo. Copyright has now been granted to Advance Australia Pty Ltd to which the rights of the logo have been transferred. This will confer on Advance Australia Pty Ltd 16 years copyright of that logo. I am quite sure that under the chairmanship of Ian Webber those who will be involved will be enormously comforted by their more secure position which will enable them to defend their position, marketability and copyright areas.

The Government contributed $5.14m towards the funding of the program to 30 June 1983-a significant amount. To date the project could be considered a successful venture. From 30 June 1983 this proprietary company, which is wholly owned by the Government, has been on a self-supporting basis. Because of the user pays principle we now have the position where those who wish to use the logo have to apply to the company in the normal way for a licence, whether it be a non- exclusive licence, which must contain 75 per cent local content, or, in the case of exclusive licences, 100 per cent Australian content. Broadly, the areas fall into two categories; firstly, in service industries, where one finds such logos on letterheads, and, secondly, on various design and service presentations. I think most honourable members will have seen them in some form or another. They tend to be in the non-exclusive area and do not have the high profile which the exclusive licences have and which are visible in shop fronts in the form of the wares that the shop sells.

The Advance Australia pamphlet illustrates the various areas in which the company has taken an interest. For example, the pamphlet refers to television and a co-pilot around the world balloon flight. In various States the Advance Australia project has made awards for excellence on various criteria and licensing has been taken up by people such as the makers of outdoor furniture, a range of Australian steel and the inevitable Australian cooler. We all seem to know a bit about that. Probably the best picture in this pamphlet is one of another sporting venture which the Minister for Sport, Recreation and Tourism would well know. I am surprised that he is not featured, but how can we get away from it?

I draw the attention of people to the costs involved in the licensing agreements. The non-exclusive licence is granted on the basis of 0.1 per cent of budgeted turnover of a specific product and an exclusive licence is granted on the cost of the standard industry royalty as payment on brand names. In some cases this can run to extensive amounts of money. It may be that the smaller users, smaller developments or smaller enterprises in Australia would find that sort of charge to be a little excessive in the early period. Some phasing-in period or some incentive may have to be given to people who are commencing a business or who have a relatively small operation in terms of cost structure and who wish to use this logo.

Beyond that, I say that the Opposition supports the Bill in every respect. It has been widely recognised and accepted throughout the community. It has been associated with a number of successes, and with one or two projects that have not been quite so successful. But on the whole there is no doubt that this effort to advance Australia and to increase an awareness of Australian manufacturing and service industries helps to harvest the spirit of nationalism that is in Australia in terms of the commercial operations that we have today. For that reason the Opposition supports the Bill.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Gear Mr G.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Advance Australia Logo Protection Bill 1984 before us today is a study of a program in which private enterprise and government, working in partnership with the unions at some stages, were able to initiate a constructive contribution to the promotion of Australian-made goods that worked to the benefit of all parties. In my contribution today I would like to look at the Bill specifically and then develop some of the principles which underpin it. The Advance Australia logo, as has been pointed out, is currently used on a large number of items. If we look around we see the little logo on tee-shirts, jumpers, cars and numerous other items. Its basic appeal is to nationalism. I am sure that much of its success can be traced to that aspect. We have only to look at the America's Cup last year. I know of the nationalism which was displayed in my home State of Western Australia, where people sat up all night just to see that marvellous event. Also the turn-out for the welcoming of the America's Cup crew shows what nationalism there is in Australia. By using the Advance Australia logo on Australian-made products we were able to advance those products to the tune of $2,000m worth of items. I believe that since March 1983 nationalism has been enhanced by the arrival of the Labor Government whose Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) has really lifted nationalism. I believe that we can only go from strength to strength.
—We were a divided society.

—That is right. As the honourable member for Stirling rightly pointed out, we were a divided society but certainly since March 1983 we have come a long way in lifting our nationalism. That is a good thing. It is also my opinion from my observation that when tourists come to Australia-they will be coming here in increasing numbers thanks to the Minister for Sport, Recreation and Tourism (Mr John Brown) who is in the House today-they want something to take home which says something about Australia. The Advance Australia logo has proved very popular. I think that in the last couple of years most of us would have noticed the Australia shops which have sprung up around the place and which sell only Australian-made goods. If one looks around those shops one will see that the Advance Australia logo is very dominant.

SPEECH.PARA: A brief history of the Advance Australia campaign shows that it was formed in 1979. From that time until 1981 the campaign was managed by the Department of Industry and Commerce through the Project Australia Committee which comprised private sector management, unions and the Department. The success of the campaign led to the establishment in mid-1981 of a public interest company, the Advance Australia company. This Bill will establish a wholly private enterprise company which will be funded by licensing fees for use of the logo. The total Government outlay to date has been $5.14m and the revenue generated from the private sector in that time is over $3m, with $1.75m coming from private sources in 1982-83. As I will point out later, that figure could have been substantially more if it had not been for an oversight in 1979. What it does indicate is a substantial growth in revenue from the private source and it leads the Government to the conclusion that with the protection of this Bill the campaign can be self-funding.

The Bill is necessary because in 1979 at the launch of the campaign, due to some oversight, the design was not registered. Therefore there was no protection under the Design Acts or the Copyright Act. As a consequence of that, whenever we leave private enterprise with the option of either paying a bill or not paying it some will choose not to pay it. Many reputable companies in Australia paid the licensing fees, but by the same token some chose not to. Also, there were overseas companies that used look-alike logos. This also had an effect that was not intended when the company was set up, because when the company was set up it was thought that the Advance Australia logo would promote Australian-made goods, would identify them as such and would generate the sales which I spoke of earlier to the value of $2,000m which the official use of the logo generated. But certainly the overseas firms, in particular, by using that logo led a large number of people to think that those goods were made in Australia when in fact they were not.

It also put the reputable firms at a disadvantage compared with those unscrupulous firms which chose to use the logo without paying the licensing fee. Even though the licensing fee was not a large cost to the reputable firms it nevertheless gave an advantage to those firms which chose not to pay it. Another aspect of it was that the Advance Australia campaign itself was denied funds which should have come to it by the use of the licensing fee. This Bill seeks to correct the situation involving companies which at present have no access to law and to protect the use of the logo without Commonwealth involvement. As a result of this Bill a licence-holder will also have the right to appeal to law. If he thinks that some companies are in the same line as himself and have an unfair advantage over him he can also appeal to the courts and get compensation.

The Bill will protect the interests of the reputable Australian firms that did seek licences and will thereby contribute to the success of the campaign. It will protect the integrity of the campaign. As I said before, the idea of the Advance Australia logo was to promote the sale of Australian-made goods. Certainly, by having cheap imports which used look-alikes the integrity of that campaign was seriously undermined. The Bill will promote the sale of Australian- made goods by making the Advance Australia company the owner of the copyright. This is a significant departure from the original intention. The original intention was that the Commonwealth would own it. But under this legislation it becomes a purely private enterprise venture.

Because of the significant contribution of taxpayers' money, the $5.14m, the Bill will also have safeguards built into the legislation. Firstly they provide for the ownership to revert to the Commonwealth if the company winds up. Secondly, when the Minister considers it no longer in the public interest for the company to own the logo the ownership will also revert to the Commonwealth. So a watchdog clause is set into the Bill whereby the government of the day can monitor the activities of the company and if it believes that they are not in the interests of the Advance Australia campaign generally directions can be given by the Minister. Accountability is also built into this Bill because the annual report that must come from the company must detail the licences issued, the amounts received from those licences and how the funds generated from the licensing fees were spent.

I suppose that in clinical terms the Bill can be seen as legislation which puts restrictions on private enterprise. I would like to pursue that point because of the rhetoric that usually comes from the conservative parties when we talk of restrictions on private enterprise. This is an emotive term currently used by the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Peacock) as though we should get off the backs of business. In looking at this Bill clinically I suppose that we are actually putting a restriction on business. But as I said before, when we do not do that, unscrupulous companies take advantage of the fact that they do not have to pay the fee if they are given the choice. We do not know what the Leader of the Opposition is really saying, because the term is all-embracing. We do not know whether he means little or no regulation.

This week a private industry-a car firm-wrote to me and sought my support for its submission to the Western Australian Government which sought to place restrictions on the amount of hours that car firms could open. As it rightly pointed out to me, the larger car firms could open for much longer because of the volume of sales they have and the amounts generated by those sales which means that they can quite properly carry much larger overheads. The smaller firms, of course, would be put out of business if they had to compete on an hourly basis, and the longer hours do not really generate any more business. I suppose that is just another example of governments being approached by private enterprise to limit the ability of larger private enterprise firms to take advantage of their size to disadvantage their competitors.

I will develop a little further the point relating to private enterprise. The conservative parties, especially during elections, say that they are the parties of free enterprise. The recent Queensland election provides a classic example. The Premier of Queensland took the high ground and claimed for himself the sole responsibility for his party having the free enterprise principle. I suppose in the past the Australian Labor Party has defended public enterprise. I see this as a polarisation; really a reaction to what the conservative parties have done. Nowadays most people would recognise that the Australian Labor Party is a private enterprise party. We do support private enterprise.

TALK.START.PARA: —Ha, ha!
—The honourable member might laugh.
—I thought you were a socialist party.

—Of course I am a socialist. I have never run away from the term. I repeat: The Australian Labor Party today is a private enterprise party, but we are a little more than that; we are also a public enterprise party. We do not say that we can have one without the other. There must be a balance and a mix between the two. I think this Bill encompasses at the outset that there was that co-operation between public enterprise and private enterprise to get the Advance Australia logo off the ground. Once it is self-supporting, as it is now, private enterprise can rightly carry the burden. Certainly the polarisation that I spoke of earlier had the effect of the Australian Labor Party being seen-the laughter of honourable members opposite shows, I am sure, that they would like to continue this-as the defender of public enterprise. I will defend public enterprise any day. But I also make the point that private enterprise under the Australian Labor Party, especially under the Hawke Labor Government since 1983, has done very much better than it did under the conservatives in years gone by.
—I reckon the executive in Western Australia would want to know your name and address.

—That is okay. I do not mind talking to it any time. We usually identify the main motive of private enterprise as profit. The public enterprise system has wider objectives. It has a social objective, and usually the social objectives do not make a profit. I notice that the honourable member for Mackellar (Mr Carlton), who is the shadow Minister for Health, is present today. I think Medicare is a classic example of that point. I do not think anybody-
—Classic example of what?

—A classic example of the fact that Medicare does not have a profit motive. In fact, that was previously built into the private insurance schemes, when all the companies had to refrain from making a profit; they were supposed to be non-profit organisations. I say that the public enterprise system can handle the health insurance scheme more efficiently than happened before.
—It costs more and you get less value.
—That is the honourable member's view. We will see what happens after a year.
—Do you want to expand it to all sectors?
—No. It is a good example, though, of how public enterprise can take over a role previously handled by--
—Aren't you paying more now for health than you were before 1 February?
—That is only because of my wage. But the majority of Australians are paying less.
—Ignore the ignorance.
—I will take the Minister's advice.
—I like your speech better than their contributions.
—I thank the Minister.
—Order! The honourable member should return to the Bill.

—Thank you, Madam Deputy Speaker. In closing, I think the point must be made that the Australian Labor Party does stand for both private and public enterprise, and certainly for a mix of both. As I pointed out earlier, the Advance Australia campaign is a good example of public and private enterprise playing a significant role in developing a program that has benefited the Australian community and also the Australian taxpayer through the generation of the sales of goods using the Advance Australia logo, the taxation that the Government will obtain from it and the employment generated by those articles being sold in the Australian community.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Shipton Mr R.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —I speak to the Advance Australia Logo Protection Bill as the second speaker for the Opposition and I support the comments of the honourable member for Ryan (Mr Moore), who led for the Opposition in this matter . As he said to the House, the Opposition supports this legislation. The Advance Australia campaign was commenced under the former coalition Government. We do not get any credit for that from Government members. They tend to forget that point in these great days of consensus in which we are living. It was commenced under the former Government as a means of raising the public's perception of the ability of domestic manufacturers to produce high quality goods. I think all parties in this House agree that the desired public awareness has been achieved. We are talking about advancing Australia. We are really talking about the spirit of Australia and this particular effort is one of many, but an important one, going on in Australia today. In the last day or so awards of excellence were announced by the Broken Hill Proprietary Co. Ltd covering a number of fields of activity, one of which was industry and commerce. Others included the arts. But there is undoubtedly a spirit of nationalism abroad of which the former coalition Government was a part and was aware when it started this Advance Australia campaign.

SPEECH.PARA: The legislation does restrict the use of the logo in terms of licences. That is of some concern to me in cases of small and medium sized businesses that genuinely want to meet the quality requirements of the Advance Australia logo. I hope that the logo will be within the reach of genuine small and medium sized companies that wish to use it on high quality products that meet the standards. My reservation is that the use of the logo ought to be within the reach of those genuine companies. Of course, I do not support, and the Opposition does not support, the abuse of the present system, the illegal activity which has caused the need for this legislation. That activity directly threatens to undermine the campaign and the financial viability of the Advance Australia company because of the unauthorised use of the logo and look-alike symbols.

As I said, it is important that genuine companies and corporations have this logo within their ready reach. The cost to the small and medium enterprises is a factor that needs to be considered, because the cost of a non-exclusive licence to use the logo is 0.1 per cent of budgeted turnover of a specific product. In the non-exclusive category, the use is in packaging, business cards, letterheads , et cetera. A good point made by my colleague, the honourable member for Ryan, earlier in the debate concerned smaller enterprises in the early stage of using the symbol on new products, or it might concern a new company that has started out, and that some consideration should be given by the Advance Australia company for some phasing in system of paying the licence fee. I say in relation to both non-exclusive and exclusive licences-the exclusive licences are used as a main or predominant feature of a product where the cost of the royalty is the standard industry royalty as used on brand names-that if the profits of the Advance Australia company reach a substantial stage and the company is generating good profits, some consideration should be given to reducing the amount of royalty payments so that the logo is kept within the reach of all Australian companies that want to use it.

The honourable member for Ryan referred in his speech to the Advance Australia bulletins that are produced. I refer to issue No.9 of March 1984. These bulletins are very commendable. On the front page of the last bulletin under the headline 'TV musical on Australia aims for international market' there is an article which states:
A new musical documentary-drama on Australia will go into production soon for release later this year to the local and international TV and video markets.

Titled 'Sing a Song Down Under', the film will feature Australian actors and singers and will tell the story of Australia through music, drama and just about every aspect of Australian life and heritage.

It will have a number of prominent Australian actors, including Sigrid Thornton and John Waters, and singers Colleen Hewitt, Simon Gallaher-an Advance Australia Award winner-and Rolf Harris. The interesting thing about this television musical is that it will be shot in all Australian States and the Northern Territory and hopefully it will advance Australia in terms of the spirit of Australia that we are talking about in this debate. My concern is that if the filming to be done in the Northern Territory is to include some filming of Ayers Rock the poor documentary team will find itself having the difficulties in trying to film Ayers Rock that an Italian film team had in November last year and that the singer Val Doonican had recently. The situation in relation to the filming of Ayers Rock today is ridiculous. I see the Minister for Sport, Recreation and Tourism (Mr John Brown) at the table opposite. He might comment on this because I know that he intervened to enable Paul Hogan to film there. Paul Hogan is in fact doing a series of successful tourist promotions overseas- it has the support of both the Government and the Opposition-using Ayers Rock as its central theme. It is silly to have this great centrepiece of Australia as the centrepiece of an overseas advertising campaign to promote tourism in Australia but to deny an Italian film team the opportunity to film it when they want to promote Australia and do films on significant spots in Australia. For Val Doonican, who is doing a series on Australia, to be denied the opportunity to be filmed at Ayers Rock is a totally ridiculous situation.

I hope that the Minister will do something about that. I hope that the television documentary team which is going to do this Advance Australia promotion does not run into those difficulties. I ask the Minister to give us an assurance that it will not. We have a maze of bureaucratic regulations in relation to getting permission to film at Ayers Rock. The situation is totally out of hand. It is my belief, which I have stated in this Parliament before, that the nightmarish regulations administered by the Director of the Australian National Parks and Wildlife Service are beyond his power and are illegal. I hope that the Minister will do something about that and make a statement on the subject. So far he has been silent, other than intervening to get his friend Paul Hogan permission to film because Hoges was initially denied access to film the rock. He has left the running for his colleague the Minister for Home Affairs and Environment (Mr Cohen). Perhaps we will get a statement from the Minister at the table on the whole question of advancing Australia in relation to filming at Ayers Rock, because it is certainly a situation that needs clearing up. For the reasons stated by my colleague, the honourable member for Ryan, and me, the Opposition supports the legislation before the House.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Edwards Mr R.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the previous speakers-the honourable member for Tangney (Mr Gear), the honourable member for Higgins (Mr Shipton) and the honourable member for Ryan (Mr Moore)-for their contributions to the debate. They covered some ground that I had intended to cover but I thank them for covering it because it gives me the opportunity to talk about some other matters. I will respond to a couple of points made by the honourable member for Higgins. The Advance Australia campaign was developed by the previous Government, but the problem that the previous Government encountered was that nationally the feeling was that this was a divided country and from time to time it was almost as if the leadership of the previous Government owed loyalties to only part of the society and not the whole of society. To that extent I think that, as the honourable member for Tangney has pointed out very accurately, since March 1983 there has been a sense in which the leadership of Prime Minister Hawke and his Ministers has been directed to the whole of the country rather than to part of it. I really think that view is conveyed by the community . Certainly the polls indicate that and certainly the confidence of the community gives us reason to suggest that. The Advance Australia campaign has some extra quality to it under this Government, but we acknowledge that, of course, it was developed under the previous Government and that it has very sound commercial reasons.

SPEECH.PARA: On the question of commercial reasons, the honourable member for Higgins made the point that, if profits rise, the royalty payments could be lowered-there could be a lower threshold level to encourage access to the Advance Australia logo. That seems to me to be a point worth following up. It may well be that the company in charge of the Advance Australia campaign will look at the commercial considerations of that. Certainly we want to see some degree of proliferation of this logo and if lowering the threshold is a way of doing that and is commercially possible, it would be a sensible thing to do.

Obviously the question of Ayers Rock is a very controversial issue, but we take the view that we have an obligation to advance all Australians and obviously we have an obligation to advance Aborigines as well. One of the key things in doing that for Aborigines has been to give them some title and some right over and above what they might previously have had. Ayers Rock has great symbolic significance for them as well as considerable cultural and historical significance. We hold the view that the Aborigines deserve the right to have a say in how Ayers Rock is managed and handled. It is not that they have a right that would always exclude the rest of Australia, but I think it is fair to say that, having been given some title and some right, they might want to exercise that right; and there may be times when they believe that their historical circumstances would be trangressed by the right of others being exercised. I do not see it as a highly controversial issue. It is one which those opposite might choose to blow up from time to time, but I do not think that is quite the issue. The issue substantially is that we have the right to advance Aborigines. This is one of the ways we have chosen to do that. It may well be that from time to time we get some controversy about the rights of people to film Ayers Rock, but essentially, if we proceed with good conscience and good intention, I do not see that that will be all that some opposite want to make out.

I want to talk a little more about the question of Advance Australia. As I said earlier, I think the honourable member for Tangney has contributed well to the debate and those opposite, in joining us in supporting the Bill, are really facilitating the whole spirit of this discussion. I want to deal with why I think Advance Australia is very appropriate at the moment in the thrust of tourism and then I want to deal with some specific issues about tourism because I believe there are two or three issues in the development of Australia which are quite pronounced. It is true to say that some of the climate we are operating in at the moment, in which there has been an improvement in business confidence and a substantial increase in the level of economic activity, relates to the role that this Government has played. Some of it relates to natural circumstances. It is true that it began to rain in 1983. It is also true that the Government that took over did something about getting confidence together; that is, as the honourable member for Tangney has said, the confidence of the private sector. We are not in the business of scapegoating one against the other , as was the practice of the former right honourable member for Wannon when he deigned to become Prime Minister. He thought that there was some merit in trying to turn one sector of society against the other. We will just not wear that. We are not about to do that. We are in the business of trying to manage both the private and the public sectors. That has been the philosophy.

TALK.START.PARA: —You are not managing it with the doctors.

—The doctors are an interesting issue. It goes to show that when one takes on a privileged group in society that group reacts to try to protect the privilege. That is natural and understandable, but in so reacting to protect their privilege the doctors have not done anything to encourage the support of the community. We are concerned about that broad support, and the broad support of the community is about having a commitment to the policies of government.

SPEECH.PARA: Clearly, the National Economic Summit Conference of April was a major factor, as was the role of the Prime Minister. But in talking about that, I want also to refer to the fact that we now have a Minister responsible for tourism who has recognised that tourism is a major industry in Australia. Along with a couple of other industries, it is one of the most promising industries for Australia's future. It is a labour-intensive industry. It is one in which we are prepared to take major initiatives. The protection of the Advance Australia logo is just one of those things where we are following on from what honourable members opposite did when they were in government. But we are prepared to take major initiatives to try to advance this important industry. We believe that it is an industry which to some extent the previous Government neglected, because I do not think that that Government ever quite realised the potential that it offered; but we do recognise it, and we have some proposals. But again, of course, we have been in fortunate times.

Looking at the issue of Australian nationalism, one finds that there have been some significant events. I have spoken about March 1983 and the change of government, about the Economic Summit of April 1983, and about the quality of leadership that Bob Hawke has given and the quality of leadership that has been given by the Minister for Sport, Recreation and Tourism (Mr John Brown). But it is also important to talk about outstanding Australian achievements. Here, drawn to our minds, as the honourable member for Tangney (Mr Gear) has indicated, is Alan Bond's Australia II syndicate and the successful capture of the America's Cup. It is good that it was an Australian venture, and it is also good that it was a Western Australian venture. We are particularly pleased about that. I know that the electorate of Stirling is particularly pleased about it. We also have Neale Fraser's Davis Cup team. That had a remarkable achievement.
