It had the echoes of the 1950s and the early 1960s about it-that Australia was once again proving that it is quite a remarkable country. We are pleased about that. We believe that we have some remarkable Australians, and we have some remarkable Australians with respect to developing business in tourism, and we would want to facilitate that.

I also point to the Australian film industry. Films such as Phar Lap were just films designed to capture a mood and a moment in history, and Australians relate to that. It is quite significant that 1983 was one of those years.

We are all very proud of the efforts and the performances of Robert de Castella . I might add that, interestingly, one of the issues that we must develop in Australia is that if a person such as Robert de Castella goes out and puts in such a great effort, as he is doing, we must never judge him only in terms of medals that he gets, but we should also judge him in terms of the threshold effect, the wake effect, that he develops, whereby others are inspired by his achievements. We would hope that our attitude towards the tourism industry is rather like that; that, somewhat like Robert de Castella, it is the job of government to set the way, to point the direction, and to encourage industry to participate in that, to create a wake effect. That is our attitude, and it is one that we are determined to pursue. I know that the comments of the tourism industry about the Minister for Sport, Recreation and Tourism reflect that.

We have also had successful Australian men's and women's cricket teams. That is another example of great success by Australians. The seat alongside me is filled by the captain of the Australian hockey team, Dr Rick Charlesworth, the honourable member for Perth. That is another example, as is the Australian netball team, and as is Steele Bishop from Western Australia, a cycling hero in anyone's terms. They are examples of nationalism. It is interesting how often we choose sport as a way of capturing that nationalism, because it is something, fortunately, to which everyone in society can relate, and we should be mindful of that. When we talk about logos, it is interesting that there are many uses of sporting logos, such as those of the New South Wales Rugby League, the Victorian Football League and the West Australian Football League. They use logos very effectively in their promotion. Of course, this Advance Australia logo is a similar promotion and an important way of developing.

I think that there is a third factor. I have dealt with what I might call the overall question of leadership at the government level and the sorts of performances put in by the Government, and by the Minister responsible for tourism, and secondly, the contribution of outstanding Australians. The third factor is the positive attitudes towards the development of Australian industry and, in particular, Australian tourism, which are important. Just to list some examples of initiatives that we are taking in tourism, the one to which I want to point is the question of the licensing and registration of travel agents. This is an important initiative which I support on behalf of the Australian Government. We have the unfortunate circumstance that from time to time travellers overseas find that the travel agent with whom they have been dealing has developed a temporary liquidity crisis-in common terms, he has gone broke- and they are stranded in Singapore, Hong Kong or London. We would be trying to develop a bond system that would ensure that the Australian travelling public would have some guarantees. It is a very important initiative as part of our attitude towards consumer protection, and it reflects an important position to develop in tourism.

The other matter is the issue which the Minister responsible for tourism is concerned to look at-the question of in-bound duty-free facilities or bonded warehouses for Australian travellers. The current circumstance, in terms of developing tourism, is that people who wish to purchase goods in Australia have to take them out of the country and bring them back into the country. That is not good enough. It inconveniences Australian travellers, but it also means that we are not keeping the money in the country. We are keen to see Australian business develop. We would like to think that some of the goods that people purchase in fact have Advance Australia logos on them. We would like to see this system established so that we can get a more effective operation in terms of duty free goods within Australia, and so that we can keep business within the country and facilitate the convenience of the travelling public. It will give them some after sales service. It will give them some guarantees that they do not get when they purchase goods in Singapore and Hong Kong. We believe that that is important. It also would be of assistance to Qantas Airways Ltd, because I believe that Qantas currently carries an extra fuel bill because of all the carriage of freight that is involved. It is important to try to assist Qantas, and certainly we hope that there is some flow-through in the fares structure in Australia. The other question, which is a recent initiative-

TALK.START.PARA: —Is it Government policy to introduce that?

—It is an issue that we should be developing in the Government because we believe that it would make sense, and, in line with our attitude that the role of government is one of partnership my attitude and, I hope our attitude, is that this would be a way that government, through a common-sense approach, could make this change. At this stage, of course, it is not the policy of government; it would have to be announced. But that is a position that I would be keen to develop.

SPEECH.PARA: The establishment of new discount air fares was a great announcement. We need to have further debate about the matter; this is not an appropriate time. I simply say that the sorts of packages that are being offered and the sorts of initiatives that are being taken are symbolic of the fact that this Government and the industries with which we are dealing-in this case, the airline industry, but, of course, the related industries of accommodation and entertainment, and so on-will all be facilitated if we can get more people to travel within Australia and to spend more money within Australia. Hopefully, again, they will be supporting goods such as the goods that will carry the Advance Australia logo . We believe that this is important. I commend the initiative of the Minister for Sport, Recreation and Tourism because, coming as I do from Western Australia , I believe that that is an important issue. It is a very sore point among members of parliament from Western Australia.

As I indicated, the issue of air fares to Western Australia is also a major structural question in relation to air fares within the country. But I think that is a much larger debate. However, at this point it is important to say that the packages being offered represent a considerable advancement. We could say that honourable members opposite did not do much when they were in office, but it is too easy to say that. It is much more important to say that we are attempting a new initiative, and to turn it in that positive way rather than turn it into a negative comment about what honourable members opposite might have done. We are saying what we have done. Obviously, we would not claim that everything that we do has the glint of success all the time, but this is an important initiative. It is one that we on this side of the House welcome and I know that the travelling public welcomes it. It also indicates, incidentally, that the cost of flying will come to about 8c per kilometre, which would be a very inexpensive mode of travel. There are many people from Western Australia who would like to visit places such as Canberra. This certainly will offer them that opportunity, and we are pleased about that.
Opposition members interjecting-

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! Will the honourable member please return to the Bill to hand, and perhaps the House will get off the little chit chat about air fares.

—Thank you, Madam Deputy Speaker. I was trying to persist, clearly. The other point about the Advance Australia logo is that we are keen to see people coming into the country and spending money within the country. We are having success with that. We have previously spoken, as have honourable members opposite, about Paul Hogan. There has been a substantial increase in visa issuances for the United States of America, which are up by 31 per cent for January. That is an example of the effect that Paul Hogan is having. We are seeing a substantial increase in the prospect of travellers from the West Coast of the United States. The figures are quite astonishing. They jump from 5,013 for January and February of 1983 to 9,022 for January and February 1984. That represents a substantial increase in activity. That is because, under this Government, tourism is being promoted. This Advanced Australia logo will be one of the important factors in the development of tourism itself. We are keen to see the total development of tourism.

SPEECH.PARA: In summing up, I say that we believe we have an important opportunity as a government. We have been given a great trust by the Australian electorate to do something substantial. That is starting to fit together. The work is being done, the economy is performing and the leadership is being shown. This is another example of the structural change that we are making which, we believe, will assist the development of industry. We are certainly keen to see the private sector flourish and we are also concerned to see more Australians travelling within Australia, to be proud of Australia and for people from overseas to come to Australia. I conclude by saying that I believe the whole thrust of tourism has taken an improved position under this Minister. I certainly commend the Minister and the Bill to the House.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brumby Mr J.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —Might I say in my introductory remarks that a number of very good speeches have been made on the Advance Australia Logo Protection Bill, which is basically a very straightforward piece of legislation, but I think none have been better than that of the honourable member for Stirling (Mr Ronald Edwards). As the Minister for Sport, Recreation and Tourism and Minister Assisting the Minister for Industry and Commerce (Mr John Brown) has noted in his second reading speech, the purpose of this Bill is simply to regulate the use of the Advance Australia logo. The major aim of the Advance Australia campaign has been and will continue to be to stimulate the demand for Australian goods and services. For my own part, that objective is a very worthy one.

SPEECH.PARA: Before I proceed to some of the other issues raised by the Bill, I think it is important that we look a little more closely at the background and some of the achievements of the Advance Australia campaign. In August 1979 the Australian Manufacturing Council launched the Project Australia campaign of which the Advance Australia theme formed the major part. The 1979-80 annual report of the Australian Manufacturing Council reported that the principal objectives of the Project Australia campaign were as follows: First, to develop an increased sense of national identity and pride amongst Australians; secondly, to highlight the contribution that each individual can make towards attaining and sustaining a strong economy; thirdly, to emphasise the importance of product quality, design and marketing; and, finally, to encourage the purchase, use and export of Australian products, services and technology to increase employment opportunities.

Between 1979 and 1981 the campaign was managed by the Department of Industry and Commerce through the Project Australia Committee. In response to strong private sector support and interest during that period, a non-profit public interest company, Advance Australia, was established in mid-1981 to manage the on-going campaign. I think it is important to emphasise that since 1979 revenue for the campaign has come from two major sources. More than $5m has been provided by the Federal Government and more than $3m has been derived from licensing arrangements involving the franchise of the Advance Australia logo. As all honourable members who have spoken on this Bill today have indicated, it has been a joint venture between government enterprise and private enterprise. Because of the success of those licensing arrangements, which I understand in 1982 and 1983 involved more than 700 actively participating companies which will contribute some $1.8m in licensing fees, the Federal Government ceased its contribution to the campaign in June last year. The Advance Australia company is now a self-funding private sector project.

There is no doubt that that campaign has been remarkably well received by the Australian community. It is estimated that the logo advertising now appears in marketing activities and advertising of goods worth more than $2 billion annually. Research completed last year showed overwhelmingly that Australian consumers are prepared to support Advance Australia products in preference to other products. Ninety-nine per cent of Australians instantly recognised the logo and 79 per cent of Australians indicated that they were favourably disposed towards this campaign. More than half of the population clearly stated its preference for products bearing the Advance Australia logo. So in many ways the logo has become the Australian consumers' means of putting their support and, importantly, their money behind this country, its products and its services.

Not only has the campaign made a substantial contribution to improved sales for Australian manufacturers but also it has enhanced Australian pride and participation in our community. It is fascinating to look back just five years ago at the perceptions that Australians had of themselves and their country. Yesterday I was reading an article on this subject in the February 1982 edition of the Bulletin. It quotes Mr Phillip Adams, who at that time was involved in the market research in the preliminary stages of Advance Australia and who had to present its conclusions. The Bulletin quotes Mr Adams as having said the following about Australians and their perceptions at that time:

The research was totally gloomy. I had to tell Malcolm Fraser and I remember that he hated it. The research said that Australia didn't have any leadership, it didn't have any quality, that if a product said Made in Australia, no one would buy it. There was a sense of apocalypse, of being third class, almost a sense of despair. To be Australian was, in a sense, to be a walking apology.

That was in 1979. I think everyone who has spoken in this debate, particularly the honourable member for Stirling and the honourable member for Tangney (Mr Gear), has indicated that times have changed very much. No longer is there that sense of despair and desperation in being an Australian. One is no longer a walking apology for being an Australian. It is a fascinating change and it has occurred just in that space of five years. I think there are three or four reasons for that change. Obviously, the Advance Australia campaign has made a significant contribution to changing people's attitudes about the quality of Australian goods and the strength of Australian manufacturing. That is a very desirable change but, of course, the political situation has also changed. It is in many ways predictable that the research done at that time would have indicated that Australia did not have any leadership. Of course, it did not, and that is something that has changed fundamentally in five years. We now have a political system which offers leadership to the Australian people. We have a Prime Minister who is supported by and popular amongst more than 73 per cent of Australians. The Government has some positive policies and there is a greater sense of optimism and confidence about the future. Importantly, there is a new sense of co-operation and consensus within our community. That comes across private enterprise, government and the whole union movement. There we have two factors-Advance Australia and the change in political circumstances.

The Australian film industry, which the honourable member for Stirling mentioned, has also made a very substantial contribution to our own self-image and our image as Australians. We can all be proud of the Australian film industry, which evolved particularly in the early 1970s under the Whitlam Australian Labor Party Government. In the period 1979-84 some remarkable achievements have been made. Films such as Breaker Morant, The Man From Snowy River, Phar Lap and Gallipoli, to name just a few, have all offered a very new and positive perspective of our history. They have also been resounding box office successes. Not only have they been resounding box office successes in Australia but, importantly in terms of Australians' self-image and perception and the quality of what we can produce, these have been outstanding box office successes overseas. In addition, there are the television series. We produced the series A Town Like Alice and, more recently, All the Rivers Run. A Town Like Alice was not watched by just 70 per cent of Australian television viewers; it showed in 50 countries around the world. When it showed in Britain for a week an average of 16 million viewers watched it every evening. That is a remarkable achievement. It won the international Emmy award for the best foreign drama and, as I have said, it has been sold in more than 50 countries.

As I have said, those films have not just given us a new sense of identity and purpose in terms of our culture, history and development, but they have also been outstanding successes, highly professional artistic productions. They have not only done well in Australia but also shown what we can achieve overseas. It is for that reason that some people have suggested that the Australian film industry is rapidly taking over. It is rapidly becoming the most successful export industry since merino wool.

A number of other matters have contributed to that sense of greater aspiration, confidence and pride in being Australian. Obviously the sporting achievements in the last two years are also very significant. Again the honourable member for Tangney and the honourable member for Stirling mentioned some of those achievements-I do not want to dwell on them; they were great achievements-the America's Cup, the Davis Cup, the victory of Robert de Castella. We have had victories in the Australian netball team and, of course, we have had victories in men's and women's cricket. So all those factors have contributed to this greater sense of identity and positive self-image of Australians. As I have said that is a complete turnaround from that research in 1979 which showed that Australians really felt themselves to be a walking apology.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Moscow Olympics too.

—That did not help, did it? It is shameful. To conclude on a few final remarks, I did refer earlier to the objectives of that Project Australia campaign when it was launched in 1979. The fourth objective I mentioned was to:

SPEECH.PARA: encourage the purchase, use and export of Australian products, services and technology so as to increase employment opportunities.

I just want to say that that is an objective, amongst those other objectives, which is totally and wholeheartedly supported by this Government. Early in 1983 a number of the national media organisations throughout Australia concentrated on the issue of Australian industry, Australian employment and Australian technology and the need for us to develop further in the future. The Melbourne Age in particular had a month-long investigation into the technology gap as it termed it. In that paper of 5 January 1983 we find:
As a nation Australia has given the world the Hills hoist, Victa lawnmowers, automatic totalisators and Henselite lawn bowls.

We have such a rich history of inventiveness that it is puzzling why, as one observer wrote recently, the country should seem almost prostrate and about to be run over by the juggernaut of the microprocessor revolution.

A four-week investigation by 'The Age' has identified a number of reasons for our national malaise in exploiting new technology in industry. They include inadequate Government policies, complacency and bad management by business and a lack of venture capital for new companies and products.

We find that in the Age of January 1983. As I have said that issue was studied for more than a month. A little later, in May of that year, another prominent Victorian newspaper, the Melbourne Herald, devoted a number of its editions to the question of technology. In its editorial on 2 May of that year it stated:

Australia is losing ground in economic and job growth and is being overtaken by smaller and less naturally well-endowed nations, because of our lagging pace in the international pursuit of new technology. The position is not merely worrying but critical.

If anyone has listened, as I know many people have, to the comments, speeches and remarks made by our excellent Minister for Science and Technology (Mr Barry Jones) since our election last year as a government many would recognise that those sentiments and facts expressed in those two newspapers are a truism. We have slipped well and truly behind in the industrial and technological race. Prior to the last election in March 1983 our Party, which is now the Government, made a very firm commitment to developing a more positive approach to industry policy and to creating the most favourable environment possible for the growth and development of industry. Of course the reason I mention that is that it ties in perfectly with that fourth objective of the Australian Manufacturing Council.

I want to point out that our Government has already acted in a number of ways to put effect to those commitments and so to foster and develop our industry and technological growth. Some of those policies we have already made and enunciated . We have retained the investment allowance and that was an important decision. We have allocated a record $71.6m for Australian Industrial Research and Development Incentives Board schemes. We have broadened importantly its terms of reference. Last year we legislated to establish the development of a private sector venture-capital market in Australia involving 100 per cent tax deductibility in the year in which the capital is subscribed.

Last year again we strengthened and expanded the supporting services available to exporters through the Export Finance and Insurance Corporation. We injected an additional $12.5m into the Australian Industry Development Corporation, thereby allowing for a $50m increase in AIDC statutory capital. Importantly also , we increased its gearing ratio so that it will be able to borrow up to 15 times the level of its capacity and reserves compared with eight times the level in the past. Finally, and most recently, we have expanded significantly small business education, counselling and information programs and we recently established a new Council of Small Business Organisations of Australia.

Of course the need for action in all those areas was overwhelming and the need for further action in the future is equally as strong. It would be no good at all for any government to say 'We have made those achievements already. They are positive achievements. We can now sit back and watch things progress', because that is not what will happen. Things will move forward but we have a very long way to go. I was very impressed this morning by some of the remarks made by the Minister for Science and Technology when introducing a Bill to amend the Patents Act. I wish very briefly to quote two paragraphs of the speech of the Minister this morning.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! This would have to relate to the Bill before us.
—It does very much, Madam Deputy Speaker. I mentioned before the very important part of the whole Advance Australia campaign was to:

SPEECH.PARA: encourage the purpose, use and export of Australian products, services and technology so as to increase employment opportunities.

That has been fundamental to that campaign. It has been a joint campaign between government and private enterprise. I totally support the Advance Australia campaign. I am just trying to emphasise how important that is and I will just do it very briefly by quoting one paragraph and then I will finish off. The Minister said:

With its 15 million people, Australia has 0.3 per cent of the world's population. We perform 2 per cent of the world's scientific research, but originate 0.7 per cent of patents and undertake only 0.1 per cent of high technology production. Australia is in the middle rank of Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development nations in terms of government expenditure on research and development. But because of the very small contribution by industry we fall near the bottom of the list in terms of gross expenditure on research and development.
The poor performance of the Australian private sector in research and development finds its reflection in Australia's comparitive standing as a technologically-advanced country.

I believe that, over a period of five years, the Advance Australia organisation has made a great contribution to increasing our self image and perception to encouraging excellence in every area and particularly in industry. I believe that our Government, since its election, has also acted to stimulate and give every possible encouragement to industry. I see both of those objectives moving along the same course. The last paragraphs I quoted from the Minister's speech this morning are pertinent because the challenge certainly lies ahead, not only for this Government, but also particularly for private industry in Australia. The challenge is very much in one sense in the hands of the Advance Australia organisation to continue its work in the future and to continue to ensure that the private sector itself encourages excellence and puts the resources into research and development so that we are able in the future to compete equally as a nation with other countries. I commend the Bill to the House.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brown The Hon J.J.

TALKER.NAME: Mr JOHN BROWN
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Sport, Recreation and Tourism)

TALK.START.PARA: —in reply-In closing the debate I would like to make a few comments. I hope that those people who are sitting in the gallery note that it is possible to have a pleasant debate in this House. It is not necessarily a cockpit for rancour and discord. On some occasions there is some rapport between all honourable members of this House. I am pleased to note that the sense of national pride that I detect, which is abroad in Australia in large measure at present, reflects itself in a debate such as this in the national Parliament. I think that can only do something about raising the stature of this House.

SPEECH.PARA: I will say a few words about national pride. I noticed that all Government members who spoke in this debate concentrated particularly on Australia's achievements of late. Of course, that thread also ran through the contributions from the honourable member for Ryan (Mr Moore) and the honourable member for Higgins (Mr Shipton). This sense of national pride was not around some years ago . Referring to the quote of 1979 from the honourable member for Bendigo (Mr Brumby), I think it is true to say that the sense of despair and hopelessness which existed some years ago, of almost apologising if one was recognised as an Australian, has largely dissipated. If people were asked to nominate the great achievement of the Hawke Government since March 1983, I suspect they would say it is in restoring a sense of national unity, pride, optimism and hope to the Australian community, which reflects itself in many ways.

I have always had a belief that Australians need to shrug off their cultural cringe, their feeling of inferiority. I think that Australians should realise that this is, as has been stated in several prestigious magazines in the last year, the most interesting and most exciting country in the world. It has taken us a long time to realise exactly what we have achieved in Australia. People perhaps should look at our history and discover that in 1950 there were less than 150,000 Europeans in Australia. What this small group of Western people has achieved in conjunction with native Australians is simply miraculous. To turn an island that was so far from the mainstream of world activity, an island with a hostile environment, into one of the great economic and social developments of the world's history is something of which we should be duly proud. I think it is time we shrugged off that inferiority complex that led us perhaps even to advertise Australia as a zoo, as a marsupial farm, and never to push our great achievements in terms of culture, enterprise and business. I am pleased to note that all Government members took up those points when they spoke about our achievements in sport that have given us a sense of national identity in the last 12 months or so.

The high standard of our films and television productions was mentioned by the honourable member for Bendigo. He also touched on our high technological achievements that the Minister for Science and Technology (Mr Barry Jones) is forever pushing at us. Fortunately Australians are starting to realise this. But , more importantly, he mentioned the improvement in the standard of Australian manufactured products. I think it is high time that we did realise that Australian products stand up very well in comparison with similar products around the world. That makes the Advance Australian Logo Protection Bill all the more important because the Advance Australia logo is a signal, a sign, of the high standard of Australian manufacture.

While I noted that one member of the Opposition pointed out that this campaign was started by the previous Government-of course that is true-the reason this Bill is before the House is that whoever started it was sufficiently incompetent not to register the design; that is why the Bill is here. But if that mistake led to a reasonable debate, I guess there is something to be said for the mistake that was made.

I would like to say something about some of the suggestions that were made by members of the Opposition. The honourable member for Ryan, in leading for the Opposition, suggested that the licence charges might be too high. That suggestion was reinforced by the honourable member for Higgins. This certainly was a complaint in the first stages of the Advance Australia campaign but, as I understand it, there has been no such similar complaint for at least 18 months. I think I should also point out that the product licence is the only source of revenue for the company. The level of the fee that is applied is determined by the Advance Australia Board. Further, I think it is also fair to point out that, where there is an application from a non-profit body to use the logo, no fee is charged by the company. The level of the fee, when it is charged to commercial enterprises, is determined by the Board on the basis of the income expected to be derived from the sale of Advance Australia products. So I do not think the complaint that the licence fee is too high is legitimate. In fact, if the profits of the company do become excessive, the Government could be quite amenable to looking at this matter because the logo is intended to be a great profit maker for the company and to signify that the product that bears that logo is a product of which Australia can be proud.

The honourable member for Higgins commented on air fares when talking about Australia's new ventures in tourism. I am sad to see that he adopts this destructive, negative approach to most of the things that we have done in tourism that seem to be lauded by the other 15 million people in Australia and certainly by everybody in the tourism industry and, in the case of air fares, by the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Peacock). At exactly the same hour as the honourable member for Higgins, in his role as the shadow Minister for Tourism, was putting out a Press release decrying the new air fares the Leader of the Opposition, who is much more intelligent and much more attuned with proper conduct and behaviour, was putting out a Press release lauding the incentive. I dare say that the honourable member for Higgins will be pulled in and chastised by the Leader of the Opposition if he continues this constant carping which is doing him and nobody else any credit. He is certainly considered a farce in the tourist industry.

TALK.START.PARA: —He is getting under your skin.

—No, he will never get under my skin. He also mentioned the difficulty Val Doonican had in filming at Ayers Rock. I think he has brought up a reasonable argument. It is fair to point out that the rules that apply to filming at Ayers Rock have really nothing to do with the consequence of the Government's decision to hand ownership of the park back to the Aboriginals. Commercial activity, such as filming, within Uluru National Park is subject to the provisions of the National Parks and Wildlife Conservation Act and the park plan of management. Those restrictions are not applied by the Aboriginals to suit themselves; they are a measure of the fact that Ayers Rock is a sacred ground of the Aboriginals. It is part of their heritage and they have strict conditions on how it is used.

SPEECH.PARA: As I understand it, there have been 51 applications in the last 12 months for filming at the Rock and only four applications have been rejected. The reason the filming of the Paul Hogan advertisement ran into difficulty is that nobody had bothered to apply for permission. After about a two-hour delay permission was granted and filming went ahead. Of course, this advertisement has had a great effect on the Californians, who are now streaming here in their thousands. The original proposition for the Val Doonican filming was not acceptable to the Aboriginals responsible for management of the park and they knocked it back. Subsequently, there has been another application which is much more in line with the guidelines. That application has been granted and filming has gone ahead.

All in all, I am quite pleased to note that we did have a pleasant and productive debate on this issue. On occasions we can find a matter of accord in this House. I am pleased to see that the most significant reason for that in this debate was national pride. I think it is high time Australians realised that this is the most exciting country in the world. It is a pity that we needed American and French magazines to point out to us that we were the country of the year. At least that is reflected in the attitude of honourable members of this Parliament on both sides of the House.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Leave granted for third reading to be moved forthwith.
Bill (on motion by Mr John Brown) read a third time.
Debate resumed from 7 March, on motion by Dr Blewett:
That the Bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Carlton The Hon J.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —We are returning to debate on the Quarantine Amendment Bill which was introduced by the Minister for Health (Dr Blewett). I have been searching around all week to find some nice things to say about the Minister for Health. He has had a fairly difficult week and I was feeling a bit sorry for him yesterday. However, I am pleased to be able to say that on this matter of quarantine there is quite a broad measure of agreement. I am able to say some nice things about the Minister in regard to this Bill.

SPEECH.PARA: The main purpose of the Bill is to increase the penalties for quarantine offences. A lot of concern has been expressed by rural industries and honourable members on both sides of the House representing rural constituencies as to the very small penalties imposed on offenders in quarantine matters. For example, as pointed out in the Minister's second reading speech, the penalty in 1979 for a breach of quarantine was a maximum of $10,000 or five years imprisonment. Under the measure proposed these penalties will be increased to $50,000 or 10 years imprisonment or both on the part of an individual. For a body corporate there would be a maximum fine of $200,000.

In the case of a failure to observe or obey a direction by the Minister in an emergency-for example, if there were some outbreak of foot and mouth disease or some other terrible disease amongst livestock or plants-such a failure in 1979 would have attracted a penalty of only $10,000 or five years imprisonment. Under the proposals being put forward it is now a maximum penalty of $100,000 or 10 years imprisonment, or both. I think that those penalties, which we certainly support, will reinforce the very real concern that people have about the outcomes of possible breaches of quarantine.

It is certainly very much in our minds, as it is in the Government's, that a simple outbreak of foot and mouth disease in Australia could bring to a total standstill our exports of meat and other commodities of livestock origin, causing a drop in rural output in the order of $2.5 billion in the first year. An economic disaster of that kind would be terrible for Australia. Therefore, there is a need for constant vigilance in these matters. Certainly the penalties introduced indicate the seriousness of the Government's purpose in this matter. We support the Government on that.

Of course we have the opportunity with a Bill of this kind, which has an enormous number of provisions, for a fairly wide-ranging debate on quarantine issues which honourable members want to take up. Before I pass on to some of the more detailed matters in the Bill I mention the point that if penalties are to be imposed we must first catch the offenders. In one particular area there is a matter of concern which apparently has not been resolved. The point was raised on 10 November last year by my friend and colleague the honourable member for Riverina (Mr Hicks) in a Press release. It concerned the threat to northern defences of exotic diseases. I think it is worth quoting from the honourable member's Press release which stated:
Australia's meat export industry could be threatened by a reduction in aerial surveillance of northern Australia . . . Mr Hicks said until the end of March this year-
That was 1983-
radar surveillance was provided over a section of coastline up to 200 nautical miles off the north west approaches to Darwin, using specially equipped Nomad aircraft.
'However, because the contract was not renewed, there is now no radar surveillance of any part of this stretch of ocean, except for overflights by RAAF Orion aircraft about twice a month.'
Mr Hicks said the Northern Territory Government had sent a submission calling for the flights to be reintroduced, to the Federal Government in about August.
He said the submission pointed out the dangers faced by Australia without adequate surveillance.
The Northern Territory Government submission stated:

'In this light the cost of surveillance must be considered in terms of the horrendus penalties, economic and social, that will be incurred following just one outbreak of any of several animal diseases from which Australia is now free.

'The Commonwealth Department of Health estimates that in the event of a confirmed outbreak of foot and mouth disease, which could be introduced by way of infected animals, foodstuffs and animal products, rural output would fall by as much as $2500 million in the first year alone as vast quantities of products would become immediately unexportable. It would cost the beef industry $1000 million each year.'

Mr Hicks said the submission also pointed out that other equally devastating diseases, such as Rinderpest, Swine Vesicular Disease, Virulent Newcastle Disease, African Swine Fever, Screw Worm Fly and many more also posed a major threat.
'The submission argues that to restrict surveillance operations on economic grounds in the face of threats of this magnitude is 'the very ultimate of penny wisdom and pound foolishness'.
'There are a host of exotic diseases that are literally on Australia's northern doorstep and we should be strengthening, rather than weakening, our northern surveillance capabilities.
He continued:

'I want to know whether the relevant Federal Ministers are aware of the Territory Government's submission. If they are, then why has the Government apparently taken no action on it. If they are not, then they should be asking why the report has not been brought to their attention, . . .'

I have been making inquiries as to whether there has been a satisfactory response to the honourable member's Press release. Apparently there is still great concern on the part of the Northern Territory Government. If in the course of the debate the Minister or the Government were able to give any indication to the House as to actions taken in response to that matter we in the Opposition would certainly be grateful.

There are other matters in the Bill which I want to refer to. Firstly I mention the appointment of quarantine officers of which there are some 1,700 in Australia. I would be the first to welcome the administrative reform which the Minister has introduced on this occasion. One of the first things I noticed when I was initiated into the mysteries of the Ministry of Health is that I spent most of a Sunday afternoon looking through an enormous number of submissions of a totally trivial nature. On the first Sunday afternoon when I was looking through the blue bags and saw all the things I had to read and sign there seemed to be a dozen appointments of quarantine officers to some remote part of Tasmania. These submissions had to be read and signed by me. Subsequently, since I was a member of the Executive Council, I had to meet the Governor-General for the signing of these documents so that they could be passed into law and the appointments made. I noticed the Governor-General too had the burdensome problem of signing all these submissions for all 1,700 quarantine officers who seemed to be changing their positions very frequently indeed.

That was indicative of a general problem within public administration where there has not been a serious analysis of the relevant level of decision making in each of the portfolio areas. I know that the Minister for Finance (Mr Dawkins ) is looking at these matters and is trying to do something about them. I hope that each Minister within each portfolio area will recognise these nonsenses. In my case I asked the Department to prepare changes to the law so that we would take these matters off the Governor-General's table, and also off my table. I am glad to see that the present Minister has continued with this. The result is the change in this Bill.

In this particular case the Governor-General is relieved of this burdensome task. I am sure he gave very serious consideration-as did the Minister-to each individual appointment. Now it is up to the Minister to give approval for the appointment of the Director of Quarantine and chief quarantine officers. For the remainder of appointments the Director of Quarantine can make those decisions.

There is another aspect of the Bill on which I want to comment. I do not want to delay the House too long as other members wish to speak. My point concerns the power of the Minister to determine the level of fees for the recovery of expenses on quarantine issues instead of having these brought about by regulation. I notice that the changes recommended to be made by the Minister are still subject to parliamentary disallowance under certain provisions of the Acts Interpretation Act. It is nice to know that on this occasion I can congratulate the Minister on the procedure he has used here which contrasts with the procedure contained in a clause of another Bill about which we have a public dispute. In the first instance the Minister has allowed for parliamentary scrutiny.

I am also pleased to observe that he is following a principle, in the setting of these fees, of the recovery of direct operating costs. In other words, this is the user pays mechanism. It seems that in another area the Minister is not all that keen on this principle either, but in this case that principle is being followed. We certainly support the application of reasonable levels of fees for the recovery of costs. Certainly these are not based on any form of percentage of after tax income or whatever other measure one might apply for the recovery of costs. The remainder of the Bill covers a whole lot of tidying up provisions with which we do not disagree. Therefore we are supporting the Bill. I will allow other speakers in the debate to raise matters that are of particular importance to them or to their constituencies.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Snow Mr J.H.

TALK.START.PARA: — Breaches of quarantine could one day very easily ruin Australia's primary exports, devastate the economies of country towns, wipe out farm incomes and reduce the living standards of all Australians. The Quarantine Amendment Bill 1984 which is now before the Parliament increases the penalties that may be imposed upon people who offend the quarantine laws of Australia. The Bill also amends the Quarantine Act 1908 to bring it up to date. For instance, the Governor-General is required to appoint each quarantine officer. Confronted with 1,700 quarantine officers the Governor-General would not want to spend half his working hours appointing them. One Governor-General is rumoured to have observed that everyone in Australia must have been appointed a quarantine officer at some time. The machinery changes in this Bill relieve the Governor-General of that task.

SPEECH.PARA: Mr Don Duncan, the Veterinary Inspector at Yass, has only recently pointed out the dangers of foot and mouth disease, which is rapidly spreading. It is the most infectious disease known to humans, a debilitating disease leading to low production of milk, meat and wool and tragic deaths amongst unborn and new-born animals. Foot and mouth disease affects sheep, cattle, goats and pigs. This Bill raises the penalties for persons who introduce that disease and other diseases into Australia.

We have had such scares in this country. Honourable members may recall that there was a scare in the Northern Territory in 1977. Fortunately the bluetongue virus was not clinically significant. There was also a criminal threat from a Queenslander who said he would bring a virus into the country if he did not get his way. With all the overseas travel and with our proximity to other countries to the north one day there will be reason for the scare. One day a threat may be carried out and then what will happen? Don Duncan, the Yass veterinary officer, has told farmers what to do if the symptoms of foot and mouth disease are suspected. First, they should immediately report it to the authorities. No person, animal, vehicle or thing may enter or leave the affected property until the veterinary officer arrives. Then all livestock on the property is to be destroyed. That is what will happen on the farm but that is not all that will happen because the farmer and his or her family will be ruined.

What will happen nationally if, for instance, our quarantine laws do not discourage a disease such as foot and mouth or bluetongue from entering this country? Even though the bluetongue scare in the Northern Territory in 1977 was uneventful it lost the region $5m through a complete ban on exports and delayed and disrupted marketing. Some $5m was lost over what turned out to be only a scare. However this is nothing compared with the likely cost of an outbreak of bluetongue or foot and mouth disease.

Our animal product exports to most countries depend on our foot and mouth disease free status. The United States of America, Japan, Korea and Canada all depend totally on that status. Our strongest competitors, the European Economic Community, Argentina and Brazil have foot and mouth disease. The United States cattle producers use the foot and mouth disease as a lever to keep imports down. Foot and mouth disease in Australia would mean that we would have to compete with cheap South American beef on the United States market and that would be a real sock in the jaw for our beef exports. Exports of sheep and sheep meat would be seriously affected. Some countries would also ban wool imports. We are talking here about over $1,000m that would be lost in beef exports, nearly $400m that would be lost in sheep meat exports and $40m that would be lost in pig meat exports. Nearly $2,000m in wool exports would be threatened as well as $387m in dairy products and $6m in eggs. I say 'threaten' wool, dairy and egg exports because there would be some export bans. The total cost to Australia and Australians would not be hundreds of millions of dollars but thousands of millions of dollars.

This Bill deals with the front line of attack against exotic diseases-our quarantine laws. In Australia there is plenty of apathy which arises from our country's good fortune in the past with exotic animal diseases. We have been fortunate because our native animals have few serious endemic diseases which are transmittable to live- stock. We have little need of meat and animal product imports. This reduces the probablility of disease. Our climate and low livestock density in northern Australia are unfavourable to the spread of animal pathogens . We have been relatively free of exotic diseases because of our geographical isolation. All of these great advantages are now dissolving as more and more people travel in and out of the country using air transport. People visit overseas farms-as I did on one occasion-and wear the same shoes and clothes back in Australia. Far worse, there are some tourists who would like occasionally to bring into the country undesirable goods such as salami produced in a country where foot and mouth disease or other exotic diseases are prevalent. Our good fortune may easily change. We are closer in travelling time to South East Asia than ever before. Contact with our northern coastline may mean that one day one of the dreaded diseases will reach our shores. Once that animal disease is found , no more questions will be asked. In that case only Tasmania may be saved from meat export bans.

A few years ago a traveller illegally imported bull semen which is a very successful carrier of the bluetongue virus. The offender was caught. One day this sort of contravention of the laws which protect us could lead to the outbreak we fear. The maximum penalty for importing a disease agent contrary to the Act is no longer $10,000 or five years imprisonment; it is $50,000 or imprisonment for 10 years, or both. If the offender is a body corporate the fine is $200,000. Obstruction no longer leads to a fine of $10,000 or five years imprisonment. It is $100,000 or 10 years imprisonment, or both. But penalties are not the entire answer. If this legislation is to work people must be told about it. Community education is needed on foot and mouth disease, rift valley fever, bluetongue disease and other diseases which would cause an immediate cessation of exports.

Who would pay for an outbreak of a major exotic disease? It would be the farmer , whose net income would be wiped out and whose livestock would be slaughtered. The Government would pay. The Government would have to pay for disinfection and for compensation to keep the family alive. 'Government' means the taxpayer. Then there would be a reduction in the number of taxpayers as farmers became non- income earners. The taxpayers left would have to pay. Even that has its limits. Social security beneficiaries, pensioners, unemployed and others would have to take, as usual, more than their share of the economic downturn.

We vote for this legislation as an insurance against an enormous drop in Australian output and revenue. The legislation is but one response to a healthy fear. Excessive fear is powerless, but fear can be nature's warning signal to get busy. Feral animal control is another response. The straightening out of the proliferation of Federal and State departments involved with animal health is another response we ought to make. But here we have a Bill which will have no financial impact on the taxpayer, only on the criminal offenders. It is another government move to defend Australia's social and economic standards in the country and ultimately in the cities.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McGauran Mr P.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The purpose of this legislation is to increase penalties for offences committed against the Quarantine Act 1908 as well as to improve quarantine administration in both Australia and the Cocos (Keeling) Islands. Together with my Opposition colleagues, I support this legislation. The substantial increases in penalties are overdue and are in line with the previous Government's increase in penalties for offences contravening our export regulations. The previous Government increased penalties for any Australian exporter who shipped agricultural products which were below standard. It is pleasing that this Australian Labor Party Government has followed that lead and enacted legislation which the coalition Government had intended.

SPEECH.PARA: There are, however, a number of concerns which I wish to draw to the attention of the Parliament. At the risk of stating the obvious, I stress that Australia, as an island continent largely dependent on agricultural livestock exports, needs to enforce its quarantine laws with the utmost diligence. That need is impossible to overstate. Although Australia has been remarkably free of exotic diseases to date we must constantly guard against complacency. We cannot afford under any circumstances to rest on our laurels or in any way ease our stringent quarantine safeguards. Indeed, I believe that there is a clear case for further tightening present measures.

Let me examine three areas where I believe the Government has not acted as forcibly as it might have. Firstly, it was an election promise of the Labor Party to transfer Commonwealth responsibility for animal and plant quarantine from the Department of Health to the Department of Primary Industry. I support that transfer and express my disappointment that the Government has failed to honour its election promise. It is only common sense to transfer the quarantine administration from the Department of Health, which is concerned with the health of humans, to the Department of Primary Industry, which is primarily concerned with the health of animals. After all, the Department of Primary Industry is responsible for ensuring that health quarantine standards are met by Australian exporters. So it is only logical and, I suspect, less expensive-more economical, that is-for the Department of Primary Industry also to assume responsibility for the quarantine standards of imports. I therefore express my disappointment that the Minister for Primary Industry (Mr Kerin) has failed to act on his Government 's election promise. At this point I will resist the temptation to list the several other rural election promises that the Minister has not honoured.

The second area which concerns me is the Government's handling of the Australian National Animal Health Laboratory at Geelong. In September 1983 we witnessed in the Parliament and outside it a heated and, at times, even bitter conflict between, on the one hand, the Minister for Science and Technology (Mr Barry Jones) and the Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation and, on the other hand, that Minister and the Minister for Primary Industry. As a result of the confusion over funding for ANAHL at that time as well as in the future, the importance of ANAHL was significantly degraded. Staff morale suffered. The Minister's public lack of confidence in ANAHL will have long term consequences. The situation at present is that the ministerial committee on ANAHL will make a submission to Cabinet based on the advice of the advisory committee chaired by Professor Frank Fenner. It is to be hoped that the Government will then act expeditiously to end the confusion and support ANAHL in its fight against the diseases which could threaten our livestock industry.

The third area which needs closer scrutiny is quarantine controls at airports in Australia. A number of constituents, and particularly the shire of South Gippsland, share my concern that improvements could be made in this regard. I acknowledge that Australia is one of the few countries in the world which require entrants at airports to declare their movements overseas to be able to determine whether they have come into contact with a farm or farm animals, but, as the Shire of South Gippsland maintains, this is often where the matter ends. The person who has made the declaration is then subject only to a very cursory examination. I understand that the purpose of the declaration is to enable the quarantine officer to make a judgment as to whether the apparel and shoes are free of mud and/or organic materials. If the apparel or shoes are visibly clean no cleaning is needed. I acknowledge that it is not practical to take the test any further than this. I further acknowledge that we cannot devise a system which will guarantee against the importation of organic materials. But the concern is that in some instances the examination is very brief and very superficial.

I recently returned from a visit to Japan as part of a parliamentary delegation which visited farms. I made the declaration and was directed to the relevant officer. I informed him that I was wearing the same pair of shoes that I had worn on the farm but that they had since been cleaned. The officer behind the bench did not examine the shoes and did not, furthermore, ask to see any of my clothing but simply waved me through. This has also been my experience on other occasions and has been the experience of a number of Australians. There are obvious problems with delays and the frustrations that these delays could cause by-I will not say a more serious search-a more detailed examination of clothing and shoes. But I believe that the risk inherent in the importation of exotic diseases into Australia merits further examination by quarantine officers.

This would require an increase in the number of quarantine officers. I realise that that necessarily means an increase in expenditure, but it is a matter of what are this Government's priorities. If its priorities are the same as those of the Opposition, and that is the complete protection so far as is humanly possible of our livestock industry, it will be prepared to increase the number of quarantine officers so that a more thorough examination can be made of persons who make a declaration that they have visited farms during their overseas travel.

I also add that I have a concern about coastal surveillance in the northern part of Australia and the apparent lessening of importance which this Government and this Minister place on maintaining that surveillance. As the honourable member for Mackellar (Mr Carlton) pointed out in his speech, there is no point in increasing penalties for those who offend quarantine laws if we are not able first to apprehend them. I therefore urge the Government to treat coastal surveillance as seriously as does the Opposition and again allocate the necessary expenditure to maintain a viable and serious surveillance scheme.

One of the problems in increasing expenditure in this area is that we do not immediately see returns for that increased expenditure. I suppose it is a bit like the Secret Service guarding the President. If there are no assassination attempts on the President over five years, I guess that some would question the level of expenditure on the Secret Service. Of course, in that case, as in this case, the success is measured by whether there is an emergency. It is very difficult to assess the effectiveness or otherwise of our quarantine laws, quarantine surveillance and quarantine enforcement. Given the stakes at risk, in many cases involving the survival of our primary industry, this matter deserves the full attention and energy of, and enforcement by, this Government. Furthermore, increased expenditure and a higher priority ought to be given in the area of coastal surveillance and, just as importantly, in regard to quarantine officers at airports.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McLeay Mr L.B.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will say a few words on the Quarantine Amendment Bill and make the point that the present Government has moved quickly in many areas in the quarantine jurisdiction. In fact, I was surprised to hear the previous speaker, the honourable member for Gippsland (Mr McGauran), say that he was concerned that the Government had not carried out its election pledge to transfer quarantine services to the Department of Primary Industry. I have no doubt that, if he had spoken to his colleague the honourable member for Mackellar (Mr Carlton) before he spoke, he would have realised that the honourable member for Mackellar and his predecessor, as Ministers for Health, grappled with this question for a number of years. The previous speaker's party was unable to come to any decision about transferring the quarantine service from the Department of Health to the Department of Primary Industry after it had considered it for a number of years. The present Minister for Health (Dr Blewett ) has a submission before him regarding the matter and at least he has become active on the matter within 12 months. So it is rather carping criticism on the part of the Opposition to say that within the first 12 months in government we have not transferred a problem that it had had for many years.

SPEECH.PARA: I address myself also to a matter raised by the previous speaker regarding the Australian National Animal Health Laboratory. The situation is that the current Government is now seeking to resolve that problem. The Government set up an expert committee chaired by Professor Frank Fenner, to view the future functions of ANAHL. The committee recommended that there should be a reduction in the size of ANAHL's operations and that it should not manufacture vaccines, as had originally been planned. Also, there is to be a sharing of financial responsibilities for ANAHL. Fifty per cent of the financial responsibilities will be shared by the Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation and 50 per cent by the Department of Primary Industry. The Fenner report was adopted with minor administrative changes by the ministerial committee on ANAHL and a Cabinet decision on ANAHL's future may be expected shortly. I think that that action shows that the present Government has taken an extremely responsible approach to matters dealing with animal health, with the prevention of importation of animal related diseases and other diseases that could be affected by Australia's quarantine laws. Opposition speakers by implying that the Government has been rather tardy show that they do not really understand the situation at all.

The present legislation which has been introduced by the Minister provides in the main for a substantial increase in the penalties that accrue to those who breach Australia's quarantine laws. Honourable members may be aware that the present penalty for conviction for breaches of quarantine laws is a maximum fine of $10,000 or a five-year gaol term for natural persons. The Government is proposing that that be increased to a $100,000 fine or a 10-year gaol term for natural persons and a $200,000 fine for corporations. People might ask why we need to have these rather extensive and expensive fines or gaol terms. Australia , fortunately, has been free of many animal diseases. It is important that we should do whatever we can to ensure that there is no importation of diseases such as bluetongue-of which we have a little-or foot and mouth disease. Australia earns quite significant export earnings from our livestock exports. Exports in the beef industry alone run to $1,500m per annum. The fact that Australia is free from foot and mouth disease gives our export markets a competitive edge compared with other countries such as Argentina, which has foot and mouth disease. I have no doubt that it is of great importance to the primary producers of this country that we should ensure that Australia remains free from foot and mouth disease.

The importation of those types of diseases is more likely to occur inadvertently by tourists than by any corporation or organisation attempting to import meat or other goods that could carry those diseases. The main area of detection of the importation is of tourists at airports and seaports. I have no doubt that that would account for the fact that the recent penalties that have been imposed by the courts under the quarantine legislation have raised fines of approximately $5,000. No one seems to remember when a gaol sentence was ever handed down for an offence under the quarantine legislation. We ought to be looking today at two things. The first is the size of the fines which will no doubt be a deterrent. The second, however, is a matter raised by my colleague the honourable member for Eden-Monaro (Mr Snow) regarding a community education program so that people know the reasons behind Australia's quarantine legislation.

The Department is moving in the area of providing pamphlets in foreign languages for tourists coming to Australia. The Department is attempting to detect, where possible, tourists who may be inadvertently importing goods which can cause the spread of disease. The main area of danger is the importation of food stuffs, particularly meats and dried meats, such as salamis. The Department probably needs to have a closer look at its education program. There is a greater need for the pamphlets that are handed out on aircraft to be printed in languages that are more appropriate to the originating port of the aircraft. I make that criticism not only in the area of quarantine legislation, but also of the Department of Immigration and Ethnic Affairs, which falls foul of the same issues.

We could also ask our national carrier, Qantas Airways Ltd, to take a more responsive approach as well. Many tourists who enter Australia feel that they are suffering undue inconvenience by our quarantine requirements. We could make a good start, at least in relation to Qantas, if the Minister made an approach direct to Qantas or through the Minister for Aviation (Mr Beazley) to ensure that when Qantas announces over the aircraft's public address system that people must fill out the forms it tells them why they must do it and explains the reason for the penalties. I think we would then find a little more co-operation from tourists. I am of the firm view that the same thing ought to be done in the immigration area.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! It being 12.45 p.m., the debate is interrupted in accordance with sessional order 101A. The debate may be resumed at a later hour. The honourable member will have leave to continue his speech when the debate is resumed.
—I refer the Deputy Prime Minister to the Prime Minister's call, during his recent Asian tour, for the restructuring of Australian industry.
—Hooray; at last you are asking a question about it.
—Would you like to add to it also, Andrew? Would you like to join me in the question?
—No, one Andrew is enough.
—I think Andrew is having as much trouble with you as he is with me.
—Order! The Leader of the Opposition will continue with his question.

—Why is the Government proposing to amend the Trade Practices Act to impose severe limitations on mergers, thus making the rationalisation of high cost industries in Australia harder, which will, therefore, have the effect of impeding the very restructuring the Prime Minister has recently extolled?
—Mr Speaker--
—Don't tell him, Bob.

—It would be helpful if somebody told the Leader of the Opposition how to ask a good question. I think everybody agrees that there will be structural adjustment in all countries. It is happening because of technology changes and consideration of what should be applied in an intelligent industry policy. The difficulty of previous governments has been that people such as those opposite have relied just on tariffs to try to work the magic mechanism of structural adjustment. It has not happened. I have noticed from recent statements of the Leader of the Opposition that he has been adopting the appearance of a protectionist all of a sudden whereas his questions in this House had always been related to the fact that he felt there should not be any protection at all.
—Not me. You thought I was the greatest free-trader in the Parliament .
—Yes, and I have never been wrong to date. The question though, in all seriousness, is this.
—Will you make up your mind? What am I?
—That is a big problem for the Leader of the Opposition. I do not know whether he is coming or going.
—Order! The Deputy Prime Minister will not answer the supplementary questions and I ask the Leader of the Opposition to desist.

—I apologise for the levity. The question is serious and it relates to the matter of mergers and the Trade Practices Act. Of course, it is well known that at times there are mergers which become monopolistic and, therefore, prevent the very purpose of trade-prevent its being free, fair and unfettered. If a company takes the monopolistic attitude that it can dominate the market from production right through to retail, of course, the consumer does not benefit.
—Ha, ha!

—I notice the distinguished colleague of the Leader of the Opposition, the honourable member for Bennelong, laughing. Of course, he had a lot to do with what he called strengthening the Trade Practices Act.
—No, I freed it up.

—The honourable member freed it up to the extent that it is no longer workable! On that basis the Attorney-General quite fairly is having to look at the problems that face consumers and others in Australia to see whether they will bear the burden of what are called monopolistic practices. The idea that international concerns can dominate a market to the detriment of the consumer is a valid criterion that should be looked at by an intelligent Trade Practices Commission. I assure the honourable gentleman that there is no conflict between structural adjustment and mergers. Both have the objective of guaranteeing that the market is fair, that the consumer gets the benefit of it and that the private enterprise sector has an opportunity to flourish in an atmosphere that is fair and unfettered.

—I direct my question to the Prime Minister. In view of the significant rise in next year's Budget outlays projected in the forward Estimates, will the Government be able to reduce personal income taxation in the Budget, particularly for low and middle income earners, while at the same time reducing the Budget deficit?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hawke The Hon R.J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —As I made clear in the House yesterday, the Government will be working towards and will achieve a responsible reduction in the deficit for next financial year. At the same time we will be looking at the scope for significant reductions in direct personal income tax, particularly for lower and middle income earners. Clearly, achieving both those objectives will not be an easy task and will certainly require stringent decisions in regard to expenditure. But the important point is that we will be equal to that task and we will not shirk those decisions which are necesssary to pursue responsible economic management. That is in contrast to the completely opportunistic game being played on the other side of the House, so bad that in respect of the Leader of the Opposition one journalist has been led to say that he has at least a $2 billion credibility gap. At the same time as the Opposition calls for reductions in the deficit it is supporting expenditure on totally unrealistic and uneconomic programs such as the Alice Springs-Darwin railway project and its wish to buy an aircraft carrier. It is no wonder that in these circumstances there is talk about at least a $2 billion credibility gap. I remind the House that the Leader of the Opposition has called for reductions in the personal income tax burden.
—Hear, hear!

—The honourable member says 'Hear, hear!', but as soon as this Government indicates that it has sympathy with the prospect for and will work towards personal income tax reductions, what do we get from the spokesman from the Opposition, the shadow Treasurer? I remind the House of what the shadow Treasurer said on 19 March on AM:

ANSWER.PARA: I think if the Government is faced with a choice between giving a tax cut of, say, $1 billion and having a deficit that is a billion dollars lower than it might otherwise be, I think it ought to choose the latter.

There is the shadow Treasurer talking about the possibility of tax cuts. He said : 'No, we would rather have a billion dollar reduction in the deficit'. We are talking in a hypothetical situation, but I challenge the shadow Treasurer, in the unlikely event that he will be in government after the next election--

TALK.START.PARA: —I challenge you to tell us what you are going to do.
—Order! The honourable member for O'Connor will cease interjecting. He seems to be at his most vocal just after 2 o'clock on every day of sitting.

—In the unlikely event that those opposite had the opportunity, would they repeal the tax cuts brought in by a Labor government? That is the question one has to face up to if one is talking about tax cuts. The Opposition is in total disarray in this fundamental area. Members of the Opposition are opposing one another. The Leader of the Opposition talks about tax cuts. The shadow Treasurer says no. In respect of the fundamental issue of wage policy, the shadow Treasurer has one policy and the relevant shadow Minister has another.

ANSWER.PARA: As far as the economic capacity of the Opposition is concerned, we know what it left us with. These are the things it left this country with. First of all, it left us with a $9.6 billion deficit. Honourable members opposite left us with an inflation rate of 11.5 per cent. In their last year of office they left us with an increase of a quarter of a million in unemployment. That is what they left us with. They left us with a wages explosion. They left us with an explosion in industrial disputation.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! I realise that most of the exchange seems to be fairly good humoured, but the level of noise is becoming far too high, and unreasonable.

—Honourable members opposite had no credibility when they were in government; they have even less credibility in Opposition. That is the reason that they will stay where they are now, in opposition, for the next 20 years.

—On a question of further bipartisanship in this Parliament, I direct a question to the Deputy Prime Minister again. In welcoming the Government's likely change of direction towards liberalising exports of uranium, and recognising the widespread confusion within the industry, I ask whether the Government will encourage likely exporters immediately to enter into negotiations to secure valuable long term contracts for an industry, the uranium industry, that an increasing number of members of this House now see as vital to the nation's future.

—As the Leader of the Opposition would know, the question of contracts for uranium is at present awaiting the survey of that industry by Professor Slatyer who is reviewing the whole of the concepts of the uranium industry, from the question of production to reprocessing and to waste disposal. On that basis, the Government is entitled to get expert advice, and that report should be available before June this year. In the light of that report, the Government will be able to make firm decisions as to its uranium policy. The interesting thing about uranium at present is the spot price. It is down below $ 20, which is well below the contract price of our existing contractors. So any contract in the market at present, because of the floor price indicated by previous governments as well as by our own, is well above the market price. On that score, the question of new contracts is not really a pressing matter.

—My question is addressed to the Minister for Aviation and concerns air fares. Is the Minister aware of some newspaper articles which have appeared in Western Australian publications critical of the Government's newly- announced tourist air fares? Is it true that the newly-announced fares are as cheap as 8c a kilometre? Is it a fact that residents of Western Australia are limited to travel within their own State by the new fares?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Beazley The Hon K.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the honourable member for his question. I have seen the articles to which he refers. They seem to be based on inaccurate information in the first instance, at least in part provided by the Opposition spokesman on tourism, and on a lack of awareness generally of the potential for adding other means of transport to the proposed holiday tours. What the airlines have done, under some pressure from the Government, is to introduce fares permitting a cost as low as 8c per kilometre. That cost compares very favourably with taxis, hire cars, the Indian-Pacific and even some bus fares. The Royal Automobile Club in Perth, for example, calculates that a small car costs about 30c per kilometre to run. Western Australians can get to the eastern States using the $500 fare, contrary to what has been suggested in the articles to which the honourable gentleman refers, and they have an enormous range of options in regard to the $ 800 fare. I cite a couple of examples under both. For example, under the $500 fare they could fly Perth-Darwin-Alice Springs-Perth at a saving of $272 on the price. Using another means of transport, for example, they could fly Perth to Melbourne and on to Launceston, and catch a boat back to Melbourne and fly home via Adelaide for a saving of $297. Or they could use the $800 fare, under which it is possible to fly Perth-Alice Springs-Sydney-Gold Coast - Melbourne - Launceston - Melbourne- Adelaide-Perth, for a saving on air fares of $626. On the basis of that, the Opposition spokesman on tourism and some irresponsible sections of the media in Western Australia addressing this issue have lent themselves completely to misleading the general public on that matter.

ANSWER.PARA: For people who wish to go only to one city, as I have mentioned before, there has been that 45 per cent discount introduced earlier, and some 50,000 Western Australians have already taken advantage of it. The fact of the matter is that, in pressure to provide cheaper air fares for the travelling public to serve the interests of tourism, no government in recent history has done more than this Government to achieve those objectives. There is one other matter in those articles that I wish to correct. Again, it was attributed to the Opposition spokesman on tourism. He seemed to imply in his statements that these were Government directed air fares. It has never been claimed, either by myself or by the Minister for Sport, Recreation and Tourism, that we are capable of issuing directives on air fares.
