Our position, persistently, has been that we have urged the airlines to undertake those air fares initiatives, and I would say that the proof of the pudding is in the eating and that our urgings have, to this point of time, been reasonably effective. But why are we in this position, where we are urging and not directing the airlines? We are in such a position because of the nature of the two airlines agreement. Who voted for that agreement when it came into this House, and who voted against it? Those who voted for it include the Opposition spokesman on tourism. Those who voted against it include both myself and our spokesman on tourism.

I do not make a point of criticism of the operations of the Independent Air Fares Committee. It was one of the initiatives of the Government in that package of legislation which I thought had a great deal to recommend it. But when Opposition spokesmen decide to perambulate around cities criticising our tourism policy, alleging that there is a power in the hands of the Government that does not exist, I should be grateful if they have a degree of embarrassment about doing that, recognising the circumstances that place us in a position not to direct but only to advise and to cajole. It is a situation which was created entirely and, in this instance, given the Opposition spokesman's membership of the previous Parliament, personally by himself and his colleagues.

Within the framework of what honourable members opposite left us to do on this matter, we have been very successful. I am grateful for the airlines' co- operation and their willingness to consider the propositions that have been put to them by, in particular, the Minister for Sport, Recreation and Tourism and by myself. They have addressed in such a timely fashion some of the problems that are being experienced with air travel by our tourism industry. I hope that they will continue to do that. I do not think that either of us is fully satisfied with the operation of discount fares in Australia, but we must acknowledge that the airlines have addressed themselves to this problem in a very systematic way. The progress has been good to date-no thanks at all to any of the Opposition spokesmen on this matter.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is the Deputy Prime Minister and Minister for Trade confident that the assurances given to him, the Prime Minister and the Minister for Foreign Affairs that Australia will maintain its share of the Japanese beef market and that Australia would not be disadvantaged as a result of the recent negotiations by the United States to gain a greater share of that market will in fact be honoured by Japan?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Bowen The Hon L.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —There is continual worry about the question of whether there can be an increase in the sale of beef as against maintaining the market share with Japan. The honourable gentleman would know, from his time in office in the period of dealing with Japan and selling beef, that the share of the market fell from 78 per cent to 70 per cent. In other words, during the honourable gentleman 's term of office there was a decline in the share of 8 per cent. Nevertheless, looking at the specifics of volume and the question of tonnage, it is found that the tonnage rose. So, whilst one can get an increase of beef into Japan, at the same time one can, as the honourable gentleman's experience showed, also lose one's market share, for this reason.

ANSWER.PARA: Over a period, the Japanese have been negotiating with the Americans for a different type of beef-namely, grain-fed beef. The problem that the Australian producer has had has been trying to convince the Japanese authorities that Australia's grass-fed beef, its high quality beef, is as good as grain-fed beef. But it certainly does not meet that classification pursuant to quota. Accordingly, because the Japanese have been expanding their quota over and above the initial quota for what they call grain-fed beef, it has been impossible for the Australian producer to tender for that quality beef. That is the present problem we face. It appears that the Japanese are about to announce an increased quota in grain-fed beef. That, of course, will give an advantage to the United States of America. It will allow us to get some additional access but in the process we will not get 70 per cent, which is what we would need to hold our market share. We are very concerned about that matter.

My colleague the Minister for Primary Industry and I have had discussions with the Japanese Ambassador on this issue. He said at the time, and we accept it as being right, that that was purely a matter of speculation in the Japanese Press. Nevertheless, the history of events from the time of the previous Government over a period of years shows that there is a tendency for the Japanese to encourage more grain-fed access than grass-fed access. Our attitude is that we should suggest to the Japanese that they deal with us on a fair and proper basis and that if there is to be an additional quota for the grain-fed beef they should allow the same percentage increase in the grass-fed quota so that we could at least tender for it.

The honourable gentleman's question had a lot of veracity in the sense that I am not confident that the Japanese for the first time will now behave differently from the way in which they behaved in the time when honourable members opposite were in government. I think the tendency will still be to lean towards the pressure that comes from the United States market. The difficulty we face lies in convincing the Japanese that, having lost 8 per cent or more of the market, we are anxious to maintain the reduced market share of 70 per cent that we now have. The Japanese argue that we are getting more access anyway and we are able to sell more beef. That is the difficulty that we face. We do not accept it. As I said, we have already made representations to the Japanese Ambassador. Officials of my Department are in the process of going back to Japan to have immediate discussions as to whether that is the position and, if it is, why it should not be changed to guarantee that we can at least maintain our market share.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thought the Prime Minister said everything was all right.
—Everything is all right, but we are talking about beef-
—It is not all right.

—I know that the right honourable gentleman has a particular problem because he produces it. But the issue at the moment is that of the Japanese market, the Japanese consumer being always convinced by the Government authorities that the better beef to buy is the grain-fed one, when in our view, from the experience of our own producers, our high quality beef is as good as, if not better than, that being allowed into Japan. That is the argument. It is a question of the quality of beef.
—You are putting the pressure on then?

—Yes, we are putting the pressure on. If that were all that mattered we would be happy. Honourable members opposite may think that pressure is the thing that counts, but it did not count in their case, because we lost 8 per cent of the market in their period in office. There is no need to look surprised about it. The fact is that that happened. The point that honourable members opposite have to realise is that the Japanese consumer allegedly is expressing a preference for grain-fed beef as against grass-fed beef. That is a consumer's choice, if you like. All we want is the chance to compete in that market, to have access in the same quantities that are now being allowed. For example, if the Japanese are to allow another 6,500 tonnes of grain-fed beef to be imported we would like to say: 'Don't classify it as grain-fed, call it high quality beef, give us 70 per cent of the market and see whether the customer would not approve of it'.

—Can the Treasurer indicate the effect on the equity of the tax system of the Senate's rejection last night of the Government's legislation against superannuation tax avoidance schemes known as cherry picking or tontines ?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Keating The Hon P.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Opposition in the Senate was at it again last night doing its usual number, which is protecting the tax avoidance industry. Yesterday the combined Opposition-the Liberal Party of Australia, the National Party of Australia, three Australian Democrats and Senator Harradine-joined together to defeat an element of the Income Tax Assessment Amendment Bill (No. 5) 1983, the measure which relates to the cherry picking schemes. That is the description of those schemes whereby the tax benefits which accrue in a superannuation fund for the benefit of the employees of that fund are taken away from, ripped off from, that fund by unscrupulous employers who either dismiss the employee or have his or her employment terminated before the benefit can become payable because the schemes are not subject to vesting.

ANSWER.PARA: Yesterday we again heard all the phoney excuses about why the Liberals and Senator Harradine in particular could not support the measures. The Liberals said that they were not blatant enough-that was their fall back position-and Senator Harradine tried to claim that the Australian Taxation Office would be ripping off money that should have gone to the employees. The fact is that these measures were always illegal. They operate in contravention of the rules of the superannuation funds by which the Commissioner of Taxation approves that benefits should accrue. Therefore, the only recourse left to the Commissioner was to wind up the funds after the rip off had taken place. Of course, there was no point in winding up the funds after the event. So now, as a result of last night's little performance in the Senate by the colleagues of the former Treasurer, we now have no Bill, no legislation, in respect not only of retrospectivity but also of prospectivity relating to these superannuation schemes.

Let me make it clear that when the Bill returns to the House of Representatives it will of course have in it other elements which the Government thinks it is important to have carried into law. Therefore, we will accept it with the amendment which the Senate has introduced, but we will then introduce another Bill, again containing that express provision. We will send that to the Senate and let Senator Harradine, if he must, trot out his argument again and let the Opposition face even greater scrutiny by the public and the Government as to why it believes that employers ought to be able to take the advantages of the tax system which were there for the benefit of employees and, by unscrupulous behaviour such as dismissing employees or terminating their employment before they are liable for a benefit, take those tax exempt benefits back into their own companies.

The scheme is blatant. I referred in the House of Representatives debate to the judgment by Mr Justice Wootten in a case in New South Wales in which he referred in the most extravagant terms to the blatant quality of the scheme. Despite that , we find that the Liberals suggest that it is not blatant enough, they will not have a bar of the retrospectivity. Not only that, when the retrospectivity measure was carried last night, they decided to vote against the whole provision so that there is now no law, retrospective or prospective, in relation to these schemes. So we will accept the amendments, but we will be back with another Bill . We will put the focus back on members of the Opposition again for what they are-protectors and apologists for the tax avoidance industry.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Treasurer. It is supplementary to the question asked earlier of the Prime Minister regarding the Budget deficit. Does the honourable gentleman recall the Prime Minister saying in New York on 16 June 1983 that a tax reduction given at the cost of a higher deficit would be of no value because of the inflationary and adverse growth consequences of that higher deficit? Will the honourable gentleman assure the House that the same approach will guide the Government's framing of this year's Budget, or has enough time elapsed since that earlier statement for the Government to feel able to repudiate it?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Keating The Hon P.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —That statement was made because of the disastrous fiscal inheritance left to us by the former Treasurer. He keeps coming back to the scene of the crime. He cannot stay away from the $9.6 billion deficit. It rankles him that he took off the award of champion liar for 1983 with the $9.6 billion deficit.
—Order! I ask the Treasurer to withdraw that remark. It is not parliamentary.

—I withdraw it, Mr Speaker. There was a massive deception of the public that there was indeed to be a $6 billion Budget deficit in prospect, whereas we found it to be $9.6 billion. The Prime Minister said in the course of the election campaign, on the Wednesday prior to the election, that if there were a greater level of fiscal deterioration than we believed in the course of the campaign we would have to review the question of a tax cut. It would have been, quite obviously in my terms and, I think, in the Prime Minister's and the Government's terms, irresponsible to have pushed the deficit out beyond those limits in 1983-84.

ANSWER.PARA: What is quite obvious in contrast to that is that in 1984-85, with the tremendous level of growth which is now moving through the economy and the income surge which will flow from that, the cyclical element of the deficit will respond to that growth. Of course we will not be facing a financing task in 1984 -85 in any way akin-

TALK.START.PARA: —So the prospective deficit is not too bad.

—Look, George, you have trouble balancing your own cheque book; don't talk about the Budget. The fact is that in 1984-85 we will not have a financing task the size of which we had in 1983-84. Not only was there a large deficit for policy reasons and because of the fiscal inheritence but also there was the massive level of capital inflow to which the Government had to attend in the course of the operation of its monetary policy. Quite obviously that bond- selling program will not be a feature of 1984-85.Part of the cyclical wind back in terms of the revenue will come to some extent from fiscal creep. That is not a description of the former Treasurer; it is a function of inflation on the tax system. Naturally, as incomes are inflated through the scales the revenue yield- -
—Mr Speaker, can I have some protection from the clowns on the front bench opposite?
—I ask the Treasurer not to invite interjections. As I indicated before, the level of noise is far too high and I will have to take action shortly.

—Some of that increase in revenue obviously will occur because of the inflation of income. I assume that the basis of the question by the former Treasurer is the suggestion that the Government stick to every dollar of bracket creep, fiscal drag, call it what you like; therefore, if we did we would have a net contraction in activity in the economy. Indeed if he is echoing the sorts of sentiments which have been echoed recently by others, of foolishly low Budget deficits, what we will have is a tremendous contraction of demand in the economy , which this Government will have no bar of. For that reason we do not accept the premise of the question.

ANSWER.PARA: It is interesting that the former Treasurer is extolling the virtues of a lower Budget deficit at the expense of tax cuts while the Leader of the Opposition has been running around the country urging the Government to reduce taxes, dragging out his handkerchief for the crocodile tears being shed about the inflation of average weekly earnings into the 46 per cent bracket. Members of the Opposition should get their story straight. Either they believe in a tax cut or they do not . The Leader of the Opposition believes in a tax cut. The former Treasurer believes that there should be no tax cut but a lower deficit. Quite obviously members of the Opposition do not have any idea on fiscal policy, monetary policy , incomes policy or exchange rate policy. As the Prime Minister said earlier, we will be bringing down the Budget deficit and looking at the question of tax relief consistent with the budgetary flexibility available to us for a good outcome for growth in the economy in 1984-85. That is why we will be leaving the Opposition where it is now, firmly entrenched in opposition.

TALK.START.PARA: —Can the Minister representing the Minister for Industry and Commerce inform the House of the details of the Government's recent changes to the Australian Manufacturing Council and the Government's action to form specific industry councils? In particular can the Minister explain the role which these councils will play in the development of the industry policy of the Government?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Brown The Hon J.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is true that the Minister for Industry and Commerce announced on Monday the formation of a new Manufacturing Council and 10 associated industry councils. Given the crisis that exists in the manufacturing industry in Australia after seven years of mismanagement by the alleged economic geniuses on the other side of the House, the need was absolutely imperative.

ANSWER.PARA: In launching this new arrangement the Minister, Senator Button, spoke about this being the last chance for manufacturing industry in Australia. I think those words should be taken to heart by everybody who has an interest-I presume that is everybody in this House-in the future of manufacturing industry in Australia. This is the last chance for manufacturing industry to understand the ills that presently prevail. Because it had lost its competitive edge and it had not come to grips with technological change, the work force in manufacturing industry was declining and, as manufacturing industry is so important to Australia, something needed to be done. Who better to do it than the Minister for Industry and Commerce, Senator Button?

Honourable members should all recall with some pleasure exactly what the honourable senator was able to do in formulating the steel plan. This is exactly what is required in manufacturing industry, to drag together all the disparate threads of this very important industry. I think it was a watershed for industry in Australia to find a government able to drag together industry, unions and the Government to form a plan that would revitalise the steel industry. The same will now happen in manufacturing industry generally.

The Minister, in announcing the formation of the Manufacturing Council, referred to the previous Manufacturing Council as a wailing wall and a monumental irrelevancy. How right he was. The previous Manufacturing Council was really only a club where the investors could come along and complain about the lack of profitability. Never once did they consider that there were a lot of elements in manufacturing industry that needed uniting. I guess that has been the abiding influence of this Government. We have united Australia and we will do it to the manufacturing industry. The new Council will be much different from the last one. I will explain why to honourable members opposite if they will just listen. The objectives will be very simple: Firstly, to prepare some advice on manufacturing policy for the Government to promote increased co-operation among all elements of the manufacturing sector and to develop and help industry to implement solutions to major problems.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Speaker, I take a point of order. Surely the Minister is presenting a statement of government policy which could be done better at another time.

—It is very obvious that honourable members on the other side, after all their years of mismanagement, have no concern about the fact that an extraordinary number of Australians will gain employment from the manufacturing industry that they sought to destroy. What they should do is accept some responsibility for it.
—Go and ask Laurie Carmichael.

—As for the honourable member for Denison interjecting about Laurie Carmichael, there is much more chance of Laurie Carmichael having some sort of good effect upon the promotion of jobs in Australia than the honourable member will ever have, with his constrained mentality.

ANSWER.PARA: The Chairman of the new Council will be Mr John Ralph, a very distinguished Australian, who is the Chairman of Conzinc Riotinto of Australia and many other important companies. But what is important is that the Deputy Chairman will be Mr Fred Peterson from the Clothing and Allied Trade Union of Australia. Well may Opposition members laugh. That is the basis of their failure in government, the failure to realise that in any industry, be it manufacturing or other, there is not only one player; there are not only investors and management but also the unions and all the consumers to be concerned with. That was the abiding failure of the previous Government; it never took that into account.

This Manufacturing Council will work because all of the components of that industry will have some say in how it works. There will be 10 industry councils consisting of a whole range of sections of the manufacturing industry. One of them will be chaired by Laurie Carmichael.

TALK.START.PARA: —Comrade!

—The honourable member might refer to me as comrade. He does not even know what comrade means. He should look it up in the dictionary occasionally and he will find that it is not such an insulting term. The efforts of the Minister for Industry and Commerce not only in the steel industry but also in the manufacturing industry generally will be lauded with the effluxion of time because this very important part of Australian industry is in the depths of despair. But shortly it will be exactly as the steel industry is now a very short term after the steel plan came into operation and will be, once again, a profitable adornment to the Australian scene and a vehicle for great improvement in the Australian employment area.

—My question is addressed to the honourable member for Mackellar with regard to the notice he has given of his intention to present a Bill for an Act to amend health legislation. Can the honourable member advise when his Bill is to be introduced into this House?
—Thank you, Mr Speaker-
—This will be the best answer we have received all day.
—Mr Speaker, I raise a point of order.
—Do you want the standing order, Mick?
—I cannot speak while there are interjections.
—Order! I invite the honourable member not to speak while there are interjections. When the House comes to order, I will take the Minister's point of order.
—The honourable member for Mackellar is not in charge of the order of business for this Parliament. I draw your attention to previous decisions given from the chair about questions of this nature.

—Order! There is no point of order. The practice of the House is that questions may be asked of a member who is introducing a private member's Bill. They may not, however, presume that there is a second reading debate on that Bill. They may only ask questions such as whether it is likely to be introduced, when it is likely to be introduced, whether it is drafted and whether a copy is available. So the area on which he has questioned the honourable member is very restricted. I call the honourable member for Mackellar.

—Thank you, Mr Speaker. I thank the honourable member for Cook for his timely question. He is referring to the Bill I tried to introduce yesterday into the House which would have had the effect of removing-
—Mr Speaker, I raise a point of order. The question is: When will the Bill be introduced?
—Yes. I am waiting to hear the honourable member's answer.
—Mr Speaker, my remarks are made only to the timing of this matter.
—Your remarks will only be allowed to be made on the timing of the matter.
—I understand fully. The honourable member for Cook is referring to the Bill I tried to introduce yesterday which would have had the effect of removing the objectionable section 17-
—Order! The honourable member will resume his seat. He is defying the ruling of the Chair. I call the honourable member for Petrie.
—Order! I call the honourable member for Petrie.
—Order! The House will come to order.
—Mr Speaker, I rise to take a point of order. The honourable member for Mackellar is entitled to refer to the Bill and to answer the question that has been put to him.
—He is entitled to refer to the Bill. He is not entitled to refer to the causes for the Bill being introduced. That is exactly what the honourable member-
—Mr Speaker, he is entitled to refer to the Bill and the Bill is the matter of the question. The question was put to him with respect to identifying that which was before the House.
—Order!
—How can he possibly respond unless he can identify the Bill?

—Order! The right honourable gentleman should read the House of Representatives Practice. The possibility of a member answering such a question is restricted. He is not entitled to put argument for the Bill into his answer. On those grounds, because the honourable member was discussing the reasons why the Bill was introduced-that is part of the argument-he is out of order.

—Mr Speaker, I raise a point of order. The question related to the introduction of the Bill. The words that the honourable member used in the introduction to his answer related to the introduction of the Bill and his endeavours yesterday to introduce it into the House. That is covered by the Standing Orders and, with great respect, you are wrong in your ruling today.

—With great respect, I am not wrong in my ruling. The practice in this matter is quite clear. If the answer to the question causes the member to enter into the reasons for the Bill, presupposing debate on the Bill, he is out of order. It is quite clear that the matter is restricted to whether the Bill will be introduced, whether the Bill has been drafted or whether the questioner could see a copy of the Bill. These are the sorts of questions which would be in order.
—Mr Speaker, I take a point of order. May I refer to that aspect? I was trying very carefully to remain within those rules which I had read beforehand.
—I can assure the honourable member that he was not.
—I assure you, Mr Speaker, that I wish to give the honourable member for Cook a proper answer and will, if allowed by you--

—Mr Speaker, I take a point of order. There is no doubt that your ruling was quite correct. The honourable member for Mackellar started his answer by saying that 'the effect of the Bill will be'. They were his first words. You are entirely correct, Mr Speaker.
—There is no point of order. I have given a ruling.
—If the honourable member for Mackellar wants to put his answer in order, let the honourable member for Cook ask the question again tomorrow.

—On the point of order, Mr Speaker, you will recall that in answer to a question put the year before last by the honourable member for Lilley a very similar matter was canvassed by the House. In exactly the same manner as my colleague now seeks to respond, a member of the then Opposition was asked to give a response which related exactly to the timing of introduction and conveyed the general area of the Bill before the House. I submit that this matter is exactly in accordance with that--
—Order! I have made my ruling. I intend to proceed.
—This is an absolute--
—Order! I call the Prime Minister.
—Mr Speaker, I ask that further questions be placed on notice.

—I still take a point of order, whether we move on to another element of the business or not, because I submit to you that standing order 143 is rendered nebulous or negated by your very ruling today. Now either questions--
—Order!
—can be addressed--
—Order!
—I am speaking--
—Order!
—You can call 'Order!'--

—You can do what you like. I do not intend to have the ruling of the Chair defied. We will go on with the business. You will sit down or you will have to take other action. I call on the presentation of papers.
—Are you taking the point of order, Mr Speaker?
—No, I am not taking the point of order. That matter is finalised.
—Okay, let's get out of here.
—Order! Presentation of papers--
—I call the Minister for Trade.
—Mr Speaker, I move dissent from your ruling.
—The Leader of the Opposition has moved dissent from my ruling. He must submit his motion in writing.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Peacock The Hon A.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Speaker, I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Speaker's ruling be dissented from.

I will put my motion in writing as I speak to you, Mr Speaker. I have moved dissent from your ruling for two reasons. The first reason is that by indicating to the honourable member for Mackellar (Mr Carlton) that he was in breach of the Standing Orders you effectively negated the question which was put to him quite legitimately under standing order 143. I will read that standing order to honourable members. Standing order 143 provides:

Questions may be put to a Member, not being a Minister or an Assistant Minister , relating to any bill, motion or other public matter connected with the business of the House, of which the Member has charge.

That standing order has been interpreted by successive Speakers to mean that a question can be put to the member concerned relating to the introduction or the timing, et cetera, that you, Mr Speaker, referred to when you were answering the point of order taken by the honourable member for Port Adelaide (Mr Young), the Special Minister of State, indicating that he was unaware of the standing order and seeking to prevent the honourable member for Cook (Mr Dobie) from asking his question.

I submit to honourable members that there is no way in which the honourable member breached that standing order in the short time that he was at this despatch box. The honourable member's remarks related solely to the endeavours to introduce a Bill which is, of course, of the greatest import to the people of this nation. He had not sought to debate it in any way whatsoever. He sought to relate the question to the timing of that Bill. Mr Speaker, you then sat him down. I then sought to take a point of order concerning you to indicate that by ruling in the manner in which you had you were, by precedent, preventing any question henceforth being put to the honourable member for Mackellar, or any other member who wanted to introduce a private member's Bill.

Mr Speaker, with great respect, your job is to ensure that these Standing Orders provide protection for every member of this Parliament. Mr Speaker, you are here not to serve honourable members on your right hand side; you are here to serve the entire Parliament and by that, abide by the Standing Orders. There is a standing order that specifically provides for the sort of question asked by the honourable member for Cook, which had hardly been answered by the honourable member for Mackellar before he was ruled out of order. To rule me out of order for even drawing attention to this standing order is to make an absolute mockery of the Standing Orders and the conduct of this House. Either honourable members on my side of the House are able to draw attention to matters contained within the Standing Orders or they are not. Either they are able to utilise the Standing Orders that give them the opportunity to seek information formally in this House, or they are not. Mr Speaker, they are two matters you have to face.

That I move this motion of no confidence is regrettable but I believe not only did you deny my colleague the honourable member for Mackellar the opportunity of answering his question but also you denied me the opportunity of putting my point of order in relation to standing order 143. The tragedy is that it has been the tendency of Speakers when giving rulings in this place to adopt the stance of the jurist and regard such a ruling as a precedent. I am not going to allow my colleagues to be ridden over in this way simply because this blabbermouth, the Special Minister of State, gets up and seeks to have the honourable member for Mackellar prevented from answering a question. I hazard the view that had the Special Minister of State not sought to prevent the honourable member for Mackellar from answering his question you, Mr Speaker, would not have ruled in the manner in which you did. I gained the impression, from the moment the Special Minister of State took his point of order and you, Mr Speaker, pointed out what the standing order was, you sought nevertheless to deny my colleague the right to answer the question. You definitely denied me the opportunity of raising a point of order. I will not delay the House any more other than to say that if this is a precedent for the further conduct of questions that are legitimately asked under this standing order you, Mr Speaker, are effectively negating that standing order.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Speaker, I raise a point of order. Could the House know whether the Leader of the Opposition has moved a motion of dissent or a motion of no confidence?
—It is a motion of dissent from the ruling.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sinclair The Rt Hon I.McC.

TALKER.NAME: Mr SINCLAIR
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Speaker, I second the motion of my colleague the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Peacock) in moving dissent from your ruling. There is no more sacred right in this place than the opportunity for private members to ask questions without notice in accordance with the Standing Orders. The responsibility for interpreting the Standing Orders, in spite of the incipient creeps which we have just heard about, is to be determined by the arbitration which you, as Speaker of this place, exercise. The manner and form by which these questions are asked are laid down not only within the Standing Orders but also within Pettifer's House of Representatives Practice. I draw the attention of honourable gentlemen and you, sir, to the application of standing order 143 in accordance with Pettifer's Parliamentary Practice as it is stated at pages 483 and 484.

SPEECH.PARA: In particular, Mr Speaker, I draw your attention to the substance of the explanation on page 484, where it is said:
Questions most often allowed have concerned private Members' bills listed as notices on the Notice Paper.
Mr Speaker, of course that is a question which you properly allowed. The passage continues:
However, if the answer to such a question would require the Member to anticipate what he might say in his second reading speech, the question is anticipating debate and is therefore out of order.

Mr Speaker, I put it to you that there was nothing in what my colleague said that in any way canvassed the matter that he would put to this House in the second reading speech. What he was doing, at the time when you brought his answer to a close was identifying the Bill so that he could explain the reason why he believed it was essential that it should be introduced at the earliest possible time. We all know that it is important that when a member of this place introduces, as a representative of his constituents, a measure which seeks to draw to an end the first ever strike by medical practitioners in this country-a Bill which is directed to enabling this Government properly to introduce a Medicare proposal taking into account the rights of private patients-that is a matter which certainly should be answered in a question of the order of that asked by the honourable member for Cook (Mr Dobie) of the honourable member for Mackellar (Mr Carlton).

It is imperative that the rights of a private member answering a question in accordance with standing order 143 be protected by you, as the occupant of the chair. It is an area where obviously the honourable member, in responding to the question, needs to be able to refer to the Bill that he sought to introduce yesterday. The question did not in any way require him to canvass his second reading speech. It was necessary for him to identify the reason for urgency of the Bill, the character of the Bill, and hence to give an answer to the question . The question asked when the Bill was to be introduced. Why was it necessary for him to state that? It was necessary because there is at the moment a first ever strike by medical practitioners because this Government and the Minister for Health (Dr Blewett) have made such a mess of their introduction of a scheme which at the moment is causing every taxpayer in Australia to pay a levy of one per cent of his income without the scheme being there. The Bill relates to the setting up of circumstances whereby that problem can be rectified.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Speaker, I rise on a point of order. The Leader of the National Party is out of order. He is not debating the reasons for the motion of dissent. He is attempting in this issue to debate--
—Order! There is no point of order.

—Mr Speaker, I think the point of it all is best illustrated by the precedent at page 625 of the House of Representatives Hansard. Mr Speaker, you have of course, in the exercise of your function, to bear in mind precedents set by those who have sat in the chair before you. I draw your attention to House of Representatives Hansard of 16 March 1976 and a question asked by the then Leader of the Opposition, Mr E.G. Whitlam. Pursuant to standing order 143 he asked the honourable member for Port Adelaide (Mr Young)-who coincidentally happens to be the Leader of the House-a question relating to his notice of motion for General Business Thursday No. 1. Without repeating the question, I note that it did relate to a Bill introduced by the honourable gentleman concerning an electoral Bill of which he had given notice for the next General Business day. It is interesting if we read the debate to note the points of order taken by Mr Whitlam following the definition by then Speaker Snedden with respect to the terms of questions that might be asked. Mr Whitlam said, at page 626:

SPEECH.PARA: Mr Speaker, may I ask the honourable gentleman whether the Bill as he is drafting it will cover the public disclosure of funds available to political parties and candidates from trust funds established overseas?

TALK.START.PARA: —I call the honourable member for Port Adelaide.
—The proposed section of the legislation will be identical with that introduced--
—Order! The honourable gentleman is now anticipating the debate.
—Perhaps I could just give the House an incident that would be covered- -
—No, the honourable gentleman is not entitled to give an instance.
—Of course, all donations and all funds, set up in any manner, from which a candidate or political party would receive a donation would be covered by the proposed legislation.

SPEECH.PARA: Mr Speaker, what the now Leader of the House, the then honourable member for Port Adelaide in opposition, was doing was responding to an even greater degree than the honourable member for Wentworth sought to do with respect to a Bill of which he gave notice yesterday. The Bill of which he gave notice yesterday needs to be identified in accordance with the question that was put to him by the honourable member for Cook. Mr Speaker, unless you are able to allow a member who has moved a motion relating to a private member's Bill to identify, as the now Leader of the House the then honourable member for Port Adelaide did, the Bill to which the question relates, it is quite impossible for standing order 143 to have effect. The reason why the Leader of the Opposition moved this motion of dissent, Mr Speaker, is that this is a fundamental area involving the rights of members of this Parliament. If you, as Speaker, deny a member the right to answer a perfectly proper question, as interpreted by Pettifer's House of Representatives Practice and as interpreted by your predecessors, no substance can be given to the Standing Orders of this place.

The Standing Orders of this place are designed to allow a member to introduce a private member's Bill and to give notice of that. In this instance my colleague sought to bring to the attention of the Parliament, in answer to a question regarding the timing of that Bill, the difficulties which face the medical profession, patients and taxpayers. The Bill is designed to relieve all the people in the constituency, for which the honourable member for Cook and indeed all of us are responsible, of a concern as to when the medical practitioners' strike will end and when it may be possible for proper negotiations to be entered into by the Minister for Health (Dr Blewett) with the medical practitioners. The difficulty in this matter arises because the Minister for Health has not properly set up the terms within which ordinary negotiations can take place.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The Leader of the National Party is now using this motion to go far beyond the question of dissent from my ruling.

—Mr Speaker, the point of it all is that in order to answer the honourable gentleman's question my colleague the honourable member for Mackellar sought to identify the terms of his private member's Bill. He was not anticipating a second reading debate but anticipating the circumstances of public concern which necessitated the introduction of his Bill at the earliest possible time. The character of his answer was not in any way anticipating the second reading debate. The character of his answer was to explain why the Bill had to be introduced at an early time. Mr Speaker, unless you are able to identify that Bill, as did the present honourable member for Port Adelaide who is now wearing another hat, it becomes quite impossible for standing order 143 to have any substance at all.

SPEECH.PARA: Mr Speaker, the reason for the Opposition moving a motion of dissent from your ruling is not because we believe that in most areas you have not exercised true impartiality in the exercise of your functions; it is because this is one of the fundamental rights of members of this Parliament. Standing order 143 gives the Opposition the only right to introduce legislation about matters of public concern. Standing order 143 was taken advantage of by the honourable member for Mackellar in order to introduce a piece of legislation to resolve a public difficulty caused by the Minister for Health and contributed to by every member of the Government. It is the only way that honourable members on this side of the House can find a way to resolve the present medical practitioners' dispute. It is only by introducing a Bill, such as that to which the honourable gentleman 's question relates, that there is a possibility of an early resolution of the difficulties between private practitioners and the Government. It is only by replying to questions relating to that Bill that the honourable gentleman can give an answer to the honourable member for Cook.

Mr Speaker, I suggest that the ruling you have just given not only goes against the meaning of our Standing Orders, not only goes against the interpretation of the House of Representatives Practice as defined in the volume to which I have referred, but also goes against precedents which have been laid down even as recently as 16 March 1976 by Mr Speaker Snedden relating to the present Leader of the House.

Mr Speaker, in all of those circumstances I submit that you were wrong in your ruling. It is essential that standing order 143 be interpreted in a proper form and that those on either side of the House who introduce a private member's Bill can properly identify it for answering a question relating to the time of its introduction. Unless that can be done, standing order 143 has no meaning and Government members are able to deny properly members of the Opposition exercising the function which the Standing Orders are directed, and were framed, to permit. I have no hesitation in suggesting that every member of this House, who genuinely seeks to represent the interests of his electorate, and genuinely wants to take advantage of the Standing Orders which were introduced to try to protect every member of the House, and every constituent, take note of the consequences of the ruling you have just made, Mr Speaker. It is essential that members of this place are able to respond properly by identifying such Bills and by giving an answer to questions asked of them. Mr Speaker, your ruling prevents that. I suggest the only recourse we have is to do as the Leader of the Opposition has just done and move a motion of dissent from your ruling. On the basis of that I suggest, Mr Speaker, that you reconsider precedents and reconsider Petiffer's House of Representatives Practice and accept that in this instance you have been wrong.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Young The Hon M.J.
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: SPECIAL MINISTER OF STATE; LEADER OF THE HOUSE

TALKER.NAME: Mr YOUNG
TALKER.ROLE: Special Minister of State and Leader of the House)

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Speaker, I, on behalf of the Government, enthusiastically and energetically support your ruling. It is pretty obvious that the Leader of the National Party (Mr Sinclair) has been a defendant much more than he has been a prosecutor, judging from the case he presented to the Parliament this afternoon. As the former Speaker has been drawn into the debate let me say this: The honourable member for Denison (Mr Hodgman) ran to the Library to see whether I had ever been able--
—And I found it.

—But like most things the honourable member does, he found only 50 per cent because I had been asked two questions. Some years ago we were rather amazed because the stupidity of the then Government allowed Mr Bungey the right to ask me a question as the member who had introduced a Bill on electoral reform . The Speaker at the time allowed me to answer it in full.
—Precisely; that is two precedents.

—The honourable member should wait just a minute. As the then Opposition was rather amazed at the Speaker's ruling in allowing me to answer the question we decided to try it again. We were not quite so successful the next time, because by then the Speaker had ruled that the Parliament would get out of hand if members of the Opposition were able to introduce unknown numbers of Bills and then ask each other questions about it. So, he decided that he would put a clamp on the practice. However, something of equal importance which history will have to judge is: Who was the smarter person; me or Sir Billy Snedden? I got away with a little bit and Sir Billy let it go.

SPEECH.PARA: The other matter that I think we should take into account is the parting speech of Sir Billy. He said he did not want to be here to influence the present Speaker. He left the Parliament so that this Speaker would not be influenced by precedents which may have been set by him. I do not know whether Sir Billy Snedden was part of the scheme whereby I was asked a question when I was a shadow Minister responsible for electoral reform. Certainly in the first instance which has not been referred to by the Opposition today I was allowed to give a very full answer and that is why the then Opposition tried to do it again , but that time we were not so successful. Of course, the Parliament has learnt a lot since then. The Government does not challenge at all the right, as the Standing Orders provide, for the honourable member for Cook (Mr Dobie) to direct his question today to the honourable member for Mackellar. However, we on this side of the House do know the tactics.

TALK.START.PARA: —You took a point of order to it.

—I took a point of order and the Speaker ruled there was no point of order. I accepted that. The Opposition wants to know when the Bill will be introduced; it will be introduced next time it wins government, which is a long time away.

SPEECH.PARA: So I accepted the Speaker's first ruling about the order of business. But I did not accept that the honourable member for Mackellar, the shadow Minister for Health, could then start to proceed into debate. There was no doubt as to the tactic of the Opposition. There was no reason for us to disbelieve that the question just happened to be asked three minutes before the end of Question Time so that 10 or 15 minutes could be taken up by the shadow Minister for Health telling us all about what should have been his second reading speech.

The Leader of the National Party of Australia reads through House of Representatives Practice, but the emphasis should be on the description of what is allowed in the House of Representatives. House of Representatives Practice states:
Questions most often allowed have concerned private Members' bills listed as notices on the Notice Paper.
We accepted that when the Speaker ruled so today. It continues:

However, if the answer to such a question would require the honourable member to anticipate what he might say in his second reading speech, the question is anticipating debate and is therefore out of order.

The first words spoken by the honourable member for Mackellar were something about a clause 17. He was going to go on to tell us about the impact of the Bill . If that is not anticipating debate, back to all the campuses for all honourable members opposite. They will all have to do a bit of study on what is debate. That was the tactic being adopted by the Opposition today. Our good friend the honourable member for Cook has a big grin on his face. He knew what it was all about. He is thinking: 'I wish we could have got away with it, but we will have to think up another tactic'. We are not going to allow our Speaker to be embarrassed in the manner--
Opposition members interjecting-

TALK.START.PARA: —I warn the honourable member for Denison.

—Mr Speaker, I take a point of order. I suggest that it is a reflection on the Chair to use an expression such as 'our Speaker', that you are accepting a subjugation to one side of this place. It is totally against the precepts of the high office which you hold and I suggest that the honourable gentleman be asked to withdraw that inference.

—I believe that any member of the Parliament can refer to me as 'our Speaker'. If the right honourable member wishes to make inferences from it, I cannot stop him. He will do so whether or not it is said by members of this House. I call the Leader of the House.

—Mr Speaker, this is a day of good rulings. Of course I was speaking for the whole House; who thought otherwise? How else could one refer to such an esteemed person but as 'our Speaker'? I referred to the honourable member for Kooyong as our Leader of the Opposition.
—I invite the Leader of the House to continue with the debate.
—The only bloke I will not take on board is the Leader of the National Party.
—You think you are in the soup.

—Order! The honourable member for Denison will not be in it in a moment. I make an appeal to the House. It is a difficult situation for a Speaker when a motion of dissent from his ruling has been moved. It makes it very difficult to control the behaviour of the House at that stage. I think that out of respect for the office, if not me, some silence should be observed during this debate. I call the Leader of the House.

—Mr Speaker, no one in this Parliament could take a question such as this as seriously as those of us on this side of the House who had to sit opposite for seven years. People in this House will understand that if a procedure being pushed by the Opposition were to become practice in this House of Representatives the Opposition would become almost totally in charge of the business of the House. Obviously the people of Australia have decided that the Government should be made up of Australian Labor Party members. We are in charge of the business of the House. The Standing Orders, which are laid down and carried out by each respectively elected Speaker, are there to see that government programs can be carried out while taking into account specific purposes for private members' activities, whether they concern grievances, private members' Bills, Question Time, the adjournment debate or whatever else it may be.

SPEECH.PARA: All these things have been sorted out. While they are looked at from time to time there are certain rights in the House for individual members. There may not be enough. That might be an argument that has been held in this Parliament since Federation. It may be an argument which will go on. I am sure that a lot of frustration is felt in this House by many honourable members when they serve in Opposition about the way they think they are participating in the government of Australia. But one cannot do it in the way the Opposition attempted to do it today.

The sad thing about this exercise is that when the Opposition was caught out it had to move dissent from the ruling of the Speaker, who is entirely right on this question. There can be no doubt that once the shadow Minister for Health started talking about clause 17 and the impact of the Bill he was moving to an area to anticipate debate. That is what the gimmick today was all about. The Opposition anticipated using the last 10 or 15 minutes of Question Time to employ that tactic. Then, of course the Opposition moved dissent. It should not do that so lightly because it knows that it is going to be knocked over on a question such as this. But the Opposition did so in order that the speakers moving dissent-the mover and seconder-could then take on board the argument about Medicare. As the Leader of the National Party said today: 'All we are trying to do today is to protect all the patients throughout Australia wherever they may be'. So he gets his words in about what he is trying to do. He gets his five or 10 minutes worth. Eventually Opposition members are able to use this tactic. It might mean that further on down the track today, they will lose some other business, but we will just have to look at that in terms of the timetable.

I have always found when I sat on the other side of the House and watched the Leader of the House that one of the great talents of the Leader of the National Party was that role. There is no doubt that one of the great leaders of this House since Federation has been the present Leader of the National Party when he was in government. I have learnt a lot from him. But it has only been from practices in the House. From the experience I had in regard to the questions that were asked of me as the shadow Minister for electoral reform, had this tactic been attempted after those occasions in this House, I have absolutely no doubt what the ruling of Sir Billy Snedden would have been. I entirely concur with the ruling that you have given today, Mr Speaker. It is entirely within the proper practice of this House. I move:
That the question be now put.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Mr SPEAKER

TALK.START.PARA: —In accordance with precedent, I will respond to the motion of dissent before proposing the question that the question be now put. I respond because I take the Standing Orders very seriously. Until the debate started I was uncertain what ruling was being dissented from. I gather that the ruling that the answer of the honourable member for Mackellar was out of order is the ruling which is being dissented from. I use the two arguments that have been put before the House. I quote from page 484 of House of Representatives Practice:

INTERJECT.PARA: Questions most often allowed have concerned private Members' bills listed as notices on the Notice Paper. However, if the answer to such a question would require the Member to anticipate what he might say in his second reading speech, the question is anticipating debate and is therefore out of order. A question asking when the bill would be introduced, whether the bill has been drafted or whether the questioner could see a copy of the bill would be in order.

It was on those grounds that the question was asked. I will allow my ruling to rest on the Hansard record of what the honourable member for Mackellar said. I am sure that it will uphold the ruling I gave. I acknowledge that the Leader of the National Party has mentioned a precedent. It is a precedent with which, I must admit, the honourable member for Port Adelaide went a little further than I would have allowed him but where eventually Speaker Snedden said:
Order! The honourable gentleman is proceeding beyond the bounds of the Standing Orders. I ask the honourable gentleman to resume his seat.

This was in accordance with my ruling. I think I should respond to the question of points of order. I think honourable members would accept that I allowed a reasonable number of points of order on this matter in order to clarify it. Speakers, in practice in this Parliament and others, do place a limit on the number of points of order when they go beyond reason. That was why I refused to accept further points of order and why I tried to carry on with the business of the House, until the motion for dissent was moved. I rest on that statement. The question is:
That the question be now put.
That the Speaker's ruling be dissented from.

DIVISION.RESULT.PARA: Question so resolved in the negative.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-After the election of this Government 12 months ago, we addressed the question of how we should deal with lobbyists who seek to represent people, organisations and, in some cases, foreign governments which are aimed at influencing decisions and policies of the Government. Virtually unheard of at the beginning of the 1970s, lobbying has became a major profession in the national capital. The Government believed we had reached the stage where the relationship between Government and lobbyists should be placed on a more formal footing. Prior to dealing with the establishment of formal guidelines, the Government made it known that dealings with lobbyists would be conducted as individual Ministers saw fit, but recommended to Ministers that whenever possible meetings with lobbyists should take place with the principals present. The Government recognises that lobbyists are, in a complex society, an inevitable part of the democratic process and as a result the Government raised this issue in the Parliament last year. We held meetings with representatives of the Canberra lobbyists, the legal and accountancy professions and other interested parties and had submissions from the public.

SPEECH.PARA: On 6 December last year, following an initial round of discussions, the Government announced its intention to establish a register for lobbyists. The scheme encompasses two confidential registers maintained within the Department of the Special Minister of State. A special register, which covers lobbyists with clients who are foreign governments or their agencies was established immediately. A general register, covering lobbyists with other clients, commenced on 16 March this year. Persons currently affected by the scheme have until 30 March to register and beyond that date applications to register should be lodged as the need arises. Any lobbyist not registered under this scheme will not be granted access to Ministers or Departments. I table the guidelines that the Government has decided upon. Under the guidelines a lobbyist is defined as:
. . . A person (or company) who, for financial or other advantage, represents a client in dealings with Commonwealth Government Ministers and officials.
The scheme applies to specific activities of special concern to the Government, and covers representations-
(a) to make or amend legislation of the Commonwealth or Territories other than Northern Territory;
(b) to make or change Government guidelines or policies; and,
(c) to influence Government decisions on awarding contracts and tenders, or appointments to public office.

Further activities could be brought under the scheme if in the future the Government identified other matters of special concern. The guidelines will apply to anyone involved in these activities, including lawyers and accountants and tax, Customs and other agents. The scheme does not apply to appearances before boards, tribunals or other bodies which allow representation of clients. Also, it does not cover representations made directly to the Government by representative organisations, peak councils, professional associations and community interest groups. Information submitted by lobbyists about themselves and their clients will be handled confidentially. Access to the general and special registers will be on a carefully-controlled 'need to know' basis.
As the Government also announced in December last year, a complementary code of conduct for Ministers has been established in conjunction with the registration scheme. It requires-
that, as far as possible, Ministers follow the practice that lobbyists who make personal representations to them are accompanied by the principals they represent.

that Ministers seek to avoid granting special privileges, advantages or access to any lobbyist by virtue of that lobbyist's particular background; for example, as a former parliamentary representative or senior office holder or employee of a political party.

I would like to point out that the course of action the Government has taken is not unique. This issue has long been on the public agenda in the United States of America and various registration schemes for lobbyists have been developed at a Federal and State level in that country. These systems have met with varied success and the Government took into account the American experience when it was developing its own policy on this matter. The Government has made it clear that this registration procedure will apply only to people who, for financial gain, represent others in an effort to influence decisions, policies or laws. The registration does not apply to such peak organisations as the Australian Council of Trade Unions, the Confederation of Australian Industry, various other employee or employer organisations and such community groups as the Australian Council of Social Services and the Conservation Council of Australia.

Under our scheme there will no longer be a mystique about lobbyists. Their activities will be recognised and there will be no doubt about what lobbyists are seeking to achieve and upon whose interests they seek to operate. The Government believes that the scheme we have developed will be effective and adequately covers the concerns of all interested parties. The system of registration will continue to be monitored by the Government and we will be happy to receive comments from anyone interested in this legitimate area of public concern so that we can provide a reasonable and workable system.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hall Mr R.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-When Mr Speaker was summing up his position in relation to the recent motion of dissent from his ruling, he said in reference to the honourable member for Port Adelaide (Mr Young) that, in 1976, he got a little further than he should. If there has been one thing about the history of the honourable member for Port Adelaide, it has been that he always goes a little further than he should. In relation to this matter of the regulation of lobbyists, of course, he is utterly dominating the question and the matter of the Government's regulation in this affair, because it is his action that has made necessary, in the Government's eyes, this rather authoritarian treatment of those who deal with government. In fact, one would say that the honourable member for Port Adelaide almost does the impossible, of overshadowing himself in the matter of his ability to transgress against the proper conduct of his portfolio. When one looks at this statement one can only assume that the whole thing has been got together because of his previous action , which meant that he spent six months in exile because he sought a colleague out in a Canberra car park. But in looking at the statement, which I understand the Minister has prepared, one can see the humorist in him. There is no doubt that in his management of Government affairs in the House he demonstrates a great amount of humour, which at times is a very desirable attribute. I am not so sure, however, that it exonerates him from the position in which he put himself in 1983. I invite honourable members to study this document. In one paragraph the Minister says:

SPEECH.PARA: Prior to dealing with the establishment of formal guidelines, the Government made it known that dealings with lobbyists would be conducted as individual Ministers saw fit . . .

We know how the honourable member for Port Adelaide saw fit to deal on an individual basis with lobbyists. He came out of a meeting of the National and International Security Committee and sought out his lobbyist friend in a car park to leak to him matter of substantial importance to Australia's national security. He also said:
The Government believed we had reached the stage where the relationship between Government and lobbyists should be placed on a more formal footing.

Indeed, the Minister's example would have forced any government that contained such a Minister to look at a more formal footing for lobbyists. There can be no other conclusion because of his behaviour. He goes on in his statement to say:
. . . the Government raised this issue in the Parliament last year.

That is a complete understatement of the importance of that question and the pressure the Opposition put on him and the Government about the matter of dealing in an unauthorised way with national security secrets. He goes on further to indicate that information submitted by lobbyists about themselves and their clients will be handled confidentially. I put it to the House: Is this the Minister to make a serious statement about handling details of lobbyists on a confidential basis? If the Minister is willing to go to a car park to seek out a lobbyist friend and tell him of a matter of national security, how secure are the business details and the secrets of lobbyists in his hands in the form of a register which apparently he is to keep? He goes on to state further:
As the Government also announced in December last year, a complementary code of conduct for Ministers has been established in conjunction with the registration scheme.

He said that Ministers seek to avoid granting special privileges, advantages or access. It would seem that someone has sat down in the Minister's six months of exile and asked: 'If the honourable member for Port Adelaide ever gets back into Cabinet, how can we circumvent his ever repeating this matter of grave defection in relation to Cabinet security and committee security? How can we prevent him from transgressing again?' The action detailed in this report is aimed not at lobbyists but at a particular Minister. It is all clearly set out here. The Minister has been told by Cabinet, I suppose in the interests of his rehabilitation, to make sure that the finger will not again be pointed at the Government in relation to the leaking of important matters to lobbyists and therefore through to the community.

Worse than that, we know that the basis of this goes much more deeply into the internal workings of the Australia Labor Party. The matter in which the Minister was involved led to the public persecution-not the prosecution-of a previous Federal Secretary of the Labor Party. We all know of the use by the Government of tapes secretly taken of individuals' conversations which were volunteered and given to the media to publish. The action in those days rested basically on tapes. It is interesting to see the double standards of government. It is willing and has been willing to pursue the matter of those tapes and the subject matter in them to the degree that one of its previous most able colleagues has been denied his proper security of livelihood. The Government has been willing to use those tapes. One of the results of those tapes, apart from the appalling attack exhibited by the Government on an individual and one of its former colleagues, was to place a different value on tapes which have been mentioned in this House and publicly in relation to other matters, matters of great concern to the public and to the Parliament.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! Would the honourable member like to return to the statement?

—Yes I will, Madam Deputy Speaker. I do so in drawing to a close that comparison of the double standards which the Government exhibited in relation to tapes. All of those matters stand behind this authoritarian action which I have mentioned, which is for the first time to regulate lobbyists in their dealings with governments and to have their business details put on a register and be subject to circulation on a restricted basis among the ministry. In circulating that register, anyone knows--
—Not circulating; the need to know.

—Well, on demand. I take the Minister's point that it will be available on proper demand. With the register being circulated in that fashion on demand, it will inevitably be seen by people other than the Minister in the operation of the ministerial offices. That will mean that there will be an enormous interface of knowledge of the business clients, the clients of lobbyists, and obviously at times there will be some leakage. That in itself will present a hazard to anyone dealing with his client as a third party with the Government.

SPEECH.PARA: The whole object, of course, will fail because the regulation is aimed at those who earn their living as lobbyists. It is aimed not at those who lobby for themselves but at those who bring their own case to the various Ministers of government. What a distinction it is that people can be drafted into two pathways to the Government. A large company, the largest company in this land, with all sorts of reasons for dealing with the Government, as long as it sent an employee, would not have to be registered. However, a different situation would apply to a small outfit which could not afford to employ someone as a third party. That is an essential point in this argument. These people so often make their livelihood as third party representatives because the individuals who aggregate in their responsibility either are unable themselves to get their cases together, with their lack of knowledge of politics or the way in which government operates, or cannot afford to employ their own representatives.

TALK.START.PARA: —Then they go through their peak council. They go through the Confederation of Australian Industry.

—The Minister has interjected that the lobbyists should go through their peak councils. It is the Minister who is saying that they must go through their peak councils. It is the sort of attitude he exhibited in his defensive debate in this House. He says to the lobbyists: 'You must'. The lobbyists cannot make the decisions themselves. We are not only now regulating lobbyists; we are also saying to the people out there: 'You must'. This is the corollary of what is going on here. Not only does a lobbyist have to be regulated but also the Minister says: 'If you are a small manufacturer employing six people making pipes and you have to lobby the Government you must go through your peak council, whichever it is, or else you will go to a lobbyist who is tied hand and foot under these regulations'.

SPEECH.PARA: Madam Deputy Speaker, I feel that the Minister should take leave today. I do not suggest that he take leave for six months, only today. He might do better when he comes back tomorrow. He has already widened the implications of this regulation to an enormous degree. He believes that the lobbyists must be registered. Without pointing any personal fingers at him in that regard, it is a typical indication of a socialist government which sees authoritarian regulation as the answer to a problem. If we distil this, it is clear that he created a problem which he is now solving. In solving his own problem he is adopting the traditional response of governments that come from the Left.

We in the Opposition do not support this regulation. If there is to be regulation and if the Minister sees his colleagues and views his own future in relation to dealing with lobbyists with such uncertainty, I suggest that he turn back to the lobbying fraternity and do what is done in the only really successful country in this area-and that is not noted to be all that successful- the United Kingdom, and have some self-regulation. If the association of lobbyists in Australia or the various associations, if the lobbyists form them, have standards the Minister can assess them. He can then decide whether or not he will deal with them. That will be his business. But at least the industry would be self-regulating. That is the only way to go if we do not want to do what the Minister has said they must do-go through their peak councils. That would be their decision.

The Minister is at fault, and gravely at fault, in pursuing this matter, putting at risk not just the future livelihood of lobbyists but also the business secrets and details of their clients. That is something that this Parliament should not approve. I believe that the Minister is wrong in bringing this measure into the House in the form of a report which simply states that that has been done. He should have moved a substantive motion. A matter as important as this should have been brought in by manner of a Bill. This House could then have properly debated all the essential points and would have known far more of the Minister's intention in regard to this wide-reaching piece of regulation. The Opposition opposes the objectives of this regulation and says simply that if there is to be regulation, if Ministers cannot be trusted, there should be a form of self-regulation which will leave lobbyists free to deal with their clients in a confidential manner and will leave those who they represent free of the sort of strictures which the Minister has quite clearly laid out in his interjection.
