TALKER.NAME: Mr UREN
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Territories and Local Government)

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I wish to inform the House that the United Nations has accepted an invitation by the Government to send a visiting mission to the Cocos (Keeling) Islands to witness the making by the people of Cocos of an Act of self-determination. The visit is to occur in the first week of April 1984. The United Nations mission will consist of representatives of Sierra Leone, Yugoslavia, Fiji and Venezuela. This will be the third United Nations mission to visit Cocos. Earlier missions visited in 1974 and 1980. We have appreciated the degree of friendly co- operation that has developed over the years between Australia and the United Nations in regard to the advancement of the Cocos people. We expect that this process will reach culmination in 1984.

SPEECH.PARA: In issuing the invitation to the United Nations, the Government acted upon the advice of the Cocos leaders who, on behalf of the community, recently informed the Government that they were prepared to proceed with the act of self- determination and asked the Government to make the necessary arrangements with the United Nations. The Cocos people living in the islands will be determining their future in accordance with the United Nations requirements. The visiting mission will witness the plebiscite which will be oversighted by the Commonwealth Electoral Commission.

The requirements of the United Nations provide for non-self-governing territories whose development is considered by the United Nations Special Committee on Decolonisation-known as the Committee of 24-to exercise their right to self-determination, in accordance with the United Nations resolutions 1514 ( XV) and 1541 (XV) which set out the principles by which a territory has achieved a full measure of self-government by choosing, (a) firstly, independence, (b) secondly, free association with an independent state, or (c) thirdly, integration with an independent state. The Government recently presented the details of the three options-independence, free association with Australia, and integration with Australia-to the community.

Under the independence option, the Cocos-Malay community would be completely responsible for all aspects of their lives, including foreign affairs and defence. It would be up to them to determine how they would govern themselves and how they would raise revenue and establish their own social and economic strategies. Australia would obviously seek to have a close and friendly relationship with the new State, and would offer all assistance that is within our power to give. The newly independent State would be entitled to apply to join the United Nations and its agencies.

Under free association, Australia would conduct defence and foreign affairs matters on behalf of the Cocos community, and would negotiate with a new Cocos government the way it could assist that government to take full responsibility for a wide range of functions undertaken by Australia at present. These include health, education, transport, quarantine, radio communication and the conduct of the airfield at the Cocos (Keeling) Islands.

As with the independence option, members of the community would have to determine how they were to govern themselves, the standards of services that would be provided and the ways by which revenue would be raised. The Cocos ( Keeling) Islands would not be eligible for United Nations membership but Australia, as part of its responsibility for foreign affairs, would seek to obtain whatever United Nations assistance was available.
Under integration, the Cocos people would have the full rights, privileges and obligations of other Australian citizens:
Local arrangements would be modified to give the Cocos (Keeling) Islands Council wider powers and ownership of the plantation lands at present leased by the Commonwealth to the Cocos Co-operative.
The electors of Cocos would be included in an existing territory electorate for the purposes of House of Representatives and Senate elections and national referendums.
Appropriate Commonwealth legislation not already applying would be extended to Cocos , including the social security and health Acts.

A review in three years time would examine the introduction of tax. At present levels of income, the Cocos-Malay people are under the existing tax threshold and therefore they would not pay income tax in present circumstances.

The Commonwealth Government would take measures to raise services and standard of living to comparable Australian levels within 10 years, and use the Commonwealth Grants Commission to review standards.

Consistent with its commitment to the United Nations, Australia has, since the Cocos (Keeling) Islands were accepted as a Territory of Australia in 1955, taken many measures particularly in recent years for the political, social and economic advancement of the people of the Cocos to bring about conditions which would enable the people to exercise freely their right to self-determination, in full knowledge of the choices open to them.

In November 1982, the previous Government presented general elements of act of self-determination options for the consideration of the Cocos community. In response, the Chairman of the Cocos (Keeling) Islands Council wrote to the then Minister for Home Affairs and Environment indicating that the community believed it could not proceed towards the making of the act of self-determination in full confidence without knowing what the Australian Government intended to do about the presence at Cocos of Mr John Clunies-Ross. That letter was written in the light of longstanding grievances held by the community about what it sees as interference by Mr Clunies-Ross in its affairs. The relationship between the community and Mr Clunies-Ross was commented upon by the 1974 United Nations visiting mission to Cocos and the 1980 mission which expressed the view that the interdependence of the community and Mr Clunies-Ross should be discontinued. I will quote briefly from that letter of 13 December 1982:

There is one question which is worrying us and to which we should very much like an answer. As you will be aware from your knowledge of the history of Cocos , the people of our community have suffered many hardships because of the control John Clunies-Ross had in our land for many years. After the Australian Government made its purchase of $6.25 million of Clunies-Ross's land in 1978, we were confident that his influence on the affairs of our community would cease. The Australian Government gave us assurances at the time that we would not have to worry about Clunies-Ross any more. But this has not been the case. He has continued to interfere in the affairs of our community; his ships still come to and from Cocos; he employs on his property labour from the community at rates more favourable than those set by the Co-operative; he brings in foods (goods) of the same kind as those sold by the Co-operative but sells it to the community far more cheaply than our own Co-operative can; he and his manager have made it known to some of our community in recent months that they are opposed to integration and favour the choice of free association but what they have said has been deliberately aimed at creating confusion and division. These are all serious matters which show that his efforts to interfere in our community have persisted. In 1981, our Council passed a motion calling for the removal of Clunies-Ross. We should like to know now if the Australian Government is prepared to take positive steps to carry out the terms of our motion. After all, Clunies-Ross is not even an Australian citizen, as many of us are, yet he enjoys great privileges because of tax exemption for his companies and the advantage given to his ships.

We realise that the Act of self-determination is an important step for our community. But we do not believe we can proceed with this in full confidence without knowing what the Australian Government intends to do about removing Clunies-Ross.

That then was the position when this Government came to office in March 1983 and I became Minister responsible for the external territories. The House will recall that the Commonwealth purchased the bulk of Mr Clunies-Ross' property in the islands in September 1978 to make possible the implementation of policies for the advancement of the Cocos people. Following upon the purchase, a number of reforms were implemented such as the ending of the use of token currency issued by Mr Clunies-Ross and freedom of movement for the people. A fully elected form of local government body, the Cocos (Keeling) Islands Council, with extensive advisory powers was established. The village area was transferred to the ownership of the Council for the benefit of the people. The plantation lands were leased at a nominal rental to the Cocos Islands Co-operative Society, established to run the plantation and undertake a range of commercial activities .

I visited Cocos in April 1983 to ascertain for myself the wishes of the people about all matters affecting their future, including their attitude to Mr Clunies -Ross. What they had to tell me reflected what they had told the 1980 United Nations mission and various Ministers before me. In the light of unanimous views expressed to me at a joint meeting of the Cocos (Keeling) Islands Council and the management committee of the Cocos Islands Co-operative Society and other discussions I had with members of the community, I told the leaders that I would recommend that the Australian Government acquire the remaining property interests of Mr Clunies-Ross at Cocos with the intention that the property would be given to the Council, as had been the village area, for the benefit of the Cocos people.

I announced in July the Government's intention to acquire the property using the provisions of the Lands Acquisition Act for the public purpose of the political, social and economic development of the Cocos people. While the terms for the intended acquisition have yet to be determined, the Act provides for settlement on just terms. Mr Clunies-Ross decided to take legal action to resist the proposed acquisition under the Lands Acquisition Act. The present position is that the case is expected to be heard by the Full Bench of the High Court of Australia later this year.

As the matter is before the Court, I do not propose to comment further than is necessary at this stage. But so that the views of the Cocos Malay community are clearly understood by this Parliament I was seeking leave to incorporate in Hansard a copy of a letter recently sent to the Bulletin by the Chairman of the Cocos (Keeling) Islands Council, Parson Bin Yapat. Because I am unable to have it included in Hansard, I have no other option than to read it into the record.

TALK.START.PARA: —You have not asked for leave.

—Unfortunately, a standing order was levelled by the previous Speaker. I have spoken to the present Speaker and to the Clerks of the House. Under the Standing Orders, because of that previous ruling, I am unable to have the document incorporated in Hansard. I have no other option than to read it into the record. The letter is dated 16 March 1984. It is addressed to the Editor of the Bulletin in Sydney. It states:

SPEECH.PARA: Dear Sir
I am writing this letter as Chairman of the Cocos (Keeling) Islands Council and in the name of the entire Cocos (Keeling) Islands Council.

For the last few months we have read many letters and articles about Mr Clunies -Ross in 'The Bulletin' and we are growing tired of reading all these letters and articles. It is already past the time that the people of Australia should know the real situation in Cocos. Mr Clunies-Ross is very fortunate because there are not many Australians who do know about the situation here.

First of all, it is necessary for me to say that we do not accept that Mr Clunies-Ross is one of our people. It is our opinion that he is not a Cocos Malay. It is quite clear from what he does in Cocos that he does not consider himself to be one of our people.

Supposing Mr Clunies-Ross is one of our people, why does he live in a house which is very fine whereas our houses are not so good? It is the Australian Government, not Mr Clunies-Ross, who will give us good houses. The Government has a plan to build new houses, beginning from July of this year.

If Mr Clunies-Ross is one of our people, why did he not go looking for coconuts every day, why did he not husk coconuts as we did, which he made us do before the Australian Government began to exercise effective control in Cocos. Every week, all males of 15 years of age upwards had to go and gather coconuts and husk them, the number of coconuts which had to be gathered and husked was fixed by Mr Clunies-Ross or his manager.

If Mr Clunies-Ross is one of our people, why is his food different from ours, why does he not follow our customs, but rather why, in past times, did he always go by launch whilst we Cocos Malays had to go by Jukongs to our work. He would not want to do these things if he was one of us.

In 1978, the Australian Government paid Mr Clunies-Ross more than 6 million dollars when it bought most of the Cocos (Keeling) Islands from him, apart from an area of land where he and his family live at present. Why did Mr Clunies-Ross not divide all the money he had received among our people? Or why did he not use that money for the welfare of our people? You must remember that it was the Cocos Malays who did all the work, but Mr Clunies-Ross who received a lot of money.

Is there a people in the world today which does not yet have children who have completed their high school studies? It is only this year (1984) that Cocos Malay children will complete Class 12, that is, they will gain a certificate after having studied to Class 12 (the final year).

Mr Clunies-Ross' children went overseas to study. Why did Mr Clunies-Ross not want to give such opportunities to our children? It is necessary for the Australian people to know that before the Australian Government began to exercise control in Cocos, it could be said that our children did not have the opportunity of a good education.

Mr Clunies-Ross has said that there is nobody in Cocos who has told him it would be good if he left Cocos. Indeed, Mr Clunies-Ross knows that not so many Australians know about Malay customs. According to Malay culture, Malay people must be good to and respect other people whenever they meet them. Despite this, we are certain that our people will not progress if Mr Clunies-Ross remains here . So the Cocos (Keeling) Islands council has asked the Australian Government to settle this question. It is our firm resolve that he and his family leave Cocos.

Until 1978 our wages were paid in plastic coins-our wages were very low. Mr Clunies-Ross received Australian money from the Australian Government because he carried out contracts which the Australian Government gave him. We were the ones who did the work but he continued to pay our wages in plastic coins. Mr Clunies- Ross had enough money if he wanted to go overseas, if he wanted to buy something from overseas. We did not.

For a very long time our fundamental human rights were taken away from us completely. Mr Clunies-Ross would not alow us to leave Cocos. If we did go we were not allowed to return. In the period before the Australian Government took over control of Cocos, we were not allowed to speak to Australians. If Mr Clunies-Ross knew that we had spoken with an Australian, we were punished. (It is necessary for me to explain that the Cocos Malays live on Home Island whilst the Australians live on West Island on the other side of the lagoon). We have just heard Mr Clunies-Ross has applied to become an Australian citizen. Almost all Cocos Malays are already Australian citizens.

In the years following the last war many Cocos Malays left their homeland. Some went by themselves, others were forced to leave. At that time there was no court to hear the case of whether a person wished to go or not, a person could not bring the matter of whether he wanted to go or not to a court. Last year the Australian Government, after receiving a request from the Cocos (Keeling) Islands Council that the Government settle the question of Mr Clunies-Ross and his family, took the decision to acquire his land and the house he still owns on Cocos and give it all to our people. Mr Clunies-Ross has the right to take this matter to the high court. In past times those of our people who had to leave Cocos, did not have any right of this kind.

It seems that Mr Clunies-Ross is now seeking the support of the Australian people with the intention of not being removed from the Cocos (Keeling) Islands. It is our feeling, that if the Australian people all knew the true situation, if they knew how he had treated us in the past, if they knew that Mr Clunies-Ross had taken away all our fundamental human rights, they would not want to support him at all.

Mr Clunies-Ross says that he is of the same race as us. Why has he not been pressing for the right to vote in our council elections? It is only now that he is seeking the right to vote. His intention is to participate in the election in April, that is the Act of Self Determination or the election which will be held so that the Cocos Malays can determine their own political future.

What does Mr Clunies-Ross want for the Cocos Malays? Does he want independence? He has sold many T-Shirts with the word 'merdeka' on them. (Merdeka means independence.) Mr Clunies-Ross has given the name 'merdeka' to his launch. Does he want to give himself independence so that he can regain control in Cocos? Why does Mr Clunies-Ross wish to interfere in the matter of our Act of Self Determination?

Who has given our children the opportunity to study overseas, who has endeavoured to give us higher wages? Who will give us new houses? Who has restored to us our fundamental human rights? When Mr Clunies-Ross was in control in Cocos we had no rights at all.
The Australian Government has done all these things and wishes to ensure our future. We do indeed believe that the Australian Government will do all it has promised to do.

Mr Clunies-Ross can go anywhere he likes in the Kampong everybody else has to seek approval of the Chairman of the Council if they wish to visit the Kampong. Whenever he goes for a walk in the Kampong, Mr Clunies-Ross always wears a dagger. Why? No Cocos Malay wears a dagger in this way.

It is not necessary for me to continue. My principal purpose has been that the Australian people should know that Mr Clunies-Ross is not one of our people as he said he was in a letter he wrote to 'The Bulletin'. It is necessary also for the Australian people to know how Mr Clunies-Ross treated us in the past so that we had no fundamental rights at all.
Yours faithfully
(Parson Bin Yapat)
Chairman
Cocos (Keeling) Islands
Council
16 March 1984

I read the letter out because I thought it was important. Although it was laborious to do so I had to read it to get it into the record. It is important that those Cocos Malay people be heard and their views placed on the record at this historic time because it is only a short time before they decide on self- determination. Australia's commitment to the United Nations is for the political , social and economic advancement of the Cocos community, to enable them to determine their future by free choice in accordance with United Nations principles.
An ordinance which contains the rules for the conduct of the referendum has been laid before the Parliament. In the act of self-determination, a person will be eligible to vote if:
(a) He or she has attained the age of 18 years;
(b) His or her principal residence is on Home Island; and
(c) He or she has had such residence on Home Island for the period of 12 months before the date fixed for the closing of the electoral role, 26 March 1984.

Mr and Mrs Clunies-Ross will be eligible to vote in the referendum if they wish. We have made this decision after consultation with the Cocos Malay leaders and for the purpose of preventing any obstruction to the conduct of the referendum. The leaders of the Cocos people have made it clear to me personally that they do not see Mr Clunies-Ross as one of their community and they do not want Mr Clunies-Ross seeking to influence the people as to how they vote in that act of self- determination. Finally, I would like to put on record the great respect which the Australian Government has for the Cocos people and our full confidence in their capacity to determine their future.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ruddock Mr P.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I thank you, Madam Deputy Speaker, and the House for the courtesy in enabling me to respond on behalf of the Opposition to the statement made by the Minister for Territories and Local Government (Mr Uren ) relating to the future of the Cocos (Keeling) Islands. It is an important matter. I regret in a sense that the Minister is making the statement only one week before the visit of a United Nations mission to the Cocos (Keeling) Islands for the purpose of dealing with the matter of the act of self-determination. The notice seems very short. It may be that the United Nations gave the Minister only that length of notice. If that was the case I think it would have been appropriate that the House be informed of that matter.

SPEECH.PARA: The fact is, of course, that there has been a long standing interest of Liberal and National parties and Ministers of Liberal and National Party governments in the future of the Cocos (Keeling) Islands and its people. In 1955 the islands were accepted as a territory of Australia. This was an important event. In 1978 the Australian Government purchased from Mr Clunies-Ross all his property interests on the Cocos (Keeling) Islands except for his home and its curtilage. That was a very important initiative. Of course, it was a very momentous occasion so far as the history of the Cocos (Keeling) Islands was concerned. The Government then leased to the Cocos-Malay inhabitants of the island for $1 per annum-except Mr Clunies-Ross-the areas that had been acquired.

There have been a number of benefits from that acquisition. I understand there have been significant pay increases made possible to the Cocos-Malay people. That would be seen as a significant benefit in terms of giving them a rising standard of living. As the Minister mentioned, there was an abandonment of the old token currency, about which a lot has been written and about which there was a great deal of complaint. There were opportunities to improve the facilities in which the Cocos-Malay people lived. Provision was made for electricity and sewerage-so many of the things we take so much for granted.

Freedom was granted to people of Cocos-Malay origin to enable them to visit relatives in Australia at reduced fares. Of course, there was the attainment for many of Australian citizenship. I think that was a very important factor so far as the Cocos-Malay people were concerned. Freedom was given to issue stamps for Cocos Island from which revenue would be derived for the local people. Of course , there were employment opportunities for Cocos-Malay people in many areas of activity associated with Australian Government activities on the island itself. The high security quarantine station, which has been so important so far as Australia and the future of its animals is concerned, was put in place.

It is very important from the point of view of maintaining the integrity of Australia's breeding stock that we are able to introduce stock from other parts of the world and have a place that is sufficiently isolated to ensure that no disease that might affect Australia is likely to be introduced by imported animals. The Island and the high security quarantine station were a very important involvement for Australia and also important from the point of view of the employment opportunities for the Cocos-Malay people. As detailed by the Minister for Territories and Local Government, the Cocos (Keeling) Island's Council and the island trading company were established. These were important initiatives. The fact that they were mentioned by the Minister in his speech acknowledges the role that the previous Liberal and National Party governments had in bringing to fruition this development wherein the people of the islands will be given an opportunity to determine their own future in terms of being either an independent nation, a country in free association with Australia, or a part of Australia.

I certainly welcome the Minister's statement. I do not do it grudgingly; I simply note the interest in this matter by my colleagues and by me when we were in government. Only a matter of weeks ago I put a question on the Notice Paper to the Minister seeking information about many of the matters upon which the Minister has responded today. Honourable members may be interested to know some of the questions that I raised. I asked the Minister: What is the Government's program for effecting an act of self-determination for the non-self-governing territory of the Cocos (Keeling) Islands? The Minister has dealt with that question today and I welcome that. I also asked: What questions will be put to the people of the Cocos (Keeling) Islands in respect of their self-determination ? That question has been answered today and I welcome that.

However, I asked a number of other questions relating to self-determination, some of which have been partially answered and some of which have not been addressed at all. The Minister's statement leaves many of the questions, particularly those relating to the third option that he dealt with-the question of association with Australia-quite clearly unanswered. I certainly hope that the Minister will take the first available opportunity to give attention to answering these very important questions. Many relevant questions relating to Australia need to be addressed by the Minister as quickly as possible. It may well be that the points I am raising could be relevant to the act of self- determination upon which the people of the Cocos (Keeling) Islands will be asked to vote. The Minister has clarified some of the questions in relation to the act of self-determination but he has not answered the question as to what future integration with Australia may offer.

As I understand it, there are two options that might be pursued in relation to our constitutional structure if the Cocos (Keeling) Islands are to be integrated with Australia. Either the Cocos (Keeling) Islands would become part of a State of Australia-the most likely option is Western Australia-or, secondly, they would become part of one of the territories of Australia. It is well known that many of the islanders have permanent resident status within Australia and that is likely to lead to their wanting to be part of Australia. If they are Australian citizens I think the most likely option is that the people will vote for Australia. But it is important that if they are going to exercise that choice they do so in the knowledge of what form of integration it will take. Will it be integration with Western Australia? Will it be integration with the Australian Capital Territory? Will it be integration with the Northern Territory ? The Minister has not told us whether he has consulted on this matter with the Western Australian Government, the Northern Territory Government or how he thinks the integration of a group of people who live on an island in the Indian Ocean with the people of the Australian Capital Territory would work and how that would fit in with the self-government model that he and his Government are presently proposing. These questions need to be addressed.

The Australian Constitution is very ambiguous on these islands becoming part of Australia. I recognise that there are problems with integrating the Cocos ( Keeling) Islands with part of Western Australia because before such an integration could take place there would have to be a referendum to alter the boundaries of Western Australia and that would involve an Australian Constitution amendment. That may well be a matter that the Government, after some consideration, says gives it very considerable difficulty.

The only place I heard mentioned previously as an alternative to Western Australia was the Australian Capital Territory. We now have the Northern Territory mentioned as a possibility. On what basis can one reasonably expect the Cocos (Keeling) Islands to be integrated with the Northern Territory? The Minister's statement answers in part some of my questions. He did not answer these questions which I shall address to the House. Is there any substance to the suggestion that integration with the Northern Territory may be proposed? Have discussions taken place with the Northern Territory Government on this proposal? What greater association would the Cocos (Keeling) Islands have with the Northern Territory rather than, say, Western Australia? Do all persons born on the Cocos (Keeling) Islands have Australian citizenship? How many people born on Cocos (Keeling) Islands have settled in Australia, and in which States or territories? To me that seems a very important question. As I understand it, most of the Cocos (Keeling) Islanders who have come to Australia to exercise their rights as Australian citizens have settled in Western Australia. How would they be associated with the Northern Territory? I notice that the Minister for Territories and Local Government is shaking his head. If the answer is no I am very pleased to have that answer. I have put very serious questions before him.

Finally I want to deal with the matter of Mr John Clunies-Ross. Some of the questions I asked the Minister related to him. I asked: Will Mr John Clunies- Ross and his family be eligible to vote in any questions of self-determination? Will an act of self-determination be effected before or after legal proceedings for the acquisition of the home and curtilage of the Clunies-Ross family are completed? Will Mr Clunies-Ross be asked to leave the Cocos (Keeling) Islands before or after any act of self-determination is effected?

I notice that one of my colleagues, in an effort to help me, has said that the Minister in his statement says, yes. I am aware that the Minister has said that Mr Clunies-Ross and his wife will be able to vote in the act of self- determination but the other questions that I have asked have not been answered by the Minister in his statement. The Minister read at length a letter that was written by the President of the Cocos (Keeling) Islands Council, Parson Bin Yapat. Whilst he read the letter into Hansard I had not read it previously. I have read some of the earlier correspondence in the Bulletin to which the President of the Council was replying. I have to say that that letter alone, without understanding the context of the correspondence, does take the matter somewhat out of context.

I am disappointed that the Minister did not fully background the House on the matters raised in the correspondence, particularly that of Mr David McNicoll. I think the President of the Council was replying to Mr McNicoll's postscript to a letter which appeared in the Bulletin of 24 January last. The antecedents and the associations of the Clunies-Ross family with the islands were mentioned therein, in addition to the context in which their property interests in the islands were dealt with. Mr Clunies-Ross has lived on the islands for most of his life except, as I understand it, when he left to be educated abroad. He regarded the islands as his home and until recently-I was not aware that he may have sought Australian citizenship-he has not had Australian citizenship. He has seen the Cocos (Keeling) Islands as his home. I think it is important that in terms of what might be regarded as an Australian ethos in fairness to him as well as to the people of the Cocos (Keeling) Islands he be given the right to participate in this act of self-determination. I am glad that the people of the Cocos (Keeling) Islands have agreed to that and that the Minister has announced it.

But the question of his future on the islands is still very doubtful, it would seem, from the statements that have been made. I must say that I am concerned that the Minister has not given some attention to answering some of the other questions that I raised. A media statement that the Minister made on 21 July certainly emphasised that the Government was intending to acquire Mr Clunies- Ross's property on the island, that is, the remainder of his property on the island, his home and the five hectares of curtilage to that home. But the Minister waited until 17 August-presumably until after he had seen Mr Clunies- Ross during a visit to the island-to make clear what that statement meant. In his statement of 17 August he made the following additional statement:

The Government intends that the property on acquisition will be given by deed of grant to the Cocos (Keeling) Islands Council in trust for the people. When this occurs, it must be expected that Mr Clunies-Ross leave Cocos.

We know that there has been an attempt at acquisition. The matter is now before the High Court of Australia, which is to find out whether that property is being acquired for a proper public purpose. I think it is important that Mr Clunies- Ross and the people of the Cocos (Keeling) Islands have these additional questions answered by the Minister before they make their choice. I think they are proper questions to be asked. In context it was appropriate that the Minister developed his statement to a point where all of the outstanding questions that I have addressed, both in the question that I put on notice and in those I asked today were answered before this act of self-determination takes place.

TALKER.NAME: Mr UREN
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Territories and Local Government)

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I clarify one point because I do not want any confusion amongst the Press or to confuse and frighten the people of the Cocos (Keeling) Islands. There is not the slightest intention of incorporating Cocos into the Northern Territory. As I said during my speech, the islands will be members of either one of the two Territories. There are only two territories in which they can be incorporated. Under the Commonwealth Electoral Act 1918 they cannot be incorporated in Western Australia. They can be on the electoral rolls of only the Australian Capital Territory or the Northern Territory. One of those two Territories must be determined. I do not want to say any more because in many of these matters legal implications are involved. I would prefer questions concerning them to be placed on notice.

—by leave-I think it is important that these matters be clarified, but the Minister for Territories and Local Government (Mr Uren) still has not made it clear whether the Cocos (Keeling) Islands can be incorporated in the Northern Territory. I think that the question ought to be answered properly. The Minister said that it could be the Northern Territory or the Australian Capital Territory.

TALKER.NAME: Mr UREN
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Territories and Local Government)

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-The situation is that under the electoral laws, once people become part of Australia they have a vote. Under the electoral laws these people can vote only in either the Northern Territory or the Australian Capital Territory.
—Which is it to be?

—The Government will clarify that situation at the appropriate time. I must say that it is a little too smart of the honourable member for Dundas (Mr Ruddock) to infer that the Cocos (Keeling) Islands were to be incorporated into the Northern Territory. I did not want to frighten the people of the Cocos ( Keeling) Islands. This is a serious matter. The former Minister, who will speak after me, realises how sensitive and frightened these people can be. The people of Lord Howe Island are on the electoral roll of Sydney, but Sydney has no powers over them. It is a simple matter of being on the electoral roll of either the Northern Territory, or one of the electorates in the Australian Capital Territory.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McVeigh The Hon D.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I rise in a non-partisan way firstly to congratulate the Minister for Territories and Local Government (Mr Uren) on the enthusiasm with which he has pursued the matter of self-determination for the Cocos (Keeling) Islanders. I know from my association with them and from the messages that have been conveyed back to me that the people have an affinity with the Minister. They trust and respect him. I will never be afraid to stand up in this Parliament and express those types of sentiments when I believe that they are appropriate because the national Parliament would certainly degenerate if people were not prepared to get up and speak the truth about sensitive matters.

SPEECH.PARA: It is not for me to reply on behalf of the Opposition. That was done by my colleague the honourable member for Dundas (Mr Ruddock). However, I want to be associated with this statement. It has not been an easy task for the Minister to bring this matter to finality. The finality is a matter of a vote for self- determination. I know that the great enthusiasm that the Minister has brought to this matter, an enthusiasm born out of a sensitivity for a wonderful race of people, a people who may be poor in what we might term the corporal necessities of life, but who are very rich in the real riches of life. We have much to gain by having them as part of Australia.

I congratulate many of the Cocos Islanders, people such as Wahin, Cree and Parson, for the guiding light and encouraging hand they have given to many of their fellow citizens. It is difficult for us to understand the reasoning of these people. We live in a society where the traditional democratic way is expressed by a vote in the ballot box. These people operate differently. I spoke about being rich in the real riches of life, the quality of the family life of these people and the fact that they speak on a basis of consensus, where leaders convey to the people the things they are concerned about and, having reached consensus, move to ensure that that point of view is finally the accepted point of view. It is a great pleasure to go to the Cocos (Keeling) Islands and to be the recipient of the courtesy of these people, to go into their homes and to receive good Christian hospitality. It is very refreshing and personally rewarding to observe the simple, good manners and the deep feeling which people have of friendship for the people whom they know and trust. It is not for me to express a personal point of view about what decision they should make. That would be recreant to any trust that has ever been placed in me by them. I would never want to be part of any criticism that I used any influence that I might have had to try to get these people to vote in any particular way.

But I would very much indeed like to go back, maybe many years hence and possibly not in too long a period, to see the excellent quarantine station that has been built on the island, the air strip, built at enormous personal sacrifice by the Cocos Malays, and the post office completely manned and operated by Cocos Malays.That would make me very proud of them and proud for them.

Thank you very much, Madam Deputy Speaker, for allowing me to associate myself with the statement by the Minister. It is a matter of deep personal sensitivity for me. Maybe my own views on the total matter are not shared by my colleagues. Quite frankly, that is of no importance or interest to me. I believe that the Minister has taken the right and proper decision. He has my total support for what he has done and I compliment him on being able to bring to fruition what, unfortunately, I did not have the time to complete. If I had done so, I would have been very proud to stand in this Parliament today and deliver the statement that the Minister has delivered.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Discussion of Matter of Public Importance

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Madam DEPUTY SPEAKER

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Speaker has received a letter from the Deputy Leader of the Opposition (Mr Howard) proposing that a definite matter of public importance be submitted to the House for discussion, namely:

INTERJECT.PARA: The negative effect of current Government policies and attitudes on private investment.
I call upon those members who approve of the proposed discussion to rise in their places.
More than the number of members required by the Standing Orders having risen in their places-

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Howard The Hon J.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —There is one thing that has characterised debate on economic matters since the Hawke Government came to power and one thing that has stood out above everything else; that is, the consistency with which the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke), the Treasurer (Mr Keating) and other Ministers in the Government have seized hold of any fortuitous statistics, whatever their origin, whatever their circumstances and whatever their explanation, and used them to justify the actions taken by the Government and to demonstrate that the Government is doing a very good job of handling the economy. What the Treasurer has constantly invited us to do is to make comparisons. How often have we heard him say in this House: 'Inflation was eleven point something in March 1983 and it is now much lower'? He has said in the House that interest rates were at a higher rate in March 1983 than they are now and that something else was at a higher rate in 1983 than it is now.

SPEECH.PARA: Time and again the Prime Minister and the Treasurer have both gone for the fast quip. They have said that that improvement is due entirely to the magnificence of the Hawke-Keating economic management. It reached its absolute dizzy height when the Prime Minister said in this Parliament: 'Not everything is due to me. You know, the breaking of the drought was substantially due to God. It was not totally due to God; it was only substantially due to God'. There is a nice, consistent pattern that if something good has happened, the Government claims credit for it. Hang the explanation; hang the reasons; hang the timing; and hang the circumstances.

What I will do today in connection with this matter of public importance is to take a leaf out of the Treasurer's book. I will grab hold of some statistics that happen to demonstrate that in terms of private sector investment, which both the Prime Minister and the Treasurer have said in recent weeks is the absolute prerequisite to a sustained economic recovery, this mob has been absolutely hopeless. I have a bundle of statistics that show very clearly how absolutely hopeless they are. Using their standard, and using the persistent pattern that they have adopted since they have been in government, I will demonstrate that the Hawke-Keating Government has brought about the worst prospect for private sector business investment in the last 10 years.

What this Treasurer and this Prime Minister have succeeded in doing is to create an outlook for private sector investment which is worse than it was under the Whitlam Government, and that is saying something. That is not a bad effort. I will seek leave to have incorporated in Hansard a table drawn from the Parliamentary Library, based on statistics from the Australian Bureau of Statistics. The Treasurer can have it combed over-undoubtedly he will do so, and I know by whom-to try to establish whether there is something wrong with it. I present it with my compliments. This table shows very clearly that in real terms -not creep terms, but in real terms-in 1982 prices, in 1974-75 private sector investment was $10,427m, that is, in constant prices, and by 1980-81 it had risen to $15,615m. In 1981-82 it went to $17,871m. In 1982-83-that was the last year substantially covered by a Fraser Government Budget-it had fallen back to $ 16,348m. The 1983-84 forecast is for $11,049m. Do honourable members know what the 1984-85 forecast is? No wonder the Government is coy about making forecasts this year. It is $9,803m. So in real terms it is worse than for the last year of the Whitlam Government.

But honourable members do not have to rely on the Opposition or on me to promote the importance of private business investment to economic recovery in this country. Honourable members will remember that the Prime Minister went to the Australian Institute of Directors in Sydney only two weeks ago and in a sort of plea of evangelism he said: 'Will you please invest, because unless you invest we will not have an economic recovery'. So by the Government's own definition, on the basis of those figures, it is staring over the starkest cliff in terms of private business investment that this country has seen since 1974.

One of the things that I am reminded of when I hear the Treasurer and the Prime Minister talk about the economy is the biblical quotation which states, in effect, 'Would that mine adversary would write a book'. 'Mine adversaries' have written a book-a book of predictions and a book of quotations which will come back to bite them month by month as time goes by. We all remember towards the end of last year how the Prime Minister and the Treasurer were talking up the economy. We had turned the corner! All of our Christmases were coming at once! Honourable members will remember that marvellous phrase of the Prime Minister in this House on the subject of the forecasts of the Department of the Prime Minister and Cabinet. They were the ones which the Treasurer said that the Economic Planning Advisory Council had rejected. Yet EPAC had so rejected them that it sent them away and sought further information and further explanation. The Prime Minister said in this Parliament: 'Take it from me, take it from Bob that you can consign those predictions to the dust bins of history. They are irrelevant. They are quite meaningless and they are absolute nonsense'. He said they were too gloomy and they could be confined to the dust bins of history.

But by March 1984 we have a different picture. The Prime Minister's tack has changed. He arrogantly claimed that the Government had turned the economy round. But he now asserts that it is up to the business community to do its share. What he is trying to do is to create a situation whereby the Government, having got its job, having done everything right, says that it is now up to everybody else to do their bit. We cannot really expect the Prime Minister, the Treasurer and the Government to do any more; it is up to the rest of the community! He almost suggests that the business community has some kind of social obligation to invest.

Everybody on this side of the House knows that business people, whether they are large or small, whether they live in Australia, the United States of America or anywhere else, do not invest on the basis of evangelical appeals from Prime Ministers, whether those Prime Ministers are Liberal or Labor. That is a simple lesson that this Prime Minister cannot understand. If he really wants to get a private business recovery going in Australia, if he really wants even to claw it back to the disastrous Whitlam levels, according to this table there are four things for openers that he will do. The first thing he will do is sit down with his Treasurer and decide what state they really believe the economy is in. If there is one thing that has characterised the economy and the discussion of the economy over the last few weeks it has been the utter confusion on the part of the Government and particularly on the part of the Treasurer and the Prime Minister as to the facts. At the end of last year all our Christmases were coming at once and it was a sure path to economic glory. At the Economic Planning Advisory Council meeting the Treasurer, no doubt reading a Treasury speech, warned everybody that it was a very fragile recovery. He said: 'It is not really going as well as we might think. Dear me, it is a very fragile recovery'.

The Treasurer and the Prime Minister, not to be outdone by that turnaround, and remembering that their mates were against the electoral wall in New South Wales, went to Sydney, and all has changed again. We heard the Treasurer talking about this fantastic growth of 10 per cent. He talked about this fantastic performance of the Australian economy. Of course, what those figures that the Treasurer used demonstrated very clearly, and I have never made any secret of it, was that the economy is growing faster this year than it was last year. But every last person in Australia knows that there are three fundamental reasons for that: Firstly, we had a drought that was broken. Secondly, we had a wage pause which the present Prime Minister tried to sabotage when he was in opposition. As Paul Kelly's book demonstrates, the present Prime Minister tried to manipulate the trade union movement's and the Labor Party's response to that wage pause initiative to undermine the then Leader of the Opposition. The Prime Minister behaved shamefully as a member of the Opposition on that issue and he has absolutely no credit when it comes to that. Thirdly, of course, there has been a turnaround of sorts in the international business cycle which is working its way through to Australia. Without any question, those circumstances have worked to create a far better climate.

What I say to the House and what those on the Government side ought to realise is that there is every potential for the recovery that has taken place over the last 12 months to peter out by the end of 1984. The Organisation for Economic Co -operation and Development said at the end of last year that the prospects for growth in 1985 are significantly lower than they are this year, and that is why the Prime Minister is already saying that he is going to rush to the polls at the end of this year. He knows that in 1985 all his problems will come to the surface. The forward Estimates released by the Department of Finance last Sunday week showed one very interesting statistic. They demonstrated that the forecast for the inflation rate according to the price deflator measurement, actually showed the inflation rate in 1984-85 as being one per cent to 1.5 per cent higher than it was in 1983-84. The significance of using the deflator is that it throws out that Medibank fiddle which totally misrepresents the true inflation figure. There is a very simple explanation why that figure shows an increase. It is because by 1985 the effects of that premature return to full wage indexation will have worked their way through.

There are four things that this Government ought to do if it really wants an improvement in this disastrous level of private business investment. It can get its act together as far as its own view of the state of the Australian economy is concerned. What a hide the Prime Minister had in fabricating and dishonestly claiming in the House-I repeat, dishonestly claiming-that there was a dispute between the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Peacock) and me about tax cuts. The Government ought to get its act together and make up its mind whether there is really a recovery, whether it is staggered or whether something is going to happen in 1985. The third thing it can do is to bring about a major reduction in the size of the Budget deficit this year because unless it does that, if there is some kind of recovery in private business investment and if there is an increase in the corporate sector's borrowing requirement, there is going to be a collision between that increased borrowing requirement and the largest public sector borrowing demand for 25 years. That will have an adverse effect on the level of interest rates in Australia.

The fourth thing it can do to improve the climate for business investment is to tell the Deputy Prime Minister (Mr Lionel Bowen) that he is utterly wrong about the Trade Practices Act. The amendments to the Trade Practices Act proposed by this Government are essentially anti-business in their nature. What the Government intends to do is to make it harder and not easier to rationalise and restructure. What the Government intends to do is to double the penalties on companies for predatory conduct, yet free trade unions totally from any liability for the same predatory conduct. What the Government is endeavouring to do, through those Trade Practices Act amendments, is to encumber the Australian business community, in a nation of 15 million people, with a trade practices regime which is appropriate to the United States, an economy with 250 million people. If those amendments are passed into law, if the ideological, professorial Attorney-General (Senator Gareth Evans) has his way on this subject we will end up with a cluster of additional anti-business red tape and regulation which will further depress an already depressed business outlook.

If anybody wants to know what the business community really thinks of investment prospects in Australia at present he ought to read the speech of Mr Strong, Executive Director of the Australian Mining Industry Council, delivered only a couple of days ago when he made it very clear that one does not invest on faith; one invests only on the basis of proper returns. I will just read a few quotations:

Almost to a man they will tell you that the capital expenditure that is taking place reflects completion of projects committed in earlier years, particularly in 1980-81, principally coal and aluminium projects stimulated by the second oil shock of 1979 . . . In the mining industry, there is virtually no investment taking place which will result in increased net output.

That is a pretty dismal picture. It is no wonder that he is facing an investment climate even worse than it was in 1974. This Government stands condemned on its own devices, its own rhetoric and its own methodology in economic debate, with the Australian nation staring in the face the worst private sector investment slump for over 10 years.

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam Deputy Speaker, I understand that the Deputy Leader of the Opposition asked for leave to incorporate a table in Hansard. At the time your attention was distracted.
—Leave is granted.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Madam DEPUTY SPEAKER

TALK.START.PARA: —Leave is granted. I thank the honourable member for Fisher for bringing that to my attention. It had not been addressed to me.
