SPEECH.SPEAKER: Keating The Hon P.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —This was a pathetic attempt by the former Treasurer to try to do something with a very dishonest proposition.
—You have lost your audience already.

—Look, I heard the former Treasurer in silence and I will speak in silence. So just restrain yourselves. (Quorum formed) It was a very dishonest attempt to make a case which simply cannot be made. I never thought that the former Treasurer would stoop to trying to suggest, by introducing some phony argument around statistics about investment, that a decline investment in 1983- 84 was in the period of the Australian Labor Party Government when he knows full well that the decline was simply the lagged effect of the recession which he induced in 1982-83.

SPEECH.PARA: He is the greatest job and investment destroyer since the bubonic plague. In 1982-83, with a massive contraction in profits and a massive rise in inflation and unemployment, obviously we have had a serious decline in investment in 1983- 84. His first piece of evidence in favour of his case today is to argue that there are no lags in economics; that because the numbers are down in 1983-84, that is the Government's fault; and then he goes on to postulate something about 1984-85. So much for that argument, which is hardly worth attending to.

The next thing that the honourable member says is that either the Treasurer and the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) have not got their stories straight or they are trying to mislead people about the state of the economy. The fact is that we are speaking about two different income years-1983-84 and 1984-85. For the dullards on the front bench opposite, let me repeat that in 1983-84, the current financial year, the latest assessment that I have of growth through the year is about 10 per cent, which would probably give us a year average figure of between 5.5 per cent and 6 per cent. When the honourable member for Bennelong (Mr Howard ) was Treasurer in 1982-83, the growth performance of the economy in that year was to decline by 2.5 per cent. So we have come from a decline of 2.5 per cent to growth of about 5.5 per cent, a turn around of 8 per cent, with growth through the year of 10 per cent.

Why should the Government go out of its way to hide that fact? What are we supposed to say? Are we to say: 'We are having phenomenal growth. Do not tell anyone. We shall keep it a secret, because it might offend John Howard. It may make it look as though his performance in 1982-83 was pathetic'. The honourable member tried to suggest that this year it is all due to the breaking of the drought. There are many elements in this year's pick-up-the slowing of wages, lower interest rates, the turn around in the stock cycle, certainly a pick-up in the farm sector, a pick-up in housing coming off the Government's first home owners scheme and lower interest rates, the fiscal stimulus coming off the Government's Budget deficit and the deficit of the States, the contribution to growth from exports, and stronger consumer spending. They are all the elements in 1983-84, and 1983-84 has given a kick start to the economy which it very sorely needed after the former Treasurer had let himself loose on the economy for five years.

Then the honourable member goes on to argue: 'In that case that is inconsistent '. There is no inconsistency. What we are saying is that strong growth is here. Its momentum will feed through into 1984-85. There are certainly one-off elements in it which will wane over the course of that year, but its strength is such that even as some elements wane, they will be replaced by other elements, including a very strong pick-up in consumption and, hopefully, a stronger pick- up in investment. What the Prime Minister has said and what I have said is certainly not an evangelical appeal. It is nothing like that. Neither is it what has been said by Mr Strong of the Australian Mining Industry Council. Frankly, some of these industry lobby executives need to do their homework a little better. Mr Strong in his recent speech said that it was for social reasons. There are no social reasons. To get this matter clear let me read what the Prime Minister said:
We believe that this result is possible-
That is, higher investment-
indeed, that it is a logical response by business to the general improvements in economic conditions which are now apparent-
There is nothing evangelical about that-
and which can be expected to continue for some time.
He went on to say:

Already it is clear that the policies that the Australian Labor Government is promoting are contributing to a substantially higher share of profits in total income, lower inflation, lower unit labour costs, lower interest rates and greater confidence in the continuity of economic policy. Our industrial relations policies have produced the lowest level of disputation for 15 years. I would simply ask when business has known a better environment within which to commit its own resources to a renewed round of investment. Indeed, by doing so it will itself be contributing to the maintenance and enhancement of the very conditions it so greatly values.

Is that some evangelical appeal? Is that an appeal for social reasons, as Mr Strong put it? It is an appeal based upon the preconditions for investment which will certainly be evident as we move into 1984-85. That is, we shall see a very strong pick-up in consumption. We shall see spending increase as the savings ratio is declining. We have already seen profits recovered, and indeed, over the course of 1984-85 profits will recover where the profit share of the gross domestic product will be back to something like it was in the 1960s. We shall see labour costs improving, the accord holding, inflation continuing on its downward path, and, with an appropriate Budget outcome, further scope for interest rate falls.

On the basis of that kind of situation, why would we not say that there are and will be conditions obtaining in 1984-85 which will be conducive to a pick-up in private investment? We are simply acknowledging at this stage that the first survey of business investment taken by the Australian Statistician in January showed a modest decline in investment-although I make the point that the Statistician's survey, on the average of the last nine years, is 35 per cent below the outcome for investment for that year, which would even turn the projection into a modest pick-up of investment. But what both the Prime Minister and I have said is that the conditions will be there, as they never were in the Fraser years, for a pick-up in private investment. That may be terribly embarrassing to the honourable member for Bennelong, and it may be terribly embarrassing to his colleague at the table, the honourable member for Higgins ( Mr Shipton), who is one of the supposed advocates of small business. They have sent more small businesses to the wall in bankruptcy than any government in history. Now that they have a government which is committed to a pick-up in private sector investment, which is committed to growth in the economy coming off a healthy private sector in a mixed economy, they are embarrassed by this because they have been running the phoney line for years that the Labor Party is not interested in growth, that it is not interested in investment, that it could not defend Australia, and that it lacks interest in all sorts of other issues, all the shibboleths on which they have traded in all of the years of easy post- war growth. They now suddenly find that they have a government that can make the business community tick over better than they could. That is why we shall see, over the course of the year, that they will eat their little hearts out as the economy moves correctly and progressively back into a full recovery phase, as we repair the damage which was inflicted by their policies.

Looking at the former Treasurer's policy, one would even assume, with this motion, that he had some of the answers. One of the things that he said on the Sunday program not so long ago-again in one of these characteristics bursts of candour where the acceptance of the candour is supposed to overtake the gravity of the matter to which he is addressing that candour-was: 'Of course, wages policy was our great weakness. We never had an incomes policy'.

TALK.START.PARA: —It was. I have never denied that.

—The honourable member confirms it. But he still does not have one and he will not get one. He has no tax policy, no incomes policy, and no fiscal policy. The result is that what we would see under his policies would be a pick- up in the economy to be choked off by another prices and wages round. All that he has to offer the public is the stale old recipe of monetary policy and a bit of duck-shoving on fiscal policy, winding it up for an election with a few throw -aways, hoping like hell that he can lay enough shibboleths around the place to win another three years of government as he has done in the past.

SPEECH.PARA: Liberal members have been exposed as belonging to a party which has not only run out of ideas but has also run out of confidence and, more importantly, a party which has run out of policies. They are not kidding anybody in the business community. Because they have their Liberal Party tickets in their pockets, let them not think that they are kidding anybody in business. People in business are interested in profits, jobs and growth. They are not interested in the Liberal Party. I will tell honourable members where the business constituency in this country is. It is right behind this side of the House. They can forget it being behind their side for a long time. They will be growing old in opposition while they try to disparage this Government's policies, because this Government is interested in growth-the one thing that honourable members opposite have never been able to provide.

As to the former Treasurer, I do not think that there would have been any Treasurer around the world in the years from 1976 to 1983, particularly as the world economy moved into recession, who was presented with such a one-off golden opportunity to insulate this country from the recession which affected the rest of the world with that massive investment in the mining sector coming off the general energy policies of Japan and other countries, and particularly in coal and in aluminium. We had a golden opportunity to slide through the recession, maintain our growth rates, maintain our investments and come out much better than anybody else. But what happened to us? We went down the tube. Not only did we go down the tube; we went down bigger and harder than almost any other country. Why? Because honourable members opposite were running around like chooks with their heads cut off without a policy in sight. They had this great Country Party Prime Minister, the former member for Wannon, with a sort of Country Party view of the world; that is, rely on the pork barrel and regulation whenever possible. The former Treasurer was trying to squeak a view into the Cabinet amongst all of the Country Party or National Party overlords. What did honourable members opposite finally have? They simply squandered the investment phase in mining. Their crazy advocation of movement to a market-based system of wage fixation resulted in a high wage round, high inflation and that massive burst of unemployment, taking our unemployment rate from 6.5 per cent to 10.5 per cent.

I do not want to waste any more time on members of the Opposition. I just say this to them: Come back to us in about five years because that is the only chance you will have. They will have to sit there and watch growth go up, inflation go down, employment go up and unemployment go down and they will eat their hearts out while it is happening. I have no more to say on that matter. The matter of public importance from the former Treasurer who destroyed the economy deserves the contempt of the House.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Shipton Mr R.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Opposition has raised this matter of public importance relating to the lack of private investment in the Australian economy because we are most concerned about the future of the country. Investment means jobs, and I have just heard a very disappointing explanation of the state of affairs by the Treasurer (Mr Keating). A most revealing document was tabled today by the former Treasurer, the present Deputy Leader of the Opposition, the honourable member for Bennelong (Mr Howard). It shows that private sector investment is declining and that the forecasts for the future are most depressing.

SPEECH.PARA: The Treasurer, who has chosen to leave the House and not face the facts, talked about the state of the economy. Let us look at the economy. He talked about growth. Growth is not anticipated in the Parliamentary Library forecast tabled in the House today. If we look at the figures for the last year of the coalition Government we see that in 1982-83 the private sector investment, in money terms, was $16,348m. It is forecast to decline in 1983-84 to $11,878m in money terms, and the forecast for 1984-85 is even worse. Those figures speak for themselves. They show what is happening in the economy today. They show why the private sector lacks confidence in this Government. They are depressing. They show why the Government will have an early election this year; because it is scared of the effect of its policies and of what is happening in the economy today.

Investment is not occurring in Australia because of a lack of confidence in the private sector. There is no climate for investment in Australia today. Investors are voting against this Government with their cheque books. They are not writing the cheques to invest. The figures tabled by the honourable member for Bennelong clearly show that there is a crisis of confidence in the private sector. There is no climate for the creation of wealth in the community today. There is no climate for investment, for the creation of profit. It is from profit that we get savings and capital for investment. That is what honourable members opposite do not understand. Today interest rates are rising because of the large Budget deficit and the huge public sector borrowing. High interest rates act as a deterrent to investment. Private investment is not occurring. The Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) has admitted that it is not occurring. In the week before the New South Wales election he appealed to the private sector to invest. He has admitted that the Government's policies are failing. Why? The economic policies of the present Government are not working. The wages accord has failed. It is passing on the consumer price index increases automatically. There is no recognition of industry's capacity to pay or an individual firm's capacity to pay. The cost of living adjustments are just added to the costs in the wage packet of every business in Australia. The accord has unleashed union power on the business community.

TALK.START.PARA: —Cut it out.

—I hear an interjection from the honourable member for Stirling. I hope he will admit that the Australian Labor Party is the prisoner of the trade union movement. Was the Parliamentary Labor Party not formed to be the parliamentary wing of the union movement? Does the honourable member deny that? Does he deny the history, the very basis of the Australian Labor Party? Of course he does not. He is what he is. He is the representative in this place of the trade union movement, and the accord shows very clearly that he is a prisoner of that movement. The full wage indexation policy erodes competitiveness and is a disincentive to business investment. The policies represented by the accord discourage investment.

SPEECH.PARA: Honourable members opposite talk of capital gains taxes. There is speculation about wealth taxes and about an early election. Let us look at these things. Undoubtedly, Labor wants to introduce a capital gains tax. There is no doubt about it at all; it is policy and it is there. The Minister for Industry and Commerce (Senator Button) has said that some strengthened capital gains tax to apply when people sell businesses should be in place in return for the election promises of taxation concessions to small business. There was no mention of a capital gains tax before the election but now the Minister in charge of industry and commerce in Australia says that there ought to be such a tax. Talk of a capital gains tax damages the investment climate. It deters business investment. Speculation of this sort does nothing to create investor confidence or investment. Speculation about capital gains taxes, wealth taxes and the introduction of death duties deters investment. The Government ought to realise that.

Similarly, the Government ought to realise that speculation about an early election deters investors. People do not know where they stand. The Government does not understand that capital is needed for investment. It does not understand that capital represents people's assets, savings and nest eggs and that those savings and nest eggs are used for investment. It does not understand the family business. The introduction of probate duty, a wealth tax or a capital gains tax could well wipe out the family investment in a family business. The Government does not understand that. It does not understand that in a mixed business a family may work hard to build up goodwill, which is capital which it sells. It is part of the Australian myth, part of the Australian dream and this Government wants to bring that down.

There is speculation about the nature of the assets test. The Government has said that a pensioner assets test will be introduced. Again, this discourages people from saving and investing. The Government does not understand the nature of the investment process. This was clearly shown in its introduction of a lump sum superannuation tax in the mini-Budget last May. The taxation of lum sums affects business investment. Retirees' lump sums are used for investment in businesses. Again, it shows that the Government does not understand the investment process.

The Government has failed small business. It promised all sorts of things. Small business is the key to economic recovery. No major growth is occurring in the small business sector because this Government has failed small business miserably. It promised to implement a small business action program immediately upon election. It has made taxation promises to small business that it has not honoured. There is no investment across the board, as the honourable member for Bennelong pointed out, in the major resource sector. No major investment is taking place in Australia's large corporate sector, whether in manufacturing or in mining. No across the board investment is taking place in the small business sector. The small business sector is the key to growth. Small business employs most Australians. For instance, 99 per cent of businesses in Australia employ less than 100 people and 93 per cent of businesses employ less than 10 people. It is estimated by surveys that 80 per cent of extra jobs have to come from the small business sector. This Government's policies will not create those jobs. The Government has failed the small business sector miserably.

Let us look at something else that the Government has done in relation to its bondage to the union movement. The Government has supported and endorsed the Australian Council of Trade Unions' job protection case which will put costs up and deter investment for every business in Australia. It proves beyond doubt that this government is a union government and a mouth piece of the union movement. The Australian Council of Trade Unions' job protection case places an incredible burden on business to make payments when people retire. It is an enormous burden. One has to give three months' notice, and there are enormous payments and payouts. Even the Australian Council of Trade Unions' modified claim is an incredible claim and it is deterring business investment in the private sector.

I turn now to inflation. This country currently is inflating at double the rate of its major trading partners. We are losing competitiveness daily. Investment is being deterred daily. Let us just look at the tourist industry. The last consumer price index figures show a 5.7 increase in domestic holiday travel and accommodation prices and a 5.3 decrease in overseas travel and accommodation prices. So there is an 11 per cent gap of competitiveness. This gap is widening. This is just an example that Australia is becoming less competitive under this Government day by day. We have a rate of inflation at least double the rate of our major trading partners, and we are falling further and further behind as a nation. It is an absolute disgrace.

This Government is an anti-business government, a government that has not in place policies that will encourage investment. Look at the abolition of the dividend rebate in the May mini-Budget. This Government does not understand how this deters investors. It was a blow to people who wanted to invest in companies and in stock exchanges. It was a blow to those people in businesses and in small businesses who were not listed on the stock exchanges, people on the shop floor who wanted to have a share in the ownership of those businesses.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Edwards Mr R.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is good to hear members of the Opposition at last talk about economic matters. I think we have had enough of New South Wales bashing and innuendo in this Parliament. Members of the Opposition are now talking about economic matters. It is unfortunate that when they do their performance is not better. The honourable member for Higgins (Mr Shipton) has just spoken about small business. He really has dealt totally inadequately with the matter. The reason it is inadequate is that if honourable members opposite were to talk to small businesses they would tell them that they were concerned about increased turnover, lower interest rates and wage stability. That is what they have had under this Government. The small business sector has had increased turnover and lower interest rates. We have to face that, particularly those who are seeking overdraft accommodation. Certainly there has been a lower pattern of interest rates as well as wage stability with this Government in power. We cannot run away from that. That has been this Government's performance.

SPEECH.PARA: I want to talk about housing shortly because that is where many small businesses are doing very well, especially in the electorate of Stirling in Western Australia. I might add that, if we are addressing the issue of the capacity of small business to perform, the honourable member for Higgins (Mr Shipton) has missed the point. The point is, substantially, that with increased demand, wage stability and lower interest rates small businesses are better off. But it is important that honourable members opposite have come into this chamber and talked about economics. We are very reluctant on this side of the House to take issue and say: 'We can look at the poor performance of the previous Government'. But members of the Opposition and the honourable member for Bennelong (Mr Howard) force us to.

If we look at the Fraser-Howard record of economic vandalism we see that there is a lot to talk about. The fact is that the Opposition did a miserable job in the seven years that it was in government. The electorate knows that it did; the Opposition knows that it did and it missed the opportunity. The previous Government left us with the worst recession since the Great Depression. That is an awful legacy to have. The honourable member for Bennelong is still here to face the music. His partner in crime, the former honourable member for Wannon, has left. None of us is sorry to see him go because he was a most nasty and vindictive Prime Minister in the way in which he conducted his economic policy. I concede that a lot of thought was given to the former Government's economic policies, but they did not work. The fact is that the previous Government destroyed jobs in a massive way. Two hundred and fifty thousand jobs were lost in the Australian economy in the last two years of the former Government. Now the honourable member for Hume (Mr Lusher) comes into this chamber and says that he can identify with the unemployed. What a nasty exercise it is for someone in this place. Honourable members opposite know that it is. It is an embarrassment to them. The only comment that members of the Opposition can make about unemployment is to have one of their members go through this charade of identifying with the unemployed. It is a disgrace! Honourable members opposite ought to admit that it is a disgrace! The community knows it is a disgrace and the honourable member for Hume knows it is a disgrace because he has been almost invisible in the last two days, and that is not because he cannot get his bicycle started. The fact is that it is a humiliating experience for him, and he ought to have known about it. Yet the Opposition's only comment about employment is to do that. Yet the previous Government destroyed 250,000 jobs in two years. It is a massive scandal. The previous Government did it, and we are trying to repair that damage.

I wish to talk now about private fixed investment. The reality is that private fixed investment declined by 15 per cent in 1981-82 and again in 1982-83. Members of the Opposition want to blame their performance on us. We are flat out cleaning up the wreckage of the economy. They want to say to us that we ought to be doing this and that with the economy. In fact we have been flat out cleaning up the mess left by the honourable member for Bennelong and the not lamented former right honourable member for Wannon. The reality is that private fixed investment will pick up because we are setting the framework for that recovery and honourable members opposite know that. What really bothers honourable members opposite is that they are not in government when the recovery is occurring.

Let me go on and talk about the performance in housing. This is where we have a clear record to demonstrate. The previous Government left us with 105,000 housing starts, the lowest in 25 years. Our level is up to 130,000 at least. We are getting people into houses. It is important to take up this issue because tomorrow the Parliament will be visited by the homeless groups from Melbourne. Honourable members opposite might have a look in the public gallery and recognise the fact that a lot of those people are without housing due to the failure of their policies. They are the ones who killed off the economy; they are the ones who killed off investment. When we look at the fact that there are more people in Australia without homes we see that that is the legacy that the former Government left them. It is a disgrace. It is another example of what I would call the Fraser-Howard economic vandalism and honourable members opposite have to face that; they cannot run away from it.

We have talked about the issue of getting some wage stability. We have a wages policy. The wages policy has been working since we have been in government. The unfortunate thing for honourable members opposite is that they never had a wages policy. The attitude adopted by former Prime Minister Fraser was simply to bash unions. It is unfortunate to see that the honourable member for Higgins is still on that same kick. It is not very sophisticated. It is not good enough. The Opposition has to come up with a substantial wages policy. So far it has not. The situation is crying out for a wages policy and Opposition members are not addressing that question.

Honourable members on this side of the House well know that the honourable member for Balaclava (Mr Macphee) and the honourable member for Bennelong are locked in a struggle as to who will win out over the wages policy issue. If I had a preference from the point of view of honourable members opposite I would hope that the honourable member for Balaclava wins that battle because it is an important battle. It will get back some respect in the community as far as the Opposition's wages policy is concerned. At present the Opposition does not have one. We have a wages policy. It happens that the prices and incomes accord is working with the one exception of the most disreputable union in Australia at the moment-the Australian Medical Association. We have found that we have a prices and incomes accord that is well put together.

I can go on and talk further about the gross domestic product. The Treasurer ( Mr Keating) has already spoken about the issue of GDP. That fell by 2.5 per cent in 1982-83, the last year of the former Government. What a disgrace! The previous Government said that it was in power to get the economy moving. It said that it represented the private sector. What the previous Government did was to put its fingers around the throat of the private sector and squeeze the life out of it. So GDP declined by 2.5 per cent. Already in 1983-84 GDP is projected to grow by 5.5 per cent. That is a clear turnaround. It is a turnaround that honourable members opposite have recognised. We have been able to do that and it is a substantial improvement.

I wish now to talk about inflation. The previous Government had double digit inflation in its last two years, 1981-82 and 1982-83. This year we are projecting inflation to be 8.5 per cent. That is something that honourable members opposite have to face up to. Inflation is falling. We have wage and price stability. Interest rates are down. We also have some confidence back in the economy. We have restored stability. In that climate, we are looking ahead to a lower Budget deficit. We can project that private fixed capital investment will recover. Those are the conditions for recovery. Honourable members opposite know it. What really bothers them is that they are sitting on the Opposition benches and we are in government. But we did the job of work and the previous Government did not. It had seven years and it failed. The community knows that it failed. When we really begin to address some of the hard issues of economic management, when we look at the fact that the job of government is to set a framework within which the private sector can perform, we see that the former Government had that opportunity and it blew it. Mining recovery never took off in Australia. It did not produce the jobs. It did not produce the flow through to the rest of the economy that the previous Government hoped it would. But we have managed, importantly with the National Economic Summit Conference last year , flowing through to the Premiers Conference and then the Budget, to have set a stage for economic recovery in this country. If we look at some of those conditions we see that the community also recognises that. We also have some hard data to support the claims that I am making.

Manufacturing production has turned around. It was nearly 4 per cent higher in the December quarter of 1983 than in the March quarter of 1983. So manufacturing production is up. Consumer spending is rising. The honourable member for Higgins has spoken about small business. The most important thing for a small business person is to get people coming in through the door. The only way to do that is to get money in their pockets and get interest rates down. The previous Government sadly failed in that area and it knows it failed. Somehow that arch- Tory Fraser dragged the previous Government into recession. The fact that there are so few members of the Opposition on the other side indicates that point.

Let us have a look at the projections on the balance of payments. We are getting an improvement in that area as well. Overall, the statistics show that we have a credible economic performance. We have to throw this back to the previous Government. It did not succeed. It is not good enough for honourable members opposite to come into this place with some high level of indignation and to pretend that they can unload upon us the responsibility for their failings. They did fail. They failed economically, they failed politically, and they failed miserably in political terms. If one looks at the benches on the other side of the chamber there are very few people on them.

If we take the reality, we have put together a credible economic policy. I will go through it again because I think it is important: We have a prices and incomes accord in place; interest rates have fallen; we have begun to get recovery throughout the housing sector; we have also managed to get an acceptance by finance institutions that our economic management is credible and they are looking forward to developments within this economy; inflation is down and we are looking ahead to a Budget which in fact will produce a lower deficit. All the conditions are there. So when we look at the issue of private fixed capital investment-that is what we are talking about today-the reality is that the conditions are there for recovery in investment. If honourable members knew anything about the question of lags they would understand that when those conditions are set up investment recovery follows.

In conclusion, I say to honourable members that when they want to come into this House and talk about economic issues they had better get their facts right. These facts do not make a very good case for honourable members opposite; they make a disgraceful case. But they do make a good case for the Government. The Government has put together a substantial policy. That policy is working. The community recognises this and the statistics show it. I am happy to reject the matter of public importance brought on by the Opposition.

TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of the Parliamentary Standing Committee on Public Works, I present the forty-seventh general report, and the first, second and fifth reports for 1984 of the Committee, relating to the construction of an engine runup facility, Royal Australian Air Force Base, Darwin, the construction of a new building for the Australian Film and Television School, North Ryde, New South Wales and the reconstruction of the Pyrotechnic section at the Munitions Filling Factory, St Marys, New South Wales, respectively, and I ask leave of the House to make a short statement in connection with the forty-seventh general report.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —Once a year the Public Works Committee is required by its Act to report to Parliament on its activities over the proceeding 12 months. The report contains factual information on such matters as committee membership, number of meetings held and details of the various works referred to it and the number of reports presented, et cetera. The report highlights the new areas of work now being examined, namely those relating to statutory bodies and overseas embassies . This widening of the Committee's purview resulted from recent amendments to the Public Works Committee Act.

SPEECH.PARA: Two further amendments to the Act are foreshadowed in this report. One is to cover the possibility of work being declared urgent by the Governor-General because of an emergency situation and the other is to raise the current mandatory limit of work being referred to the Committee from $2m to $6m and that the Committee be given discretionary power to examine works estimated to cost between $2m and $6m.

For the benefit of honourable members, officials and others likely to be dealing with the Committee and the public generally, I turn now to the functions of the Committee. The Committee, as expeditiously as is practicable, considers each public work that is referred to it in accordance with the Public Works Committee Act and makes a report to both Houses of Parliament concerning the expediency of carrying out the work. It also reports on any other matters related to the work in respect of which it thinks desirable that its views should be reported to both Houses. It may recommend any alterations to the proposals for the work that, in its opinion, is necessary or desirable to ensure that the most effective use is made of the moneys to be expended on the work. It is the practice for the Chairman of the Committee to read out sub-section 17 (3) of the Public Works Committee Act at the commencement of each public hearing. This sets out the pertinent matters to be taken into consideration when the Committee reports on a public work.

Honourable members may be assured that the members of this Committee, the twenty-seventh, will continue to uphold the tradition of all former committees in its important role as a watchdog, on behalf of Parliament, over proposed expenditure on public works. I commend the report to honourable members.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cowan Mr D.B.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I support the remarks of the honourable member for Farrer (Mr Fife) who is the Vice Chairman of the Public Works Committee. I will say a few words concerning the work of the Committee. I have been a member of it for over three years. I believe that the work performed by members of the Committee is very important indeed so far as the Parliament and the various departments are concerned. If we were to sum up briefly the work of the Committee we could assess it as a dollar saver for the taxpayer. Over the years I have found that all the Committee members have served it in a very capable way . They delve very deeply into the various investigations carried out by the Committee. As honourable members will see from the report over the year there have been quite a number of hearings and investigations. These take up a lot of time of the Committee but all Committee members are pleased to serve on the Committee.

SPEECH.PARA: I pay a tribute to Senator Foreman, the Chairman of the Committee. I also pay a tribute to Mr Fenton and the rest of the Public Works Committee staff who look after us in a very fine way indeed. They endeavour to fit the members into the various schedules and at times that is not very easy to do.

In conclusion, I feel that the work of the Committee has the very great respect of the various departments, particularly the Department of Defence and the Department of Housing and Construction. I believe that officers of these Departments like to appear before us. They go into great detail with their submissions to the Committee, which I believe is a very good thing as far as construction work and costing are concerned. SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bowen The Hon L.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.

On 30 November 1983 the Australian Secret Intelligence Service-ASIS-conducted an exercise at the Sheraton Hotel in Melbourne which was the subject of Mr Justice Hope's report tabled in the Senate on 29 February 1984. As a result of the incident at the Sheraton Hotel, the Victorian Police together with the Victorian Director of Public Prosecutions are considering prosecuting certain persons for breaches of the criminal law in Victoria. On the advice of the Minister for Foreign Affairs (Mr Hayden), confirmed by Mr Justice Hope, the Government considers that there are very strong grounds for believing that the disclosure of the names of some, if not all, of these persons in the ordinary course of criminal proceedings, would be prejudicial to the national or international security of Australia. In these circumstances, there has been detailed consultation between Commonwealth and Victorian Ministers and officials with a view to meeting the concerns of both governments by means of State legislation specifically empowering Victorian courts, in appropriate circumstances, to make orders for confidentiality upon grounds of prejudice to the national or international security of Australia. Complementary Commonwealth legislation is necessary to give effect to such orders outside Victoria.

On 20 March 1984, the Victorian Parliament passed the Criminal Proceedings Act 1984, specifically empowering the courts of that State to make certain orders for confidentiality in relation to criminal proceedings arising out of the Sheraton Hotel incident. The Bill now before the House represents the Commonwealth's part of the arrangement and complements the Victorian legislation , which received the royal assent on 27 March 1984. (Quorum formed) This Bill amends the Judiciary Act 1903 by inserting a new Part under which any such orders for confidentiality made by the criminal courts of Victoria in relation to those criminal proceedings are applied, by force of Commonwealth law, throughout Australia. Under the Bill, the Federal Court of Australia is, in effect, given power to punish contravention of these confidentiality orders in the same way as contempt of court is punished.

The new Part is inserted by clause 3 of the Bill. Proposed section 46 provides that the Part is to apply only to orders made by Victorian courts in criminal proceedings arising out of the Sheraton Hotel incident. Proposed sub-section 49 (1) makes it clear, furthermore, that it applies only to orders made on grounds of necessity or desirability 'in the interests of the national or international security of Australia or in the interests of the physical safety of the accused, of a witness or of any other person'. The particular types of confidentiality orders to be applied by the Part are spelt out in proposed sub-section 49 (3) as follows:
Orders for the whole or part of the proceedings to take place in a closed hearing;
orders excluding a person or class of persons from the whole or part of the proceedings;
orders prohibiting or restricting disclosure of information respecting the whole or part of the proceedings;
orders prohibiting or restricting publication of a report relating to the whole or part of the proceedings;
orders ensuring that, without the approval of the court, no person has access- before, during or after the hearing-to any document used in, or court records of , the proceedings; and
orders combining any two or more of the foregoing.

The scheme of these amendments can be summarised as follows: If a Victorian court should make, under the specific power conferred by the Victorian Criminal Proceedings Act 1984, an order to which the present Bill applies, that order would by force of proposed sub-section 49 (2) take effect throughout Australia and beyond, applying to all natural persons, whether Australian citizens or Australian residents or not, and all bodies corporate as provided in proposed section 47. Any contravention of the order, for example, by someone in New South Wales, would be punishable by the Federal Court of Australia under proposed sub- section 49 (4) as if it were a contempt of that Court.

These amendments have been introduced to meet the particular issues of concern to the Commonwealth and Victorian governments arising out of the Sheraton Hotel incident and it is not proposed to give them general or permanent force. Thus the Bill contains, in proposed section 51, a sunset clause limiting the application of the Bill to orders made within two years after the commencement of the Victorian legislation. This limitation expressly recognises the exceptional nature of the amendments and the particular circumstances which they are designed to meet. In addition, the Bill contains, in proposed section 50, a specific provision to ensure public accountability in regard to the operation of the Part. It requires the Attorney-General to make an annual report to Parliament on the number of proceedings known to him in which relevant confidentiality orders were made, and the outcome of those proceedings. Such annual reports are to be made in terms that would not breach the confidentiality orders involved.

I draw the attention of the House to the fact that provisions of the type proposed in the present Bill and the Victorian legislation it complements are not entirely novel. There are precedent provisions for confidentiality orders in the United Kingdom Official Secrets Act 1920 and also in existing Australian legislation. For example, section 85B of the Crimes Act 1914 gives judges and magistrates in Federal jurisdiction a power to make orders similar to those referred to in proposed section 49 if satisfied that such an order is expedient in the interest of the defence of the Commonwealth. Again section 50 of the Federal Court of Australia Act 1976 gives that Court power, at any time during or after the hearing of a proceeding, to make such orders forbidding or restricting the publication of evidence or the name of a party or witness, as appear to the Court necessary in order to prevent prejudice to the administration of justice or the security of the Commonwealth.

The amendments contained in this Bill will enable the criminal law of Victoria to take its due course, but at the same time will provide a procedure designed to ensure that the national or international security of Australia, or the physical safety of persons, is not prejudiced in the process. No significant financial impact is expected. I commend the Bill to the House.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Coleman Mr W.P.

TALK.START.PARA: —I seek leave to make a short statement on one of the reports of the Joint Standing Committee on Public Works just tabled, the one on the construction of the new building for the Australian Film and Television School.

—Madam Deputy Speaker, I would just like to say that our patience has been a little bit tested because the Deputy Prime Minister was interrupted when making a second reading speech. However, the honourable member for Wentworth did see me prior to the House moving to the Deputy Prime Minister's speech. He pointed out there were four reports. I think there was some confusion in his mind. I had agreed that he be given leave to speak to the report on the Australian Film and Television School. We will stick to that agreement.

—I thank the Minister for Primary Industry (Mr Kerin). I particularly welcome the opportunity to speak on the tabling of the Public Works Committee report on the construction of a new building for the Australian Film and Television School because of my involvement, in the early years of the school, some 15 years ago in the planning of this new building for the Australian Film and Television School. With the honourable member for Lalor (Mr Barry Jones), now the Minister for Science and Technology, I was on the film committee of the old Australian Council for the Arts which proposed the report, which the then Gorton Government accepted and which the subsequent Whitlam Government continued , on the construction of that school and for the examination of various sites, including the site on which this new building is to be built.

SPEECH.PARA: We examined sites all over the country but finally settled on a site in North Sydney for the reason that that is where the Australian film industry tends to be concentrated. The school began in effect in a small office in North Sydney, then moved to a slightly larger office in Chatswood and finally moved to temporary warehouses in North Ryde where it has carried out its programs, I think it is fair to say, with very great success.

Some 85 per cent to 95 per cent of its graduates are in employment. There will be a graduation next Friday of 24 graduates. Already eight of them have obtained jobs and another eight are in the process of obtaining jobs. That is a fair indication of the success of the employment rate of the school. Graduates have been associated with well known films, such as Gillian Armstrong with My Brilliant Career, John Cruthers with The Plains of Heaven, Chris Noonan with Stepping Out and Sophia Turkiewicz with Silver City which has just been completed. The school has an outstanding success record, particularly under the present Director, Mr Storry Walton. It is also becoming a training school for film makers throughout the South Pacific. It conducts a unique open program for the retraining and reskilling of people already employed in the industry. I say it is unique although it has recently been imitated by the British film school. Nevertheless it has carried on its training, its business, in inadequate buildings-theatres, studios, workshops and rehearsal space-at an annual rental of over $350,000 a year. The Public Works Committee has now recommended a new building.

The Committee is obviously surprised, impressed and a little depressed at the great cost of this new building. It will be $13m. The Committee points out that each graduate, taking into account running costs, costs the taxpayer some $70, 000. The Committee, in its report, is concerned to find ways if not of reducing the cost of at least reducing the cost to the taxpayer. I should mention in passing that the report states that all of this money is going mainly to full time students. I do not think that is accurate because the open program is a major part of the work of the school and it will be expanded in the new buildings. Nevertheless it is not surprising that the Committee looks at and makes as a condition its raising money from the industry.

The report points out that the industry is, in effect, subsidised by the school at the rate of $5.1m per annum and it asks what can be raised from the industry. I think that may be a little optimistic. The wealthy television companies do not employ cinematographers and directors. They tend to get their finished product from the producers such as the Crawfords and the Grundys who would have a more direct interest in the school than the television companies. Otherwise we are looking at the freelance independent producers, the Joan Longs and the David Elficks. All of these producers are not financially strong. Many of them do not live at all well. They survive on subsidies and tax concessions. They are not in a position to make the sort of contribution to the film school that I believe the Committee thinks is possible.

It may well be that the cinema levy referred to in the report would work. But as we know ever since there have been cinemas there has been talk of cinema levies. Except in occasional cases they have never happened and the cinema lobby seems very successful in postponing or ruling them out. Nevertheless I think the Committee is right when it recommends that some attention should be given to removing the disincentive under which the film school and all statutory authorities operate at the moment to raise money. If they raise, say, $50,000 then by standard practice the Commonwealth Government reduces their budget by $ 50,000 and that, of course, really takes away any heart that they would have in raising the money themselves. The Committee rightly suggests that this disincentive be removed and I understand that that is under active consideration .

The Public Works Committee has basically approved the new buildings. They will go ahead and do better work for Australia in the satellite age and for the industry, justifying the confidence that Prime Ministers Gorton, Whitlam and Fraser have had in the industry. It is indeed a happy day that after so many years this report giving approval to the construction of a new building, is tabled in this Parliament.

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.

The purpose of this Bill is to amend the Pig Meat Promotion Act 1975 and to make a consequential amendment to the Pig Slaughter Levy Act 1971. The Pig Meat Promotion Act 1975 established the Pig Meat Promotion Committee of four members funded by a levy of 60c on each pig slaughtered for human consumption. This gives the Committee an annual income of around $2.5m. There is no Commonwealth contribution to the Committee's funds. This Bill seeks to change the name of the Committee to the Pork Promotion Committee and to change the name of the Pig Meat Promotion Act 1975 to the Pork Promotion Act 1975. The change is intended to update the image of pig meat throughout the industry and in no way indicates any change in the role or functions of the Committee.

Administration of the Committee's funds are to be transferred to the Committee itself. At present the Committee's funds are placed in a trust account within the Department of Primary Industry and all accounts are paid through departmental procedures. Under the proposed arrangements levy money will be paid direct to the Committee which will then be responsible for paying its own accounts. This will streamline the financial operations of the Committee considerably. The Committee will be required to keep its accounts in accordance with usual procedures for such an authority and the accounts will be audited by the Commonwealth Auditor-General. The provision will be continued that the funds can be spent only in accordance with estimates of expenditure approved by the Minister for Primary Industry. The above changes have the support of the Australian Pork Producers Federation.

The Bill also provides for a number of amendments of a machinery nature, which have been endorsed by the Committee. One of the two producer representatives on the Committee is Chairman. It is proposed that the other producer representative should be the Deputy Chairman. It is provided that, instead of all four members having to be present to hold a meeting, a quorum of three will be sufficient. The Minister for Primary Industry will be required to approve persons proposed as deputies of members prior to their appointment. The Pig Slaughter Levy Act 1971 is to be amended to take account of the change of name of the Committee. I commend the Bill to honourable members.

DEBATE.TITLE: AUSTRALIAN BICENTENNIAL ROAD DEVELOPMENT TRUST FUND AMENDMENT BILL 1984

PROCTEXT.PARA: (Quorum formed)
Bill presented by Mr Peter Morris, and read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Morris The Hon P.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.

The purpose of this Bill is to amend certain of the arrangements under which financial assistance is made available to the States and Northern Territory under the Australian Bicentennial Road Development Trust Fund Act 1982. I should point out to the House that this Government when in opposition supported the objectives of the program when the Act was introduced by our predecessors. Because of the declining level of Commonwealth expenditure on roads the need for such an initiative was obvious. However, we were concerned about some of the provisions of the legislation, particularly the compulsory tendering requirement , and during last year's election campaign we undertook to review it.

Upon coming to government we have accordingly reviewed a number of provisions of the ABRD Trust Fund Act, in addition to those relating to the calling of tenders. In giving this undertaking, our Government was concerned to have provisions that were reasonable to all parties. Consistent with our approach to conciliation and consultation, detailed discussions were held with the States, local government, industry and relevant unions. This process identified three areas where changes to the provisions of the legislation were necessary.

The first, as identified earlier, related to the provisions which required that all construction work on national, urban arterial and rural arterial roads must go to tender. The second related to the provisions requiring the States to maintain in real terms their expenditure on roads for the duration of the ABRD program. We do not disagree with the broad objective. We were concerned, however , that there was no recognition of circumstances where a State had substantially exceeded its real terms maintenance of expenditure, possibly for a number of years, but that the excess could not be taken into account in subsequent years should the State fall behind the necessary rate of expenditure.

Thirdly, a number of States pointed out that, where a State wished to take the option of directing part of its urban arterial roads allocation to urban public transport projects, additional conditions were imposed without the State receiving one additional cent of funding. Having regard to the much greater rates of investment that most States are making in urban public transport than the funds that would be available under the ABRD program, this Government is satisfied that the requirement that the State also maintain its urban public transport real terms expenditure is unreasonable. The amendments to the ABRD Trust Fund Act therefore make the changes which this Government considers are desirable in order to improve the operation of the ABRD program.

Turning to the provisions of the legislation, firstly, the Bill varies the requirement that tenders must be called by a State for all works associated with national and arterial road projects. Under the legislation developed by our predecessors this was an absolute requirement with no provision whatsoever for it to be waived. While this Government recognises the merits of the general principle of calling tenders for road construction, there is a need for some flexibility to cover situations where the process of calling tenders is either impractical or not cost effective.
The Bill therefore allows the Minister to approve an exemption from the requirement to call tenders for specific works where a State can demonstrate to the Minister's satisfaction that:
there is an emergency requirement for the works to be performed, or
the works are of such a minor nature that calling tenders would involve undue additional cost, or
it is not practical to prepare adequate tender specifications for the works, or
the works are of such a kind that competitive tenders are unlikely to be received, or

the works involve adjustments to utility services which would normally be undertaken by a government department, a government authority or a corporation not primarily responsible for the construction of roads, or
the performance of the work under contract would cause unavoidable retrenchment or inefficiency in the deployment of a substantial number of State or local government road construction employees.
(Quorum formed)
This last provision also requires the State or local government to demonstrate that it has taken all practicable action to avoid this problem.

The Bill provides for this amendment to come into effect from 12 February 1984, the date on which the Government's intention to revise these provisions was announced. This will enable the States, upon enactment of this legislation, to seek exemption in respect of any works which have been commenced subsequent to that date. I must emphasise that each of these provisions for exemption has been carefully considered. They have been included as there are obvious circumstances where time or costs make the tendering process inappropriate. It is the Government's intention that the ministerial discretion will be used very infrequently, and then only after the most rigorous and detailed examination of all the factors involved.

The second area of amendment relates to the requirement that States maintain their own roads expenditure in real terms during the life of the ABRD program. The Act currently provides that, where a State fails to maintain its roads expenditure in real terms in a given year, it is required to make up the shortfall in the following year. Should it fail to do this its allocation under the ABRD program may be reduced. However, there is no provision to allow a State which exceeds the real terms requirement in a year to carry forward that excess as a credit against a later year. While the Government firmly intends that States should be required to maintain their own expenditure effort, it considers that the current legislative provisions are, from the States' standpoint, both inconsistent and inequitable. Accordingly, the Bill provides that excess expenditure by a State in any year shall be taken into account in determining the level of expenditure by that State in a subsequent year. This provision is comparable with arrangements which have previously applied under Federal roads assistance legislation.

The third area of amendment relates to the requirement that, where a State proposes that part of its urban road allocation be directed to urban public transport capital works projects, it must maintain in real terms its own capital expenditure on urban public transport. As it stands, a State which decides to apply part of its ABRD entitlement to urban public transport projects receives no more in total assistance than if it were to direct all of its funds to road projects. On the other hand, the State becomes liable to a requirement to maintain a specified level of State expenditure on both roads and urban public transport in each year of the program.

This Government's transport policy is to assist the States to improve and maintain urban public transport systems. It is clearly inconsistent with this objective to maintain an arrangement which disadvantages States which wish to apply part of their ABRD funds to worthwhile urban public transport improvements . The Bill therefore removes the requirement that State urban public transport expenditure be maintained in real terms where this option is taken up. These amendments, developed in close consultation with all the parties concerned, further reinforce the Government's commitment to improve the effectiveness of Australia's road system. This commitment is nowhere more clearly evident than in the increases of 45 per cent to $1,233m in our allocation to the States for roads this year. I commend the Bill to the House.

The Customs Tariff Amendment Bill 1984 which is now before the House proposes amendments to the Customs Tariff Act 1982. The Bill contains nine schedules and is necessary to enact tariff changes which have been introduced into the Parliament in the 1983 Budget sittings and the 1984 Autumn sittings by Customs Tariff Proposals Nos 15-19 (1983) and Customs Tariff Proposals Nos 1-4 (1984).
Certain of the amendments contained in the Bill arise from the Government's decisions on the Industries Assistance Commission's reports on:
Copper and certain copper products (including removal of export control)
Fatty acids and certain aliphatic acids, their salts and esters; glycerol; tall oil
Lawnmowers, certain engines and parts and the Temporary Assistance Authority's report on certain air conditioning machines.
The Bill also contains amendments relating to:
The implementation of arrangements resulting from the closer economic relations agreement with New Zealand;

Continuation of the textiles, clothing and footwear sectoral policy, including decisions taken by the Government in respect of the May 1983 report of the Textiles, Clothing and Footwear Advisory Committee;
Concessions granted under certain trade agreements with nations of the South Pacific region and with Canada;
The insertion of provisions to allow imports of certain steel products from developing countries to be admitted under quota at concessional rates of duty; and finally,
Amendments to correctly reflect the intention, scope or wording of certain provisions contained in the principal Act.
Honourable members will recall that on each occasion when Customs Tariff proposals were introduced, the decisions taken by the Government were outlined to the House. (Quorum formed)

I am thankful to the honourable member for Curtin (Mr Rocher) for giving me an audience for this gripping speech. It is a pity that he is speechless when there are things of some import before the House and confines his total speaking activities to calling stupid quorums.

The changes in respect of TAA and IAC reports contained in this Bill are directed to the level of assistance accorded to certain industries. Some of these changes have the secondary effect of increasing or decreasing revenues. Decisions affecting levels of assistance are of course expected to have an effect on levels of imports and, therefore, the level of customs duty collected. The precise impact of these changes may also not become clear, in financial impact terms, until several months after the decisions of the Government are implemented. For these reasons, the financial impact of this Bill may only be broadly estimated at $6.96m in customs revenue forgone per year. It should be noted that bounty assistance is being provided as a result of the Government's decisions of the Temporary Assistance Authority's report on certain air conditioning machines and the Industries Assistance Commission's report on lawnmowers, certain engines and parts. The financial impact of such bounty assistance is not included in the figure quoted above. Administrative amendments contained in the Bill are expected to have little financial impact. In addition, there are no significant administrative costs associated with the measures contained in this Bill. A summary of amendments for each schedule contained in the Bill has been prepared for the information of honourable members. Copies are available in the Bills and Papers Office. I commend the Bill to the House.
