PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill presented by Dr Blewett, and read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Blewett The Hon N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.

This Bill gives effect to the Government's decision which I announced yesterday to amend section 17 of the Health Insurance Act. This section was amended last year as part of the Medicare legislation package because of concern expressed by both Commonwealth and State governments about the lack of controls over rights of private practice in public hospitals. Briefly, section 17 provides that Medicare benefits are not payable in respect of a prescribed medical service rendered to private patients in or at a public hospital unless there is an agreement in writing between the medical practitioner and the public hospital. The agreement must conform to guidelines determined by the Commonwealth Minister for Health. This concern about lack of controls over private practice rights in public hospitals, especially in the area of diagnostic services, is well documented. The previous Government commissioned the Jamison Inquiry into the Efficiency and Administration of Hospitals. That report made the following recommendations:

Recommendation 109: There be an urgent review by each of the employment authorities of rights of private practice in hospitals with a view to limiting its scope, consistent with the underlying intent of the contract between an individual patient and doctor.
Recommendation 111: Steps be taken to phase out over a period of years the right of private practice for full time salaried specialists.
Recommendation 112: Action be taken to improve the awareness of all medical practitioners of the medical value and cost of tests, not only for pathology but for all diagnostic services.
Recommendation 113: Guidelines be issued by health authorities on the utilisation of radiology, pathology and pharmacy services.

These are strong recommendations from what is generally accepted as being a very conservative report. The concern was obviously aroused by the evidence given by many organisations about excess utilisation of diagnostic services in hospitals. Let me quote what the Australian Association of Surgeons told the Jamison Inquiry:

There are cases of patients tested to the point of exhaustion for reasons entirely unknown to their principal medical attendant. There is little doubt that many of these diagnostic testing procedures represent an unwarranted invasion of privacy inflicted on the patient and many of them cause unnecessary suffering and hardship. Their cost to the community is almost inestimable.
This type of statement which was made by several other conservative and respected organisations promoted the Jamison Commission of Inquiry to state in its report:

The Commission realises that patients would want their doctors to explore all available avenues in times of doubt. But the statements above must cause concern to patients, doctors, administrators and governments.
Unfortunately the matter was of no concern to the previous Government, which took no action in this area despite the strong recommendations and evidence of the inquiry that it had commissioned.

This Government does not believe that questions such as the rapidly increasing cost of diagnostic services can be ignored. We are dedicated to the operation of an efficient, high standard health care system, and we intend to provide this through Medicare at a cost that is affordable to the Australian people. It was vital that at the same time as we introduced Medicare we introduced meaningful measures to restrain increases in health costs in some areas. Given the statement I have just quoted from the Surgeons Association, it is not difficult to see why it was decided that the area of diagnostic services was in need of immediate attention.

Some medical specialists have viewed section 17 as a threat to their income and privileges, and as a result they have embarked on a course of industrial action. The Government has made every effort to be reasonable on this issue, as this Bill and the deferral of more controversial matters to the joint Government- Australian Medical Association Penington Committee of Inquiry into Rights of Private Practice in Public Hospitals clearly indicates. However, our overriding responsibility is to ensure that the $2,000m in Medicare benefits paid annually to medical practitioners in this country is wisely and properly spent. For this reason we cannot and will not be deterred from the principle of section 17, or the fairness of the guidelines relating to schedule fee compliance that have already been introduced under the section. These guidelines, which were developed in consultation with State governments, and after considerable discussion and compromise with the AMA, were gazetted on 29 February 1984. These guidelines are not in the form of a regulation and, therefore, under the current legislation not subject to disallowance by the Parliament.

The Government believed this provision for disallowance was unnecessary because the circumstances of doctors' employment in public hospitals made it impossible for any government to use section 17 to impose unreasonable conditions. Firstly, in acting in this area any government would need the co-operation of a majority of the State governments, who would not act to endanger the standards of their own public hospital system. Secondly, the specialists who are at the forefront of this dispute are not salaried specialists. They are independent entrepreneurs who work in the public hospital system only part of the time. If a government were foolish enough to impose unreasonable guidelines under section 17, then these specialists would have an immediate recourse to withdraw to their already established private practices outside public hospitals. They obviously do not need the direct protection of law necessary for a salaried employee.

Thirdly, and most obviously, it would not be in the interests of any government , especially a Labor government, to introduce guidelines that prompted an exodus of specialists from the public hospital system. We are dependent on these people for the excellence of care that is currently provided in our public hospitals. Rights of private practice are an important element in attracting high quality medical staff to the public hospitals. This Government believes that, while some of those private practice rights are in need of reform, it would be counter- productive in the extreme to abolish them.
The points I have just made were summarised in the Sydney Morning Herald's editorial of Saturday, 17 March 1984, as follows:

What, exactly, is at issue in the two-month-old industrial dispute between the doctors and the Federal Government? Is it, as the doctors claim, the unfettered power given to the Federal Health Minister by Section 17 of the Health Insurance Act? Hardly, Dr Blewett's power under Section 17 is certainly no more and probably a great deal less than that of any other employer. In theory he can do almost anything he likes. In practice, he is limited by both the doctors' industrial power and public opinion.

Now that is a realistic statement of the real position in the real world. However, the paranoia and unwarranted fear that the AMA and specialist groups have aroused in the medical profession, in the interests of furthering an industrial dispute over income and privilege, has meant that the Government now finds it necessary to formalise that real world situation into legislation. For that reason I am introducing this Bill as it meets the objections of principle put forward by the medical profession, and should lead to an end to the current industrial disruption before it seriously endangers patient welfare.

Let me remind the House again of the facts about private practice rights in public hospitals. There are a variety of different schemes and arrangements under which salaried doctors exercise rights of private practice. There is lack of detailed knowledge about how such schemes operate, and how a substantial proportion of the funds available under those schemes are applied. It is a fact that receipt of Medicare benefits by salaried hospital specialists provides them with a source of income, over and above their salary determinations. This private practice income is generally accrued during the same working time in which they are employed by the public hospital. This is why it is nonsense for the AMA and those opposite to object to the Commonwealth Government having a say in the conditions under which doctors are employed in public hospitals. Those agreements between hospitals and doctors directly affect the amount of Medicare benefits that the Commonwealth Government is liable to pay. State governments have no direct monetary interest in controlling the amount of private practice work undertaken in public hospitals. However, the four State Labor governments have accepted the reality of the problem and willingly co-operated in the development of guidelines under section 17.

As I have already made clear, this Government has no intention of abolishing rights of private practice arrangements in public hospitals, despite the recommendation of the Jamison Inquiry. Our intention is only to impose reasonable controls to ensure that those rights are not exploited. Our concerns have been greatest about rights of private practice as they relate to diagnostic services, pathology, radiology, radiotherapy, and nuclear medicine. In these areas, there is little if any direct doctor-patient contact, and the patient is usually unaware of the nature and extent of any tests being carried out. This is a high cost area of Medicare which provides substantial scope for generating additional revenue. There is also a significant technical content to these services as provided by the use of public hospital equipment and facilities. It is because these costly facilities are taxpayer-funded that we are expecting a wider degree of public accountability from these diagnostic specialists.

The Government has made no secret of the fact, from before the legislation passed by this Parliament in September last year, that Medicare benefits would be payable for these diagnostic services provided in public hospitals, only if the service was provided in accordance with an agreement between the doctor and the public hospital. Prior to that, the Government had commenced negotiations with the Australian Medical Association.

The initial draft guidelines proposed that all agreements would require certain things. I apologise to the House for the need to go through this matter in detail but it is important that the attitude taken by the Government be fully understood by all members of this House and by the public. The initial draft guidelines proposed that all agreements would require:
(a) All accounts to be raised by the hospital on behalf of the doctor.
(b) All charges to be at or below schedule fee.
(c) All revenue received for diagnostic services rendered under private practice contracts for full time specialists in a particular hospital to be treated as one fund.
(d) The fund to be applied in the following order:
(1) Facility charges, recovery of costs, to the hospital in a form acceptable to the Commonwealth Minister.
(2) Drawings by the doctor at a level determined by the State, up to 25 per cent of full time specialist salary.
(3) Any residual to be applied following guidelines set by the State Ministers for Health.
The purpose of those guidelines was, firstly:

To standardise private practice rights for full time salaried staff. In most States, the 25 per cent limit already applied, except in New South Wales where some more generous arrangements applied in some cases.
(Quorum formed)
The objective of the guidelines was secondly:

To reduce incentives for visiting private practitioners to request and perform tests. In some areas where there is a shortage of salaried staff, visiting practitioners perform most, if not all, the radiological or pathology services. This means that the fee for services payment systems allow these practitioners to generate substantial income. In such circumstances, it was reasonable to introduce income restraints as they meant that necessary diagnostic services would be performed at a more reasonable cost to taxpayers. These guidelines were in no sense harsh by community standards since they did not have any effect until an income of about $62,500 per annum was reached.
Because of the AMA's dissatisfaction with these arrangements, a further proposal , inter alia, was made on income levels. It was proposed that:
For full time, salaried staff:
(i) Drawings by the doctor, up to 25 per cent of the salary of a senior specialist, which would allow about $12,000 per annum for private practice on top of a salary of about $50,000 per annum.
For visiting, private practitioners:
(i) Full drawings by the doctor, up to 125 per cent of the salary of a senior specialist-about $62,500 per annum.

(ii) From 125 per cent to 175 per cent of the senior specialist salary-that is, from about $62,500 to $87,500 per annum-the doctor can draw 75 per cent of the earnings above $62,500 per annum and leave 25 per cent in the fund.
(iii) About 175 per cent of the senior specialist salary-that is, about $87,500 per annum-the doctor can draw 60 per cent of the earnings above $87,500 per annum and leave 40 per cent in the fund.
Any residual remaining in the fund to be applied for purposes such as education , equipment or other development activities under guidelines set by the State Health Minister.

These more generous limits were still not acceptable to the AMA. On 11 January 1984, I met with representatives of the AMA about their objections. On 24 January, I announced that the Government would defer implementation of the income restraint guidelines. I also announced that there would be a committee of inquiry into rights of private practice in public hospitals under the chairmanship of Professor David Penington, Dean of the Faculty of Medicine at Melbourne University. The Commonwealth and the AMA were each to nominate a member to constitute a committee of three. I also announced that the introduction of the section 17 arrangements would be deferred from 1 February to 1 March to allow for further negotiation, and to allow a reasonable implementation period for doctors and State health authorities.

I met with the AMA again on 9 February 1984. The AMA's attention has now turned to the Minister's 'unfettered powers' under section 17 to alter their conditions . As indicated previously, it is not in any government's interests to introduce guidelines which change agreements so significantly as to drive doctors out of the public hospital system. Therefore, in negotiations with the AMA in February, it was agreed that terms of reference for the Penington Inquiry would include consultative procedures prior to variation of the guidelines, and appeal or review procedures in relation to these arrangements. I also guaranteed that the guidelines would not be altered or extended until the report of the Inquiry had been considered.

The AMA's other objection was that the new national list of facility charges for the prescribed diagnostic items meant increases in those charges in some States for some services. Again, the Government agreed to refer the question of a national list of facility charges to the Inquiry, and to allow the existing State facility charges to remain in force until the Inquiry reported. The AMA's only concession in all these negotiations was to agree on 16 February to participate in the Inquiry. Following this further meeting on 16 February, the Federal President of the AMA, Dr Thompson, publicly stated that the Government's concessions and the Inquiry had provided a real basis for resolution of the dispute. However, the Government proposals were rejected by a meeting of the AMA and specialist groups on 22 February 1984.
This situation necessitated joint action by the Ministers for Health in New South Wales, Victoria, South Australia and Western Australia to ensure that:
No practitioners providing diagnostic services would charge more than the schedule fee for services in public hospitals after 1 March 1984;
no patient would be denied access to public hospital services and no diagnostician would be prevented from rendering services to his or her patients in a public hospital; and

the medical benefit schedule fee would not be required to be included in agreements under section 17 where a State took action to ensure that the schedule fee was charged for diagnostic services through these limited price control measures.

The guidelines which were introduced on 29 February were revised to ensure that the only significant requirement for the agreements between the hospital and the doctor was that charges raised be at or below the schedule fee. This is not a government fee. It is a fee set annually by an independent arbitrator after hearing argument from Government, the AMA and other interested parties.

Despite all the concessions made, in an effort to reach a settlement, the AMA was still being intransigent, so a meeting was held on 2 March with the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) present. At that meeting, the Prime Minister offered:

(1) To give an undertaking in writing that during the period of the Penington Committee Inquiry, there would be no change of any sort in the guidelines as gazetted on 29 February 1984 or in the details of their applications.

(2) With respect to the recommendations of the Penington Committee relating to appeal and review procedures, the Government would advise the Penington Committee that the Government has no objection to recommendations providing for such procedures and will accept the recommendation of the Inquiry on that matter .
In return, the Government sought an assurance that the AMA would recommend to the members of the profession:

(1) That they sign written agreements in accordance with current guidelines, with particular emphasis on the guidelines relating to charging at or below the schedule fee, where such agreements do not already exist.
(2) That there be no discrimination against Medicare only patients in recognised hospitals.

The Federal AMA again agreed that this was reasonable and took the Prime Minister's proposal to a further meeting of its State branches, and other medical organisations. This compromise offered by the Prime Minister was also rejected at these meetings. The AMA and some specialist organisations have now rejected all attempts at a negotiated settlement, and embarked on a campaign of industrial action in an effort to have their total demands met.

Because the Government had twice reached near agreement with the Federal AMA on proposals to resolve the dispute, we believed it was necessary to have a round table conference with all the major groups concerned in the dispute. Several attempts to arrange a meeting of myself and State Health Ministers with the Federal and State branches of the AMA and the College of Radiologists have failed, because the medical profession has refused to attend. Senator Haines of the Australian Democrats put forward a constructive proposal which would give immediate substance to the Prime Minister's undertaking of 2 March to institute appeal provisions into section 17. The Government has adopted that proposal in this Bill, and there can be no argument that the Minister's powers under section 17 are considerably fettered and restricted-both formally through legislation as well as in the practical reality which I earlier mentioned.

The first amendment of section 17 inserts in it a new sub-section (1a) for the purpose of enabling the Minister, if he is satisfied that the laws of a State or Territory, or agreements or arrangements entered into under such laws, are such as will regulate the rendering of a prescribed professional service in a manner consistent with the guidelines, to sign an instrument exempting a medical practitioner from the requirement to enter into an agreement of the kind referred to. The second amendment adds sub-sections (5), (6), (7), and (8) at the end of section 17. These provisions will enable the guidelines that have been made by the Minister under section 17, and any guidelines that the Minister makes in the future, to be disallowed in the Parliament in the same way as a statutory rule may be disallowed.

By these measures, the two practical objectives of this Bill are achieved. The first is to provide for parliamentary scrutiny of the power of the Minister for Health to make guidelines. This is the constructive proposal put forward by Senator Haines, and in practice it would mean that the Senate would have power to disallow any guidelines put forward by the Minister that it felt were unreasonable. This meets the major objection of principle put forward by the medical profession. The second objective is to give the option of Medicare benefits being payable either where there is an agreement in writing between the hospital and the doctor or where state legislation or regulation ensures that the guidelines are complied with. This amendment gives greater flexibility to allow Medicare benefits to be payable, and is designed to protect patients in what is essentially a dispute between Government and the medical profession. The Government believes that these measures are appropriate because our objective has always been to ensure compliance with the schedule fee and instituting other reasonable reforms to private practice rights in public hospitals-rather than to get signatures on pieces of paper.

In addition, the Cabinet has agreed in principle to regular arbitrated review of the schedule fee, and has authorised me to enter into negotiations with the AMA to achieve this. This should dispel another piece of paranoia now abroad in the medical profession that, having secured compliance with the schedule fee, the Government would then allow the schedule fee to stagnate for some years. The speed with which the Government moved to secure an arbitrated interim fee increase once the wage pause was ended should also establish the bona fides of the Government in this matter.

I have noted the comments of the Federal President of the AMA, Dr Thompson, that parliamentary scrutiny is not sufficient because at some future time a government may also have a majority in the Senate. I point out that such a situation could not occur in the time before the Penington Inquiry reports. The guarantee that the Prime Minister and I gave on 2 March still stands. That is, that the Government will implement whatever consultative and appeal mechanisms are recommended by the Penington Inquiry. That remains a term of reference for the inquiry, and the AMA and other medical groups will have ample opportunity to put forward any other consultative and appeal proposals they feel are desirable. The Government will not extend its guidelines beyond schedule fee compliance for diagnostic services during the period of the Penington Inquiry.

I believe that the AMA and other medical groups should accept this Bill as substantially achieving their aims in relation to appeal rights under section 17 . It is obvious that any Federal government would find it impossible to introduce unreasonable guidelines under section 17 because it would require the consent of both Houses of Federal Parliament, and also the agreement of State parliaments to any complementary legislation or regulations made by State governments.

The Federal Government has no intention of submitting to all the demands made by the AMA. We believe that schedule fee compliance by diagnostic specialists in public hospitals is fair and reasonable, and we will not be withdrawing that guideline. The Government has a responsibility to act in the public interest, and to ensure that taxpayers' money provided through the one per cent levy is properly spent. Nor will the Government abandon the principle of section 17 which is designed to ensure that the public hospital system is not exploited by private interests.

The problem with resolving this dispute has been that while the Government has negotiated in good faith, and made several compromises in an effort to resolve it, the AMA has offered nothing. It has not passed on the details of all these concessions to its membership, and this has served to create misunderstanding and inflame emotions in the profession generally. The current industrial strife should now cease. The introduction of this Bill is a positive step by the Government to seek a resolution of the dispute before the current industrial action which is causing inconvenience to patients escalates to a point where it could endanger patients. I hope that the majority at least of the medical profession will accept this public act of good faith by the Government, and cease the current industrial action in the best interests of their patients' welfare. This legislation will provide the immediate safeguards the profession has sought, and the Penington Inquiry provides a proper opportunity for them to raise any further concerns they may have. I commend the Bill to the House.
Debate (on motion by Mr Carlton) adjourned.

TALK.START.PARA: —in reply-In closing this debate I would like first to thank all those honourable members of the House who participated in the debate. I think there was a general recognition of the seriousness of the threats in this area and of the appropriateness of the Government's response. I also welcome the fact that the honourable member for Mackellar (Mr Carlton) displayed an unusual attitude of consensus, at least on this measure within my portfolio. I also thank very much the honourable member for Eden-Monaro (Mr Snow) and the honourable member for Grayndler (Mr Leo McLeay ), who stressed some of the quite constructive points about the need for further education in the quarantine area. They stressed that there should be better education on exotic diseases. More general education programs were suggested by the honourable member for Grayndler. I was also glad that all honourable members of the House welcomed the reduction of the burden of the Governor-General by the new system of appointing quarantine officers. The honourable member for Mackellar and other honourable members raised the question of surveillance in the northern area. I have to say that the point raised by the honourable member for Mackellar-that is, the cessation of radar in March-was relevant only for immigration purposes for refugees. The coastal surveillance aircraft, the littoral surveillance for quarantine, have been since fitted with ground mapping mode radar which now maintains more effective coverage for quarantine purposes. This Government has undertaken a major review of coastal surveillance arrangements, the outcome of which is at present under consideration.

SPEECH.PARA: The honourable member for Gippsland (Mr McGauran) raised a few critical points which I would like briefly to answer. He was somewhat concerned about the level of examination of shoes and clothing of passengers returning from Japan in relation to possible exotic diseases. The point here is that resources are allocated in relation to the dangers of foot and mouth disease particularly. Japan's freedom from foot and mouth disease means that not as much attention is given to the examination of passengers embarking from Japan because priority is given to goods and persons from major risk areas; that is, countries with high levels of foot and mouth disease.

The honourable member for Gippsland was also worried about the allocation of quarantine responsibility to the Department of Health and not to the Department of Primary Industry as the Government had promised at the election. Let me say that this has been a complex issue which has faced governments for a long time. The previous Government had it on its plate for several years following a recommendation from a Senate committee of inquiry and it failed to bring any resolution. This Government has been actively studying the allocation of quarantine responsibility. Submissions in relation to this matter are now before the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke). It is important, however, that before any changes are considered continuance of the important links between the three parts of quarantine-animal, plant and human quarantine-is assured.

Finally, there was an expression of disquiet by the honourable member for Gippsland about certain aspects of advertising more quarantine education in relation to passengers coming to Australia. Qantas Airways Ltd now shows quarantine films on flights en route to Australia though this is as yet not technically feasible for other airlines. However, all aircraft make an approved quarantine statement to passengers on landing. I would also like to point out that my Department's quarantine publicity program on which we spent $350,000 in 1983-84, is being altered to concentrate on arriving passengers, including tourists and will be centred on arrival areas of airports. We now print this publicity material in more than 20 languages. I hope that I have responded to the points which were made by honourable members in what was a useful debate.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam Deputy Speaker, may I have your indulgence to suggest that the House have a general debate covering this Bill and the Torres Strait Fisheries Bill 1983 as they are related measures . SPEECH.SPEAKER: MacKellar The Hon M.J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —The passage of this legislation is an historic development in the constitutional history of Australia. We have, as a nation, only one international territorial boundary, and that is the boundary which is defined in this treaty between Australia and Papua New Guinea. These pieces of legislation define the elements in this relationship which will govern the conduct of our relations in practical matters in the Torres Strait; that is, our border region with Papua New Guinea.

SPEECH.PARA: The border region between one country and another can attract problems which, if there is no system for dealing effectively with them as they arise, can become grave irritants in relations between neighbours. The question of defining the rights of Australia and New Guinea in the border region was never seen as a pressing issue whilst Papua New Guinea was a colony of Australia. But with independence, the issue became one of very considerable significance.

In 1879 islands lying to the south of New Guinea were annexed. A line was drawn with considerable imprecision between the coastline and Papua and islands immediately to the south, notably Boigu, Saibai and Dauan. Anyone who looks at the map will see that their northern coastlines lie in the three-mile territorial sea. So the 1879 line came into existence. It was not a line of delineation which carefully identified the boundary between Papua and Australia. There were a number of subsequent efforts made since 1879 to draw a line which would precisely establish a boundary which could be given international recognition. Successive Queensland governments could not agree, for a variety of different reasons, on where such a boundary might run. Efforts to do anything about it were abandoned until 1972 when, to his great credit, the Prime Minister , Mr Whitlam, opened up the matter with Queensland and Papua New Guinea. But the notion that the 1879 line was a 'border' had come to be firmly fixed in the minds of many Australians.

The islands of Boigu, Saibai and Dauan were inhabited, and the islanders were Australian citizens. Many of the islanders crossed the narrow straits, and even fished and farmed on the mainland. Also, citizens of Papua New Guinea moved through these islands and fished deep into the reefs on the Torres Strait. A complete social and cultural life had been developed by people of both countries who moved freely and sociably into the Torres Strait. But the inhabitants of the islands, who knew full well their rights as Australian citizens, had no desire either to lose their rights as Australian citizens or their traditional way of life, with its free movement and stable social system. So when they became aware that there was to be a major review of the Torres Strait question, and negotiations with Papua New Guinea would ensue, they became particularly, and understandably, worried. They could not see why the 1879 line could not be confirmed as the border. But even an initial effort by the Federal Government to take that position would have created grave problems for Papua New Guinea, particularly as there were maps in existence showing the 1879 line virtually on the Papua New Guinea coastline.

Although the Whitlam Government recognised that point, there was very little effort made to convince Queensland that any insistence on the 1879 line was detrimental to Queensland and Australian prospects for a productive negotiation. Mr Whitlam gave every impression that he would prefer to see a settlement imposed by the International Court. With this end in mind, he caused reservations to the jurisdiction of the International Court to be removed. This step opened the way for Australia to be taken before the court by Papua New Guinea, if negotiations failed.

It would have been one thing for Australia to be involved with a neighbour in litigation before the International Court on a non-territorial matter; it would have been highly divisive to have the court involved in determining an unresolved territorial dispute between Australia and Papua New Guinea. Fortunately, wiser counsels prevailed, and the way was cleared for Dr Coombs and Mr Allan Griffith to lead discussions between Queensland and the Commonwealth and to draw up proposals for negotiation with Papua New Guinea.

Dr Coombs advanced the concept of the Torres Strait area north of islands on the Cape York Peninsula being developed as an environmental zone, a zone which would conserve the resources of the region and the culture of the indigenous inhabitants. It proved both a brilliant and productive concept. Initial public exposure of the concept drew positive interest from Papua New Guinea. The Queensland Parliament became interested and on 3 April 1974, the Queensland Parliament passed a resolution calling on the Commonwealth Government to enter into treaty negotiations with Papua New Guinea for the establishment of a marine park.

It is clear that the concepts were legally different, but the essential element in the parliamentary resolution was that the Parliament of Queensland recognised the necessity for treaty negotiations, and for a special regime in the Torres Strait to be based on conservation principles. This development was to prove of crucial importance, as it facilitated wide-ranging discussions between Commonwealth and Queensland officials. These discussions proceeded for over two years before a concept was fully defined which could become a negotiating framework with Papua New Guinea. Central to the whole concept was the setting apart, in the Torres Strait, of an environmentally protected zone within and around which the rights of the Commonwealth of Australia and Papua New Guinea would be defined.

At Annex 6 of the Treaty is a map which charts the protected zone boundaries. The southern boundary of the zone includes islands north of the Thursday Island group, and the north boundary includes the islands off the coast of Papua New Guinea, which form part of the traditional pattern of activity of the people. The northern boundary takes in the coast of Papua at the northern end of the Torres Strait. Within this zone, three concepts of law apply. I have referred to the problems that arose out of the 1879 line, and the fact that this line could not serve to delineate the territory of Australia.

As a result of the Treaty, the territory of Papua New Guinea and Australia is separated by a territorial sea boundary, which for the main part is a median line between the islands of Boigu, Dauan and Saibai. Thus it is this line which replaced the 1879 line. This boundary lies to the south of the protected zone boundary, which is not a territorial boundary. The islanders in the Torres Strait and the coastal Papuans each have traditional rights of movement in the protected zone and this traditional activity is not interrupted by the territorial sea boundary contained within the zone. And this benefit is reconciled with the necessity to uphold quarantine, immigration and customs arrangements covered by these legislative amendments.

When the 1879 line was conceived, the concept of a maritime territorial boundary was not a developed international concept. But as the law on the territorial sea developed, it was later extended by a special convention defining rights in the continental shelf, that part of the slope of the seabed off an island or continent within the 200 metre mark before it drops into the seabed.

Special rights to minerals and sedentary fish were accorded the coastal state. Both Australia and Papua New Guinea were signatories of the Geneva Convention on the Continental Shelf and the Convention envisaged negotiation between countries sharing the shelf. In the Torres Strait the shelf is shared by Papua New Guinea and Australia. In accordance with the Geneva Convention a line was negotiated in basic principles of a median line. This boundary is well to the south of the territorial boundary. The consequential legislation, which adjusts our seabed rights, limiting them considerably, is comprehended by the amendments here proposed for the Petroleum (Submerged Lands) Act 1967 and the Continental Shelf (Living Natural Resources) Act 1968.

A further and major aspect of international law emerged in the late 1960s and 1970s, with a consolidation of the law of territorial sea and the seabed, and a new concept of maritime law, the 200 mile exclusive economic zone. This concept of the 200 mile exclusive economic zone gave fishing rights to the coastal states, and accorded the coastal state responsibilities for conservation and environmental protection. Again, the emergence of this new concept enables a separate negotiation to be undertaken to the shared rights of Papua New Guinea and Australia in the Torres Strait. The separate fisheries jurisdiction line is identical with the seabed line, except in the Torres Strait area in the protected zone, where it is drawn to include the islands of Boigu, Dauan and Saibai. The reason for this is obvious. But concessions had to be made in order to obtain a sensible balance between the rights of Papua New Guinea and Australia. If every island in the Torres Strait owned by Australia was given a territorial sea of 12 miles, the fishing rights of Papua New Guinea would virtually have been extinguished.

So the islands did not extend the territorial sea beyond three miles and the fishing jurisdiction line is designed to restore rights to the islands which were lost to them in the decision to hold to a 3 mile territorial sea. The fishing administrations of both countries are involved in balancing the conservation of species on which the traditional fisherman depends for a subsistence livelihood with the requirements of commercial fishermen.

It is understandable that judgments will differ on problems of conservation. Even in parts of Australia, where there has been a sustained application of research, knowledge, and experience, serious problems arise when it comes to making judgments, balancing conservation with exploitation. No one should pretend that the administration of this aspect of the Treaty will be free of problems. This legislation empowers the Minister for Primary Industry (Mr Kerin) to regulate commercial fishing by prohibition of certain activities; by setting legal minimum or maximum lengths of fish; prohibition on the use of specified equipment, reserving certain fisheries for the local community; controlling particular gear; and controlling the number of people fishing from a particular kind of boat. And what we do has to be co-ordinated with the administrative arrangements of Papua New Guinea if the zone arrangements are to work to the purpose of the conservation objectives. Moreover, the Australian position has to be co-ordinated between the Commonwealth and the State. A joint Commonwealth- State authority will administer policies to ensure a co-ordinated approach. The main aim is to keep the condition of fisheries under review, to formulate forward policies and plans.

What has been worked out between the Commonwealth and the State and between Australia and Papua New Guinea is a very great tribute to the process of negotiation and consultation. This work was put in place by the previous Government and it serves as a very important example of the capacity of co- operative federalism to work in international affairs. It gives the lie to the trend emphasised by this Government which seeks to dispose of State interests and views by overriding them. I am sure, for instance, that if the Government were to use both strength and patience in setting up a crimes commission, Australia's reputation internationally would be enhanced, and the benefit to the Australian taxpayer of more effective law enforcement in the area of major international crimes of drug smuggling. There can be no doubt that the simplistic view with which Canberra entered into the negotiations for a Torres Strait Treaty were enhanced by a vigorous negotiation and dialogue with the State of Queensland and with Papua New Guinea.

At this stage I would mention that my colleague the shadow Minister for Primary Industry will be suggesting that clause 39, page 26, should be clarified to strengthen the consultative intent of that particular clause. I hope that it will be received by the Government as a constructive clarification within the full spirit of the legislation.

Negotiations began in 1972, concluded in 1978, and were implemented by this legislation in 1984, illustrating I think very clearly the complexity of the subject matter. But, as I have said, the issue of Australia's only border region , is so fundamental that the care, the time, and the patience invested in it is more than amply justified, as the decisions will hold in place a vital relationship with our neighbour, colleague and friend, Papua New Guinea.

Finally, the coming to reality of this Treaty owes much to a number of distinguished Australians and Papua New Guineans. But from the Australian side, the Treaty is a lasting achievement to the present Leader of the Opposition (Mr Peacock) whose task it was to conduct the negotiations through its many complexities, and will be duly marked down as such in our history books. It is a durable result of his distinguished work as Foreign Minister. It is with very considerable pleasure that I, on behalf of the Opposition, support the passage of this historic legislation.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lindsay Mr E.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam Deputy Speaker, I congratulate you on your election as Deputy Speaker and Chairman of Committees. I am sure you will discharge those responsibilities with fearless independence. I look forward to speaking in this House under your chairmanship for many years to come.

SPEECH.PARA: It was in 1975 that Papua New Guinea became an independent nation. At about this time, much discussion took place among countries belonging to the South Pacific Forum on a proposal to establish 200 nautical mile exclusive economic or fishing zones in accordance with developing international law. The implications of such discussions were sufficient to impel the governments of Australia and Papua New Guinea in 1977 to accelerate negotiations to agree on a maritime boundary that would equitably divide their national rights over fisheries and seabed resources in the area where their 200 nautical mile zones would overlap.

The Torres Strait Treaty covers the whole area between Australia and Papua New Guinea. This extends some 2,000 kilometres from the Arafura Sea through the Torres Strait and out into the Coral Sea. In Torres Strait, Australia and Papua New Guinea share a common continental shelf. Australia and Papua New Guinea also share a common desire that all human activity in the Strait be conducive to further developing close and neighbourly relations.

It could be said that the saga of the Treaty began in 1859 when Queensland was separated from New South Wales by letters patent which annexed to Queensland ' all and every the adjacent islands their members and appurtenances in the Pacific Ocean'. However, in 1872 the British Colonial Office defined Queensland jurisdiction as extending to all islands within 60 miles of its coasts.

In the 1870s there was no established government in Papua and therefore no authority to regulate traffic through Torres Strait or to control the activities of Europeans moving into the northern Torres Strait Islands. With the establishment of the Protectorate of British New Guinea, Queensland no longer had the same interest in controlling the Torres Strait Islands or in meeting the expense of maintaining government ships in the Strait. Years of dithering followed. It was not until 1925 that new letters patent specifically restated Queensland's claim to all islands in the Strait. But the letters patent did not solve the question of whether the three islands of Kawa, Mata Kawa and Kussa were part of Queensland or belonged to Papua New Guinea. Papua New Guinea sovereignty over these islands is now recognised by this Treaty.

Australia will maintain sovereignty over all the islands within the 'correct' original colonial boundary. Full consultation with the Torres Strait Islanders took place during the negotiations. This has led to an agreement which protects the interests of the traditional inhabitants to their satisfaction. The Treaty also provides for consultative arrangements with Papua New Guinea on a continuing basis with the Islanders fully represented. The coastal Papuans have also accepted the Treaty.

A major feature of the Treaty is the establishment of a protected zone to maintain the traditional way of life of the Islanders and the local coastal Papuans. Both the Islanders and the coastal Papuans will have traditional fishing rights and freedom of movement within the zone. This zone will run from north of Thursday Island to the existing border.

The Torres Strait Treaty not only involves the creation of a maritime boundary with Papua New Guinea but also it will offer the legislative framework to regulate the activities of economic development in the Torres Strait. Considerable administrative and economic changes will have major significance to the Torres Strait Islanders. These traditional inhabitants have occupied this region since time immemorial. They are the original owners of the land. Long ago they established a customary right to harvest the resources of the sea and the seabed. The people known as Torres Strait Islanders are, as the Treaty provides, citizens of Australia. They are of indigenous descent. The Hawke Government, an authentic Australian government, can justly claim the title of protector of the legitimate interests of Australian citizens of indigenous descent. The Treaty will endeavour to maintain for the traditional inhabitants of the Torres Strait their traditional and customary associations, their continued opportunity to obtain subsistence and livelihood from the protected zone and the preservation and protection of their social, cultural and religious traditions.

The Torres Strait Treaty (Miscellaneous Amendments) Bill 1983 should never become a measurable financial burden on the Australian Government. It does, however, amend 10 Federal Acts. Briefly, the effect of each of its amendments are as follows: The Fisheries Act 1952 and the Continental Shelf (Living Natural Resources) Act 1968, are amended to provide that those Acts shall not apply in the future to the protected zone and to any waters outside the zone proclaimed to be waters in which the Torres Strait Fisheries Bill applies to a particular fishery. Enforcement staff will be able to cross protected zones without diminution of their authority. In addition this Bill amends the Fisheries Act to preclude any arrangement under that Act from having an effect in relation to the relevant fishery. Furthermore, the Fisheries Act is amended to permit a Papua New Guinea boat that has right of entry under the Torres Strait Fisheries Act to land its catch in any place in Australia. This authority will not be a right that Papua New Guinea boats will have automatically. Such authority will be granted in specific cases only.

The Coral Sea Islands Act 1969 is amended to realign the area that includes the Coral Sea Islands territory and to give effect to the boundaries agreed upon under the Treaty. Another amendment provides that the relevant territory may be defined by reference to the Australian geodetic datum which will enable the points to be more accurately plotted on the earth's surface.

There is to be no hindrance by any party to the Treaty to the free movement and performance of traditional activities by traditional inhabitants in the protected zone and its declared vicinity as a result of established Customs procedures. Section 30A of the Customs Act is inserted to secure this provision. Controls will still obtain with respect to narcotic drugs. Certain goods relevant to the Treaty will be exempt from Customs duties, as a result of an amendment to the Customs Tariff Act. The Historic Shipwrecks Act 1976 is amended to provide that Papua New Guinea wrecks of special significance are granted adequate protection by the law. Compliance with entry permit requirements for Papua New Guinea traditional inhabitants engaged in traditional activities in the protected zone are exempt as a result of an amendment to the Migration Act 1958. However, persons who have a criminal record or prescribed disease, or who have been deported or excluded from Australia or another country in the past will not be exempt from entry permit requirements.

The technical amendment to the Petroleum (Submerged Lands) Act 1967 will align the northern boundary of the Queensland adjacent area with the Torres Strait Treaty seabed line. There is to be a prohibition of mining and oil drilling of the seabed in the protected zone for 10 years from the date of entry into force of the Treaty.

Of particular importance are the amendments to the Quarantine Act. Under this Bill the Governor-General is empowered to make special provision for traditional inhabitants going about their traditional activities and for their vessels and boats. A traditional inhabitant may bring into a part of Australia that is in the protected zone goods which may be used in connection with the performance of a traditional activity. Traditional vessels will be allowed free movement in and around those parts of Australia that are within the protected zone.

It is acknowledged that the Torres Strait is a potential gateway to Australia for various insect pests and diseases affecting humans, animals and plants from which Australia is free at present. One such pest, the screw worm fly, if allowed in Australia, would create devastation for Australia's livestock industry. The cost of eradicating such diseases and pests would be monumental. The losses to our overseas markets and primary industries as a result of intrusion of pests and diseases would be colossal.

Notwithstanding the recognition under the Treaty of those activities which have been conducted within the protected zone since time immemorial, the Hawke Government is determined never to relax its vigilance to protect Australia's quarantine security. Both Australia and Papua New Guinea will retain the right to implement national controls to prevent possible abuse.

Amendments to the Wildlife Protection (Regulation of Export and Imports) Act 1982 acknowledge that the killing of certain wildlife for subsistence and cultural purposes is an important traditional activity recognised by the Treaty. Indigenous fauna and flora which are or may become threatened with extinction will be protected as far as possible. This obligation has also been accepted by the Papua New Guinea Government.

The Torres Strait will always be a strategic sea lane for world shipping. Total tonnage of coastal shipping using the Torres Strait during the financial year 1981-2 amounted to 6.2 million tonnes. Regular patrols by Australian Navy ships highlight the continual need for vigilance by each party to the treaty to the threat of illegal immigration, illegal trafficking in protected flora and fauna and of any potential military threat.

The Torres Strait Fisheries Bill 1983 implements fisheries aspects of the Torres Strait Treaty. The Treaty requires Australia and Papua New Guinea, when licensing fishing operations, to have regard to the desirability of promoting economic development in the Torres Strait and implementing opportunities for traditional inhabitants. Consultations are to be had with traditional inhabitants with respect to licensing arrangements for commercial fisheries. In addition, fishermen and boats of either country may fish in a protected zone commercial fishery in waters where either country's laws apply. In order to obtain this right a fisherman will need to obtain a licence from his government of nationality to operate a boat in that fishery in waters or areas of the seabed under its jurisdiction.

Unless both Australia and Papua New Guinea agree, joint ventures involving equity participation by a third country, or joint or national enterprises involving the use of a third country vessel, or a vessel of either party with a crew of substantial third country nationals, will not be permitted in protected zone commercial fisheries. Fishermen who breach the fishery law of either country anywhere in the protected zone can be prosecuted in the courts of their country of nationality only. Fishermen in waters beyond the protected zone and under the jurisdiction of the other country-
