DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Australian Broadcasting Corporation: FM Broadcasts-Export of Live Sheep- Insurance-Medicare Dispute-Domestic Air Fares-Resource Rent Tax-Meat Inspection Charges

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Mr SPEAKER

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! It being 7.30 p.m., I propose the question:

INTERJECT.PARA: That the House do now adjourn.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Braithwaite Mr R.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —Tonight I draw the attention of the House to problems with AM and FM programs of the Australian Broadcasting Corporation in one of the fastest expanding radio and television audiences in Australia, and that is the the region of Mackay which has a population of over 100,000 people. It is expanding at the rate of over 3 per cent a year which is greater than the average growth rate of Australia or Queensland. Yet this growth region is serviced by ABC AM radio on equipment which is sufficient only for the population in the region 37 years ago.

SPEECH.PARA: FM radio is not even a hope. Although FM is broadcast from Rockhampton and Townsville and overpasses Mackay, the Department of Communications has consistently denied Mackay the opportunity of receiving FM radio broadcasts. I was given to understand that the equipment had been acquired for that purpose but it was eventually passed on to some other centre. Other regional centres of population on the Queensland coast, less than one-half the size of Mackay, have had the ABC FM service for a number of years. One must ask: Why not Mackay? I have persistently brought this matter to the attention of Ministers in this House. The most recent occasion was on 29 February 1984 when I gave a notice of motion. For this and other comments I have made I have received support from my constituents. I have received the following letter which I believe justifies the complaints I have made. The letter states:

I am an occasional visitor to your home city of Mackay, Queensland, on the course of business. I was therefore interested to note your concern in the reception of AM radio from the ABC and the lack of an FM radio station in the Mackay district.

In the course of my business activities, I travel to many parts of Australia and find the ABC's news coverage and programming generally to be of considerable value in keeping me up to date with events from the current affairs programs and the new programs . . .

I have found in Mackay that reception on the ABC's AM stations is generally not all that good and on my most recent visit found it very difficult to get good reception for new broadcasts, current affairs programs . . .

I can therefore only say I have to support you in your efforts to obtain a better standard of AM reception for the constituents in your area and I deplore the absence of an FM station for the presentation of quality music programs that the ABC FM stations provide . . .
Kindest regards,

Since the installation of the original and still existing 4QA transmitters in 1947-48 the demographics of the region have changed considerably. It is not only Mackay city and the Pioneer Shire which have experienced fairly dramatic population increases over the past 30 years but also some of the large outlying towns to the west of Mackay. The signal from 4QA Mackay is just not acceptable to this expanded region and population. As I have said, FM radio is non-existent .

Compounding the reception problems from the 4QA transmitters is the fact that the major proportion of equipment, such as draglines, conveyor equipment, et cetera, used by the mining industry in those areas operates from CEB power and in doing so creates tremendous amounts of radio frequency interference. The coalfields news broadcast by 4QA has no chance of being received by the mining population although it has strong historical and commercial links with Mackay. For good reception a repeater transmitter needs to be located in that area. It is ironical that news items gathered from the areas cannot be received there from 4QA broadcasts.

Station 4QA's two-kilowatt power transmitters were installed in 1947. That was 37 years ago and no upgrading has taken place since. The equipment can only be described as geriatric. I have been told that both of these transmitters are kept going on a day to day basis by making modifications and rewiring where necessary as spare parts are unobtainable. Replacement output valves are virtually unobtainable. Again the irony of the present situation is that station 4QN at Townsville achieves far better signal strength into the Mackay hinterland than 4QA, yet this region is within 70 kilometres of Mackay and over 300 kilometres from Townsville.

A complete reassessment of signal strength needs for the Mackay basin and its rapidly expanding hinterland is urgently required. The most cost effective answer, although possibly not the most satisfactory answer to the problems I have outlined would be the immediate installation of a new breed 10-kilowatt transmitter. Consideration should be given to a more efficient RF radiator and the placing of a 4QA radio transmitter of two to five kilowatts on the western plains to serve the mining areas, the grain and beef growers and the Southern Hemisphere's top tourist area, the Whitsunday region. In spite of the tremendous growth and potential of the Mackay region it is being thrust into a cultural backwater by the neglect of the Department of Communications.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kent Mr L.

TALK.START.PARA: —A couple of days ago I had a visit by the owner of a boning room, Magtoth Nominees of Braeside. He complained that his firm, which employs 10 people, is being squeezed out of the market because of imports of boned mutton from New Zealand. He finds it hard to compete as Australian sheep are scarce on the market and he has to pay high prices for them. It is interesting to note that he came to see me on Monday. On the same morning I listened to a news item which reported that 120,000 live sheep were being loaded on the sheep carrier Al Qurain in Portland for export to the Middle East. It struck me as rather odd that on the one hand we are importing processed mutton from New Zealand while on the other hand we export live sheep. No wonder the Victorian meatworkers headed by their leader Wally Curran, were in Portland and were exposed to the blustery wind and rain picketing the loading of live sheep. By their action they are drawing the attention of the Australian people to the uncontrolled live sheep export that is having a disastrous effect on our meat industry and is causing heavy unemployment amongst meat workers.

SPEECH.PARA: Victoria has a large meat industry based on sheep and lamb killing. It was developed on the insistence of the rural sector to provide more killing space. Millions of dollars have been invested in facilities for the benefit of the rural sector. Yet today the Victorian Farmers and Graziers Association is supporting the uncontrolled export of live sheep, thus throwing thousands of meat workers out of jobs. The following works, which would employ a large number of people in sheep or lamb killing are not operating; Shepparton meatworks, Champion meatworks, Newport, Ballarat, Corio meatworks, Smorgons, Richmond abattoirs, Borthwicks at Brooklyn, Borthwicks at Portland, J. H. Ralph's and R. J. Gilbertson's. The abattoirs at Camperdown, Wodonga and Dromana are working on a reduced production from 50 per cent to a third, and, in some cases, they are killing only beef or calves.

The continuing escalation of live exports out of Portland is shown by the following figures: To December 1979, 206,330 cattle were exported. By December 1983, 1,509,907 cattle had been exported. From September 1983 to l March 1984, 9l7,000 cattle were exported from Portland. While this lunacy of exporting live sheep and forcing more and more Australian meatworkers to join the dole queues goes on, we are importing boned mutton from New Zealand and consigning Australian boners to the industrial scrapheap.

The Farmers and Graziers Association contends that farmers own and breed the sheep or lambs and they have the right to determine to whom their stocks should be sold. It seems to me that the Farmers and Graziers Association reserves the right to do what it wants when it comes to its profits, disregarding the interest of the community. Yet it is the first to call on the community for assistance when times are bad. Its theory is that profits are sacred and private while losses, which occur for instance during a drought, should be shared by the community. It cannot have it both ways.

It is time that the Government stepped in. I am glad that the Minister for Primary Industry (Mr Kerin) is at the table. I think he will take notice of what I am talking about. He is a very good Minister. He is often in the chamber and takes an interest in proceedings. I hope the Government will step in and bring some sanity and order into marketing to prevent the export of live sheep while we are importing processed mutton, thus ruining our meat industry.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: O'Keefe Mr F.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is desired to bring before the House a problem being experienced by constituents of mine, Mr and Mrs Klass Nierop of Meroo Crossing, Maitland Bar, Avisford, in the district of Mudgee, New South Wales, concerning an insurance claim of $125,000 for damage sustained in the loss of 22 pallets of venison consigned by semi-trailer from Mudgee to Melbourne. This consignment was insured with Norwich Winterthur Insurance (Australia) Ltd, a company with branch offices in Victoria, New South Wales, South Australia, Queensland, Western Australia and Tasmania. When travelling between Mudgee and Melbourne, the semi-trailer ran off the road and was destroyed with its contents of venison. This accident took place on 26 July 1983. A claim was lodged by Mr Nierop on 3 September 1983. Norwich Winterthur replied in September of that year denying any liability. The delay in Mr Nierop's sending in a claim five weeks after the accident was because at the time he had occasion to travel to Holland owing to the death of his aged mother.

SPEECH.PARA: Mr Nierop approached Anthony Davis and Co., solicitors of Penthouse, 41 Glen Street, Milson's Point, Sydney, to act on his behalf in this matter. I have contacted Davis and Co., who informed me that to date all its letters to Norwich Winterthur Insurance (Australia) Ltd have been completely ignored. Mr Nierop cannot afford the fees or the delay occasioned by court proceedings. No doubt this may be what the insurance company wants. It is a serious problem when, after a premium is paid and accepted by this company and when a claim takes place, the company denies liability. Mr Nierop is in great financial difficulties as a result of the Norwich Winterthur Insurance company not paying for the loss of the $125,000 worth of venison which was packed in excellent containers. It was a marine insurance policy. I have a copy of the policy here. I seek leave to have it incorporated in Hansard.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! There are rather strict rules about the incorporation of documents in Hansard. The rules apply only to the incorporation of tables. Essentially, Hansard is a record of the spoken word.

—As far as can be ascertained Mr Nierop has complied with all items enumerated in his policy document. This is a very serious situation indeed. Actions of this kind put the insurance industry in bad repute. I hope that Norwich Winterthur Insurance meets the claim which Mr Nierop has made as he has sustained considerable loss.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hollis Mr C.

TALK.START.PARA: —Few topics have generated as many column inches recently as the dispute in which the doctors have engaged in their totally unjustifiable strike action, so strongly supported by those who sit opposite, although at this time of the evening, as usual, there are not too many of them sitting opposite.
—Why do you hate doctors?

—The honourable member should wait until he hears what I have to say. The doctors have argued that their dispute is not about money and that their first consideration is and always has been patient care. Today I was informed of a particular case concerning a constituent of mine. Some three weeks ago Mrs Francis Brownett of Dapto was working as a parking patrol officer at Port Kembla when she fell and broke her leg in three places. She was outside the surgery of a Dr Knott and was taken to his surgery for treatment, and, as one can imagine, taken there in considerable pain. As this would have been a compensation case, Dr Knott refused to treat my constituent, claiming that the police department was a slow payer. So much for doctors not being interested in money. Honourable members opposite have gone awfully quiet now.
—No, we are just surprised at your stupidity.

—The honourable member should wait for this one. Mrs Brownett had to produce 20c before the staff would even telephone the police so that they could collect my constituent. One feels that this particular doctor, Dr Knott, has not instructed his staff in correct procedures. Where else but in a doctor's surgery in 1984 would a person, in pain and injured, have to produce 20c for a call for help? Today I contacted Mrs Brownett and also spoke with Dr Knott. Not surprisingly, Dr Knott was reluctant to speak to me at first, but he did say that my constituent had the alternative of being treated as a private patient. Unfortunately, on that day my constituent was not carrying a large sum of money, so she received no treatment. Regardless of the circumstances, the patient should have been treated even if only on a temporary basis. She should have had the opportunity to have had the pain and suffering she was experiencing relieved . The facts that have been presented to me fill me with disgust.

SPEECH.PARA: We are always told that the patients come first. Here is a case where the money most certainly came first. As I said, on the facts presented to me, this doctor was obliged to give treatment. How many other such cases are occurring, I wonder , while these greedy doctors, educated by the taxpayers at great public expense, are grabbing for more and more money? No wonder doctors have fallen so far in public esteem. I hope that those few people who have written to me-the very few- supporting the wild and irresponsible behaviour of the doctors will hear about this unfortunate case. Most certainly, everyone who writes to me about it will get a copy of this speech.

This is yet another example of the unreal world in which doctors exist. What concerns me is how many other such outrages occur. What if I had not heard of this case? How many other cases are happening which the local members hear nothing about? There is no excuse for Dr Knott not treating my constituent. I hope that the Australian Medical Association, which has been so vocal about doctors and is so vocal at the moment, takes up this case. It gives me no pleasure to name this doctor in the House this evening but Dr Knott of Port Kembla deserves to be named. I have no alternative but to name him. I am sure that all honourable members will join me in condemning this inhuman and inhumane treatment by Dr Knott.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Shipton Mr R.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to speak in this debate about the new Kangaroo air pass air fares announced by the Government last week. The Minister for Aviation (Mr Beazley) says that these fares are a good thing. I point out to the Minister that they amount to a bungle and that they are a farce. If he listens to me he will find out why. The new internal tourist fare structure, which gives up to 6,000 kilometres of travel for $500 appears to be only about 10 per cent cheaper than regular APEX fares but does nothing at all to encourage people living in Western Australia to holiday in their own State. As I said previously, Western Australia by the Government's action is obliterated from the tourist map. Earlier today the Minister for Aviation said that that was wrong and he attacked me for saying it. But it is completely true. The fares discourage Australians from travelling to Western Australia and they also discourage Western Australians from travelling in their own State. Another aspect of the fares is that whenever a traveller changes his or her itinerary there is an extra charge of $25.

SPEECH.PARA: Apparently the new air fares amount to an average of a 35 per cent reduction in normal fares which compares with the flexi-fare existing fare plan which gives a 45 per cent reduction. So as the Government says, the new fares give a 35 per cent average cut. I take on board the fact that that may not, in fact, be correct on closer examination, as I will show honourable members later in a couple of examples. The reduction is only 35 per cent, whereas the existing flexi-fare available gives a 45 per cent reduction.

Let us look at some fares. As I understand it, the Melbourne-Perth return APEX fare is $441.50. As I understand it, the distance from Melbourne to Perth is more than 6,000 kilometres. So if one wants to travel under the new Kangaroo Pass fare one has to pay $500, compared with the APEX fare of $441.50.

Let us look at a flexi-fare example. The Sydney to Perth flexi-fare, as I understand it, is $381. But the fare under the Kangaroo Pass is $800. That is $ 419 more expensive. Is that what the Minister for Primary Industry (Mr Kerin) thinks is a good idea? Is that what he is telling us the people of Australia are pleased about?

TALK.START.PARA: —I think the whole idea is a good idea.
—If we want to go to Perth under a flexi-fare from Sydney--
—You are just against private enterprise.
—He says it is private enterprise. The Minister at the table is attacking private enterprise. Let us place that on the record.
—No, you are. You are attacking the airlines. You are attacking Ansett.

—I am not attacking it. I am attacking the Government because the Minister for Sport, Recreation and Tourism (Mr John Brown) has flown around Australia and he has bragged about the new air fares. He said it was likely that there would be a simple 30-day air fare. He has been proved wrong. Then he announced on Friday that all the vegemite eating Australians could travel under the cheaper air fares. The Minister for Sport, Recreation and Tourism said all of those things. The Minister for Aviation said in the House today that they are not the Government's air fares. The Government ought to work out what it is about. It cannot have its cake and eat it too. The Government is either praising the air fares-it has caused the air fares to come about and they are the Government's air fares-or it is not. I wish it would tell us. Perhaps the Minister will be able to inform us, because it is a complete shambles.

SPEECH.PARA: As I said, the new air fares hit Western Australia particularly hard. They hit Western Australians who want to travel and they hit the Western Australian tourist industry hard. They do nothing to encourage Western Australians to holiday in their own State and nothing to encourage travellers from the rest of Australia to go west for a holiday. It is an absolute farce and an absolute disgrace. As I understand it, in Western Australia people cannot travel under these fares to Derby, Broome, Wyndham, Katanning, Learmonth, Carnarvon, Geraldton, Albany or Kalgoorlie. In Victoria, people cannot travel to Mildura and Warrnambool. This Government is not interested in tourism in regional Australia. In New South Wales, people cannot travel to Moree, Walgett, Dubbo, Mudgee, Griffith, Narrandera, Wagga Wagga, Albury and Cooma. It is a disgrace that this Government is announcing air fares, bragging about newly created air fare decreases and is excluding regional and rural cities.

The Minister for Primary Industry ought to tell his colleagues what a disgrace it is, because he is meant to be interested in rural Australia. Rural Australia, with its great tourist attractions in the outback and regional cities and towns, is denied the opportunity to get the tourist dollar because of the Government's policy. The cities and places in country, outback, rural and regional Australia will not be able to benefit from the increased tourist industry in Australia.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Theophanous Dr A.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —Let me say, as someone who knows a lot about the subject of tourism because of the Caucus industry committee, that this Government has done more for tourism in its first year than was achieved in the totality of the seven years of the Fraser Government. I want to talk about a matter of national importance which concerns the advertisements that have appeared which attack the resource rent tax.
—Hear, hear!

—Is the honourable member financing them? Is that where the money is coming from? These advertisements are a disgrace and they are nothing more than an attempt by a very narrow interest group to support its own position. What is the narrow interest group? We know that Esso-BHP is behind the advertisements because, quite bluntly, it is not interested in paying its fair share of taxation. Whichever government was in power at present-there is no question about it-would impose a tax. We now have attacks on the resource rent tax which claim that the resource rent tax will stop exploration, that it is a contradiction of agreements. It is nothing of the kind. The fact is that the resource rent tax was an integral part of the policy of the Government and the policy which the Labor Opposition put to the people in March of last year.

SPEECH.PARA: I make it clear with regard to the resource rent tax that I cannot understand what the attacks are all about because the proposals are extremely fair to private enterprise, because the resource rent tax applies only when a substantial profit has been made. If, in the process of development of the mining industry a company is not making a profit, it does not pay the resource rent tax. The present situation is that a levy is paid, and it is paid whether or not a profit is made. But in the case of the resource rent tax a company pays only on the basis of the proportion of its profit. Why are we seeing these attacks in the newspapers? Is it the intention of Esso-BHP that the Government should impose a levy rather than a rent tax, as has been leaked as a suggestion to the newspapers? A levy might be appropriate for Esso-BHP, but it would not be appropriate for smaller exploration companies, because a levy would count against them in the initial stages of production.

TALK.START.PARA: —You slapped the tax on Utah. That was a levy.

—The honourable member has had his chance to speak. I am trying to explain to people the reasons why this is a dishonest campaign against the resource rent tax. The resource rent tax, as I mentioned, is applied on the basis of profitability. Smaller companies interested in exploration, et cetera would benefit from the resource rent tax because they would not have to pay the tax on the basis of production. Their payment of the tax would be on the basis of the profit generated from the project. Nothing could be fairer than that in terms of a taxation regime.

SPEECH.PARA: We are seeing irrational attacks by companies as if they hope, by means of these irrational attacks, to avoid all forms of tax altogether. The key clause in the advertisement, which I challenge the Opposition to comment on, states:
The proposed resource rent tax, or any other tax for that matter, will cut back oil exploration in Australia.

Is it the suggestion of the Opposition that there be no tax on oil? If that is its position, let it state it. If that is its position it shows irresponsibility in relation to taxation in this country. We have made it clear from the very beginning, when the Minister for Resources and Energy (Senator Walsh) and the Government have talked about the resource rent tax, that we will be looking at a policy of off-setting exploration. I will explain that in more detail because obviously some people have not understood it. We are intending to ensure that where genuine exploration activities take place there will be a generous off-set policy for the resource rent tax. So what do we have? We have a tax which applies only when there is profitability and, in addition to that, we have an off-set program so that when there is genuine exploration activity we can off- set those activities.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cowan Mr D.B.

TALK.START.PARA: —In the minute or so available to me I appeal to the Minister for Primary Industry (Mr Kerin), who is at the table, to review the export meat inspection charges. I know that over a period there has been very great pressure upon him to review the charges because of the present position of the beef industry. This was a Budget measure followed by the necessary legislation. The Opposition appealed to the Government at the time of its introduction that in view of the circumstances existing in the meat industry there should be a review of the charges. The situation has worsened since then. The inspection charges have increased from $1.80 a beast to $5.40 a beast, so the charges have actually tripled. It has been strongly opposed by the beef industry throughout Australia, and the same charge, on a percentage basis, applies in respect of the export pork and sheep carcasses.

SPEECH.PARA: I appeal to the Minister, as I said earlier, because of the circumstances involved today in the industry. We have a single meat inspection service, which was certainly supported by us. But that meat inspection has meant that there are very few, if any, inspectors who have been taken away from the service. Today, the producers are paying the extra cost involved. Overtime expenses with regard to the meat works and the owners and other such expenses are being relayed all the time back to the producer. Actually, our beef export prices generally have not increased. In the case of breeders, they have increased.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Interception of Communications: Authorisations by Attorney-General

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Campbell Mr G.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Attorney-General, upon notice, on 24 August 1983:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) How many warrants has the Attorney-General issued in each State and Territory since 5 March 1983 authorising interception of (a) telephone, and (b) other telecommunications services by (i) Australian Security Intelligence Organisations, and (ii) other Commonwealth or State government agencies.
(2) Have any of these warrants authorised interception of communications of either State or Commonwealth members of parliament.

(3) Are conversations transcribed; if so, what safeguards exist to ensure that the transcripts are (a) accurate, and(b) destroyed or removed from individual's files if of no relevance to any matter under investigation by such agencies.
(4) Are transcripts or other information obtained from these interceptions disclosed to any overseas government or agency.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Bowen The Hon L.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Attorney-General has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) (a) (i) and (b) (i) In accordance with the approach taken in my answer to Dr Klugman's question on telephone tapping (Hansard, 16 November 1983, page 2839 ), I do not propose to answer questions seeking specific numbers of ASIO interception authorisations.

(a) (ii) and (b) (ii) The Telecommunications (Interceptions) Act 1979 empowers the Attorney-General to authorise, by warrant, the interception of telecommunications and telegrams by the Australian Security Intelligence Organisation. The Attorney-General has no power to authorise such interception by any other Commonwealth agency, or by any State Government agency.
(2) and (4) The Government follows the practice of previous governments of not responding to specific questions which may relate to the activities of ASIO.

(3) (a) Where transcripts are made of intercepted communications, I expect ASIO to use all care to ensure that the transcripts are accurate. A number of measures have recently been taken, announced by me on 25 February, to improve performance in the monitoring and supervisory areas of ASIO activities.

(b) Section 14, Telecommunications (Interception) Act provides that where a transcript is made of an intercepted communication, and the Director-General of Security is satisfied that the transcript is not required and is not likely to be required in connection with the performance by the Organisation of its functions or the exercise of its powers, the Director-General is required to have the record destroyed. I am assured by the Director-General of Security that this requirement is strictly followed.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Lloyd Mr B.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Communications, upon notice, on 20 October 1983 :

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Does the installation cost of a digital radio concentrator system service for subscribers vary between $15,000 and $60,000 and is the average cost about $ 20,000; if so, (a) what is the average cost per subscriber for a satellite telephone service and (b) what ratio of subscriber connections to satellite channels has been used.

(2) Will there be an additional charge for the satellite service, for the use of the transponder, main earth station and special exchange equipment, but not for the DRCS service; if so, what are the reasons.
(3) Has he instructed Telecom Australia to apply a user pay principle to the satellite telephone service to be operated by Telecom contrary to its established policy.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Duffy The Hon M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Yes. (a) and (b) Telecom has not yet developed charges for the provision of telephone services via the satellite. Because of the very high costs involved it sees the primary market for satellite telephone services in remote areas being for commercial ventures such as mining sites, exploration sites and tourist developments, but service may be provided also to smaller communities as well as to individual landowners. The installed costs of a remote rural station and associated terminal equipment required to provide service begin at an amount of $60,000. To this must be added annual costs for the use of the satellite transponder, the main rural station and special exchange equipment.
(2) Telecom has advised that its charges for service, including contribution to the connection costs, will take into account the much higher costs of the satellite system.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Adermann The Hon A.E.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Prime Minister, upon notice, on 9 November 1983:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Is he able to say how many signatories have appended their names to petitions presented to (a) the House of Representatives and (b) the Senate protesting against (i) ratification of the United Nations Treaty and (ii) legislation proposed by the Government relating to sex discrimination considerations.
(2) Does the Government propose to ignore this expression of public opinion.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hawke The Hon R.J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) and (2) The honourable member has, in common with other members access to records of the House of Representatives and the Senate with respect to petitions lodged.

The Government in deciding to ratify the United Nations Convention on the Elimination of All Forms of Discrimination Against Women, and in proposing sex discrimination legislation to the Parliament, consulted widely and took into account expressions of public opinion such as those included in petitions to both Houses. The Government does not make decisions on the basis of crude head counting, nor does the Australian community expect it to do so.

The Convention is the most important international human rights instrument relating to women. It calls on States Parties to eliminate discrimination against women and to ensure them equal rights with men in political, social, cultural, civil and other fields.

The sex discrimination legislation passed by the Parliament on 7 March 1984 gives legislative effect within Australia to some of the provisions of the Convention dealing with the elimination of discrimination against women. It provides machinery for people who believe they have been treated less favourably because of their sex in employment, education, accommodation, and other public aspects of life to make a complaint and have it conciliated.
All fair-minded Australians support these objectives.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Dawkins The Hon J.S.

ANSWER.PARA: The Public Service Board's central personnel records indicate the following positions to which Dr Wilenski was appointed up to the time of his appointment as Chairman of the Public Service Board in November 1983.

Promoted to External Affairs Officer, Class 2, Overseas Division, Department of External Affairs-June 1969.

Promoted to External Affairs Officer, Class 3, Overseas Division, Department of Foreign Affairs-May 1971.
Promoted to Chief Finance Officer, Clerk Class 11, Overseas Economic Relations Division, Department of Treasury-November 1971.
Transferred to Department of Prime Minister and Cabinet, unattached list. Appointed Principal Private Secretary, Level 2, to the Prime Minister-January 1973.

Reappointed by the Public Service Board as Assistant Secretary, Level 2, Local and Regional Affairs Branch, Revenue Loans and Investment Division, Department of the Treasury, but continued secondment to Royal Commission-September 1974.

Appointed Secretary to the Department of Labour and Immigration-March 1975.

In addition Dr Wilenski has held the following statutory appointments:

I should add that, while an unattached First Division Officer, Dr Wilenski was successively appointed as:

Concurrently with these appointments he was Commissioner in charge of the Review of New South Wales Government Administration and served as a consultant to the OECD, and to the governments of Zimbabwe, Papua New Guinea, South Australia and Tasmania. He was also Visiting Scholar at the National Academy of Public Administration, Washington.
The honourable member may wish to know that Dr Wilenski holds the following qualifications and awards:

Master of Arts, International Affairs-Carleton University

No doubt this and his other qualifications have been relevant to the appointments he has won and been given. In 1983 Dr Wilenski was elected a Fellow of the Royal Australian Institute of Public Administration.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Hunt The Hon R.J.D.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Education and Youth Affairs, upon notice, on 17 November 1983:

QUESTION.PARA: Does the Minister have any plans to develop a core curriculum for distance education so that the satellite system can be used efficiently and in the best interests of education in remote areas when the communications satellite is in operation in 1985; if not, why not.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Dawkins The Hon J.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Education and Youth Affairs has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question:

ANSWER.PARA: Both Commonwealth and State governments acknowledge that students in remote areas are in need of particular educational provisions and, for this reason, special programs to assist isolated school students have been in operation for some time.

Before addressing that issue, however, I should first like to explain the concept of core curriculum. The notion of a core curriculum for Australian schools, to which the honourable member refers, has attracted some attention throughout Australia in recent years. At the basis of this concept is a belief that, by sharing a common range of learning and social experiences, all students may have an opportunity to participate more fully in Australian society. However , the honourable member would be aware that ultimate responsibility for determining school curricula rests with the various system-level authorities, both government and non-government, in the States and Territories. The Commonwealth Government does not provide schools with core curriculum materials. The Curriculum Development Centre, to be reactivated within the Commonwealth Schools Commission, will develop curriculum materials for use in schools, but the extent to which school systems choose to utilise them will be a matter for decision by individual education authorities.

I return now to the issue of the potential role of satellites in providing education for students in remote areas. The Australian Education Council, which comprises all State Ministers for Education plus the Commonwealth and Northern Territory Education Ministers, discussed at a recent meeting the educational potential of current and emerging developments in technology, including the domestic communications satellite. The Council consequently decided to establish a task force to develop policies on education and technology. The deliberations of the task force should help to encourage a national approach towards these issues.

Among other things, the task force is to consider its relationship to the existing Commonwealth-State Advisory Committee on the Educational Use of Communications Technology. This Committee is currently sponsoring a three-year trials program. Some of these trials are aimed at investigating the potential for educational use of the domestic communications satellite. Examples of trials funded under the program are: Co-ordination of access to the ATS-1 satellite for communication experimentation by education institutions; the development of two- way television teaching techniques; the use of supplementary FM signals for university distance education; and a study of how school students use distance learning materials.
It is hoped that the outcomes of these projects will give education authorities valuable guidance in developing educational programs utilising communications technology.

Education authorities recognise that use of the satellite has potential for increasing co-operation among them in the interests of enhanced education services. The Commonwealth, for its part, will certainly be willing to co- operate in encouraging such developments.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Use of Private Vehicles to Transport Participants in the Community Youth Support Scheme

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Lloyd Mr B.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations, upon notice, on 8 December 1983:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Has his attention been drawn to complaints by community youth support scheme project officers and committees, particularly in country areas where there is no public transport, that the revised blanket insurance arrangements are not adequate.
(2) What action is being taken to remedy these shortcomings which potentially put at risk, participants, officers and helpers when transporting participants in private vehicles.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Willis The Hon R.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) No. I am not aware of complaints about inadequacy of community youth support scheme-CYSS-national blanket insurance arrangements in country areas. These arrangements, which were implemented from 1 July 1983, have been obtained on behalf of CYSS local management committees to relieve them of the burden of obtaining adequate insurance cover, and to ensure that the wide range of necessary cover was in place.
The CYSS insurance arrangements include workers' compensation cover for all CYSS employees and personal accident cover for participants and voluntary assistants.
All CYSS personnel who transport participants in private vehicles would, of course, be covered by statutory third party insurance applying to motor vehicles .

The Department recommends to CYSS local management committees that project staff using their own vehicles receive payment of travelling allowances at rates which include a component to allow for the purchase of comprehensive insurance and that all private vehicles used on project business are at least insured against third party property damage.

(2) Subject to arranging the motor vehicle insurance recommended by the Department, the arrangements currently in place fully cover participants, project staff and helpers who transport participants in private vehicles. The Department is however investigating the possibility of obtaining contingency third party liability cover on behalf of all CYSS local management committees in order to protect them against legal liabilities which arise as a result of use of inadequately insured vehicles.
